contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I love Project Runway. Why do I love that and a lot of other reality shows? Because the judges are smart, and the contestants have a skill that the people in the audience don't have. The challenges are almost impossible enough that you wonder how they could possibly do it...and then they do.
So you know I'm excited that the company behind Project Runway, Bunim/Murray Productions, is about to launch a new TV series centered around car designers.

The new reality series is going to be called Revved Up, and it's going to be great. The company is going to be casting people who want to be "the best car visionary ever," and maybe you (or somebody you know) are one of them.
Bunim/Murray says the casting process will look for designers, and they are hoping a lot of the applicants will be women, who "think their car design skills can  impress a leading car manufacturer."
Here's how to enter. Go to BMP Casting or email autocasting@bunimmurray.com with your, name, phone number, and a brief biography, along with two photos of yourself and your work.
If you love auto design, no matter what your experience level, get in touch with them! And tell them Jean sent you.

title: 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid

promoTeaser: Looking for a car with a mainstream look and feel that gets 50 mpg in the city?
metaTitle: 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid: The newest Accord posts some impressive numbers: 50 mpg in the city, and 673 miles between fillups. I drove it in San Antonio, and here's my report. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Does San Antonio, Texas, seem like the right place to launch a hybrid car to you? Texas is land of the pickup truck, land of the cattle ranch, land of the oil wells, with gasoline prices often as much as thirty cents lower than the national average. It’s hard to imagine a hybrid becoming trendy here. But Honda says it makes perfect sense as the place to launch its 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid, so that's where I went.

As old as the cliché is, everything’s still bigger in Texas. To Honda, the Accord Hybrid is big. It may not have a big engine or a lot of cargo space (three cubic feet less trunk space than the gasoline model), but it does have something that no other four-door sedan has: a 50-mpg city EPA rating. Honda thinks that number is a game changer. And here's another one: 673 miles. That's the combined gas-electric driving range of the new Accord Hybrid. Those are big, all right.

A Honda Accord Hybrid makes so much sense, you might be surprised to learn that there isn’t already one on the market. In fact, there was one on the market in the early 2000s, but that model mated an electric motor to a V-6 engine, and it was focused more on providing power than avoiding high fuel costs. Now, Honda is unveiling its 2014 Accord Hybrid, and it's come back with a bang. The new system has not one but two electric motors, to give it that all-important 50 mpg in the city, making it the most fuel efficient four-door sedan in production today.

Honda accomplished this feat with a combination of several fuel-efficient technologies. Its Atkinson cycle engine has slightly different valve timing than other gasoline engines, which helps make it more efficient. It has regenerative braking technology allows the Accord Hybrid’s generator to recapture energy when the car is coasting or coming to a stop, which can help extend its battery-only range.
Honda’s biggest innovation, though, is its two-motor hybrid system, also seen in the 2014 Honda Accord Plug-in.

Honda is at pains to emphasize how seamless this process is. Here's a summary of how it works: The first motor, called the drive motor, propels the wheels. The second one, the generator motor, is connected to the engine and supplies electrical energy to the drive motor and the car’s battery. In this setup, the engine is only rarely connected to the wheels, when cruising at medium to high speeds, for instance. Otherwise, the car will roll along in Hybrid mode (the default mode) or EV mode. EV mode, where the Accord Hybrid runs on power from the battery alone, can last up to a couple of miles in city driving, and once the battery is depleted the car will automatically switch back to Hybrid mode, where the electric motors get a boost from the Accord Hybrid’s 141-horsepower 2.0-liter engine.
With all its various technologies, talk of the Accord Hybrid can get a little academic. So what’s it like to actually drive the thing?

Composed on the Road, Communicative Inside

The Accord Hybrid may not be the kind of car you’d drive around the winding roads of Texas hill country if you could pick anything, but it was stable and sure-footed, and it handled the bends in the road with the composure of a much sportier car. It was also comfortable and not burdened by the cheesy eco-friendly interiors some hybrid cars insist on. No, here you can have comfortable leather seats (standard in EX-L and Touring trim levels) and sleek piano black accents on the dashboard and steering wheel. An eight-inch driver information display comes standard and will show you real-time fuel economy numbers.
A rearview camera is also standard. Instead of feeling self-consciously green, the Accord Hybrid just feels like a regular car: one with slightly decreased trunk space and terrific fuel economy.

So back to that 50-mpg rating: how real is it? Honda is so proud of its class-leading efficiency rating that practically every room the journalists were shepherded into during the two-day trip had a giant “50 MPG ACCORD!” banner hanging in it. The social media hashtag for the drive was #50mpgaccord, and as we stepped into our cars for the morning jaunt, Honda PR reps were on hand to remind us that the cars were rated at, you guessed it, 50 mpg in the city.

Real-World Numbers up to 80 MPG

With all that hype, I almost expected the Accord Hybrid to fall short, kind of a too-good-to-be-true situation. But on my two-hour morning drive I matched the 47 mpg combined rating (our drive was mostly on country roads with 55-mph speed limits), and on an afternoon city driving loop I saw indicated fuel economy numbers in the mid-60s. Some other journalists got 70 or 80 mpg on the same loop.

The 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid may be every bit as good as Honda says it is, but that still doesn’t necessarily mean it’s the only logical choice for hybrid buyers. It drives better than most of its competitors and has better EPA ratings than all of them. But it’s also a little on the pricey end of the sedans-turned-green segment (the Hyundai Sonata, Ford Fusion, and Toyota Camry hybrid models all start in the mid-$26,000 range) and suffers from slightly boring styling. Even with those marks against it, the 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid seems poised to take the hybrid market by storm.

2014 Honda Accord Hybrid

Base price: $29,845
Engine: 2.0-liter Atkinson-cycle DOHC I-4, 141 horsepower, 122 pound-feet of torque;
Total hybrid system power 196 hp
Transmission: Electric continuously variable (E-CVT)
Fuel economy: 50 mpg city/45 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Eight-inch driver information display with fuel efficiency data
Option I can’t live without: Leather-trimmed seats (standard in EX-L and Touring models)
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion Hybrid, Hyundai Sonata Hybrid, Toyota Camry Hybrid

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Here are a few things we ran across on the way to finding what we were looking for. Go ahead, click on them and let these random items sidetrack you. It's fun.

1. As our loyal readers know, at Jean Knows Cars we believe in properly restraining your dog in the car, but we also can appreciate this tumblr site that showcases dogs and cars. I choose to believe that the cars aren’t moving. I think we can help fill this site with our canine companions properly restrained, but check out this picture! Brilliant.
2. Who you gonna call? Loren Baldwin, if you want a ride in an Ectomobile replica (of Ghostbusters fame).Remember, never make fun of someone’s passion.

3. Kia is perched in the catbird seat for the first-ever YouTube Music Awards. It seems like a no-brainer to sponsor this worldwide digital event. According to the press release, "On Sunday, November 3, in the twelve-to-twenty-four-hour period before the awards ceremony, live streamed concert events will commence starting in Seoul, moving to Moscow, London, and Brazil, and concluding with the main awards show at Pier 36 in New York." Afterward, Youtube viewers will cast their votes and pick the winners. YouTube’s darling Lady Gaga will be featured along with Eminem, and Arcade Fire at the live-streaming event. I would think this is the right demographic for Kia and the right ingredients for a party.

4. My wing suit is on back order, but easy-on-the-eyes BASE jumper Dave Barlia is featured in this Nissan video flying like an eagle to beat Germany’s 2012 Nissan GT Academy Champion, Peter Pyzera. Nissan’s GT Academy is a competition created by Nissan and Playstation that finds the best online gamers and gives the winner a contract with Nissan for a race season and the chance to actually race in the real world.

5. Ron Burgundy insults a horse and then beats him in a staring contest—all while the innocent Dodge Durango stands by. If you are anxiously awaiting Anchorman 2, this ad may tide you over until Christmas.

6. Autumn de Wilde may not be a household name, but there is a good chance you have seen her work. She is an indie rock photographer and a music video director who is actually a superstar herself. She has worked with Beck, The White Stripes, Wilco, Fiona Apple, and literally dozens more. General Motors was more culturally aware than I was, and they snagged her to team up for the debut of the 2015 Cadillac Escalade.
And if you are like me, and want to learn more about Autumn, here is the rabbit hole.

7. The Chevrolet Tahoe had a starring role in the first episode of Nashville, but the day didn’t end so well for the Tahoe. Spoiler alert: Variety thought it was newsworthy that Chevrolet allowed the vehicle to be featured in a serious accident with the show’s main characters.

8. I am 5’ 7”, but most of my female friends hover down near the five-foot mark, and both my mother and mother-in-law are also vertically challenged. I see these short drivers struggle to reach pedals and find a driving position that is both comfortable and safe. The Wall Street Journal took a deep dive into developments car companies are taking to help both short and tall drivers. Now maybe I can sleep at night knowing my mother is not an inch away from the airbag.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Vital Stats

Base price: $60,450 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $61,345 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 20 mpg city/31 mpg highway
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6 engine, 310 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety features: Advance package (included in this top-of-the-line model) includes adaptive cruise control with new Low-Speed Follow and a collision mitigation braking system. The long list of standard safety features includes Blind Spot Information, seven airbags (including driver’s knee airbag), stability control, and a lane departure warning system
Tech features:Tech package includes navigation system with voice recognition, AcuraLink with real-time traffic, blind spot monitoring; all-wheel steering; Krell fourteen-speaker premium audio, SMS text messaging, Bluetooth, Pandora Internet interface, driver recognition memory system
Chief competitors: BMW 528i, Hyundai Genesis, Lincoln MKS, Mercedes-Benz E350 Sedan

Key Points

• The RLX is not a self-driving vehicle, but this car’s Adaptive Cruise Control with Low-Speed Follow is an example of technology inching us closer to the day when cars drive themselves. It lets the RLX independently maintain a set following distance in low-speed traffic situations, including stop and go traffic, and to initiate vehicle braking when necessary. When the car in front moves forward (out of danger), a vehicle icon on the multi-information display will start to blink. The driver then presses a steering-wheel-mounted button or the accelerator, and the RLX will resume the prior set speed.

• Many automakers, including Mercedes-Benz and Nissan, say “robot cars” are less than a decade away. The self-driving trend began in 2007 when Lexus offered an auto-parking feature that automatically parallel parks the car, a skill that few human drivers possess. The feature has moved into mass-market cars, including the Toyota Prius, Ford Escape, and Volkswagen Tiguan.

• More and more cars are getting these self-piloting features. The Infiniti Q50’s lane departure prevention with Active Lane Control/Predictive Forward Collision is a new option. It is an optics-based lane-keeping system that will intervene with steering if the system sense the car is driving out of lane. PFCW can judge the relative speeds of the cars ahead and alert the driver of imminent danger and intervene to lessen the impact.

• Of course, Google famously demonstrated its self-driving car in a YouTube video by putting a blind guy behind the wheel.

Audi rolled out Piloted Parking at the 2013 Consumer Electronics Show (see our article). The prototype system would allow drivers to exit their cars and send the cars off to park themselves. Drivers could summon the cars remotely with a phone app.
• All these high-tech goodies push the RLX Advance’s price up $12,000 over the $$49,345 cost (including destination) of the base model. Also, all the high-tech controls can be confusing.

• Despite all the high-tech stuff, the RLX barely keeps up with the stiff competition from the Germans. It’s a serious question whether the RLX feels and drives different enough from a Honda to justify a $60,000-plus price. The Mercedes-Benz E350 is much more luxurious. And competitors like the Hyundai Genesis offer many of the same tech features but undercut the RLX on price.
• The RLX gets kudos for a spacious interior and comfortable seats.
• But the base 2014 Audi A6 gets better fuel economy at 25 city/33 highway, according to EPA.

• The 2014 Acura RLX has not yet been rated for safety by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (and the website says no updates during the government shutdown). It gets just two ratings by Insurance Institute for Highway Safety; the RLX earned the top Good rating in moderate front overlap crash test and side crash tests.

promoTeaser: Pro/Con! Laura: Safety advances should be universal. Molly: Let the driver choose whether to buy it.
metaTitle: Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act
Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety
metaDescription: Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law? It's not just safety groups, parents, and automakers who are quarreling over that. Laura and Molly of the JKC.com staff are at odds, too. Read their pro and con on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Yes! The Government Should Mandate Rearview Cameras

Laura Sky Brown, Executive Editor (That's me on the left)

Have you used a rearview camera yet? They're becoming more common, and having used several in test cars, I now resent any vehicle I get into that doesn't have one. They're definitely on the list of things, like the iPhone and Vitamin Water Zero, that I never knew I needed but, having tried them, can no longer live without. The camera shows an image on your dashboard monitor (or sometimes your rearview mirror) of what's behind the car. The best part is the set of helpful lines that go from green to yellow to red as you get closer to that pole or curb behind you.

Just this morning, in fact, I climbed into a Dodge Avenger and put it in reverse, without the help of a rearview image. I was backing out of a diagonal parking space and had already clearly seen that the coast was clear and there was no chance anyone was anywhere nearby to walk behind me. Still, I just felt at a disadvantage, without a rearview camera in place, using the traditional mirrors and turning my head to the back. Those cameras show you the full picture of what’s behind you, and I don’t feel as good about doing without them now that the technology exists, even though I do know how to back up without one.

Government-mandated safety standards are undoubtedly controversial. Is it Big Brother to require motorcycle helmets? Seatbelts? Those high-mounted brake lights on the back of cars, which became a requirement with the 1986 model year? How about airbags? So, how about rearview cameras?

Yes, how about them. I am all in favor of seeing a law go into effect that makes car companies provide them, especially on big SUVs that ride high up off the ground, to make sure the driver can see small children behind the vehicle—but on any kind of car.

No! The Government Should Not Mandate Rearview Cameras, and Here's Why Not

Molly Jean, Senior Editor (That's me on the right)

I am a believer in choice. I agree with everything Laura says about the rearview camera, but I think it should be up to car buyers to decide whether or not they want to purchase it. When will the nanny state stop? A navigation system could also be considered a safety product by helping to keep the driver’s eyes on the road. Should the government mandate a navigation system in every car? I think the safest backup method is to walk around your car before slipping into the driver’s seat, and then to actually swivel around to view what is behind you as you slowly back up. I also know that some individuals, such as some older people, have a difficult time turning to look behind them and could really benefit from a rearview camera. But I still believe the individual should make the decision on whether one is needed. I have been lucky enough to drive many cars that are equipped with a rearview camera, and in fact the car I own has one. But it was not one of my requirements, like the heated seats were. Because I have been driving for over twenty years, it is not second nature for me to use the screen as I back up, so I rarely even remember I have one. But my teenage driver relies on it, especially when parallel parking.

At my husband’s job, employees were required to take a Smith System driving safety course. The program has a whole segment of the curriculum that focuses on reducing backup collisions. It's true that the amount of time that drivers spend backing up is minuscule compared with how much time they spend driving forward, yet a high number of collisions happen while reversing. The Smith System advocates for always backing into parking spots and grabbing pull-through spots whenever possible. Basically, the idea is to eliminate those blind-backup times altogether.

The bottom line is that a driver needs to be alert at all times, and especially while reversing. The rearview camera is a great tool, but I would like to be the one to make the decision on whether it is worth the investment.

Related story:

The Rearview Camera Fight: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that. October 9, 2013

title: 2014 Chevrolet Malibu LT
promoTeaserSmall: I could be good friends with this car. It wouldn't be a passionate affair, but that might be OK.
promoTeaser: I could be good friends with this car. It wouldn't be a passionate affair, but that might be OK.
metaTitle: 2014 Chevrolet Malibu - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Malibu: Should you buy this car? Laura and Molly tried it out on the country roads of Southeast Michigan, and here's their verdict. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $26,835 as tested (turbo model: $35,105 as tested) (prices include destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 196 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/36 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Stop/start technology
Option I can’t live without: Siri Eyes Free for use with iPhone
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Jetta
See more specs on the Chevrolet Malibu lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Niche cars are fun. Minicars are cute and funny, high-end sports cars are thrilling and attitudinal, and big utility vehicles are inspiring, challenging, and sometimes refreshingly weird. This is not a story about any of those. This is a story about the 2014 Chevrolet Malibu, the nice guy among cars: worthy of being appreciated for what it is. Why hold it up against more glamorous cars and say it doesn’t measure up?

Yes, the Malibu is the fourth runner-up this year in the sales contest in that most mainstream category of all, the mid-size sedan. In 2013 so far, the Malibu, despite being all new for the model year, has sold less than half as many copies as the leader, the Toyota Camry.
It’s for that reason that Chevrolet took that all-new model and redid it.

This story could sound discouraging for the Malibu, but the fact is that the car is actually improved in a few important ways, and the other fact is that senior editor Molly Jean and I enjoyed driving it around the countryside.
The 2014 Malibu has two interesting changes: stop/start technology and Text-to-Voice.

Stop/start technology is a fuel saver that has generally been found on more high-end vehicles, and the Malibu is the first in this segment to have this feature as standard. Basically, it works by having the engine shut off automatically when the car comes to a stop, for example at a light. It’s designed to be simple and seamless, and when we drove the Malibu through the small downtown of suburban Northville, we enjoyed waiting for it to kick in at stoplights and then listening to hear the engine resume when the light turned green. It would be a good feeling as the owner of this car to know you were saving gas while idling at intersections.

But let’s talk about that hands-free texting feature. Chevrolet is to be applauded for putting it on this mainstream car to help reduce the prevalence of cell-phone-in-ear syndrome on the roads. To take best advantage of the system, you should have an iPhone, because you can get the 2014 Malibu with Siri Eyes Free. Basically, it turns itself into a giant iPhone 4S or 5 by providing voice-controlled connectivity. I couldn’t wait to try it, and immediately on climbing in to the Malibu SE, I inserted my iPhone 4S into the perfectly sized slot in the center console, pressed the Bluetooth control, and gave it a try.

The Chevrolet version of Siri was a woman with a voice just a little different from that of the original. Molly and I tried out the Siri Eyes Free setup on Jean, calling her cell phone and taking turns shouting out our conversation through the Chevrolet MyLink system. Text-to-Voice converts text messages to speech and reads them aloud to you. The system also lets you send one of a number of text messages via voice commands, either stock ones ("I’m driving and can’t talk right now") or custom ones you create (“Is your homework done? Is your homework done? Is your homework done?” is one I’d set up and use a lot).

There are two engines available for the 2014 Malibu. There’s a new 2.5-liter four-cylinder Ecotec engine that makes 196 horsepower, teamed with a six-speed automatic transmission that’s new to the Malibu this year. Malibu chief engineer Todd Pawlik says Chevrolet expects 85 to 90 percent of buyers to choose this engine. Its fuel economy of 25 mpg in town and 36 mpg on the highway is comparable, for example, to the 26/34 mpg of the competitor Ford Fusion with the 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine.

The other engine is a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder that makes 259 horsepower and 295 pound-feet of torque. That torque is what gives the turbo engine its “oomph,” which we enjoyed while out on straight, deserted farmland roads. But honestly, for the way we would normally drive a mid-size sedan, I could see choosing the more fuel-efficient normally aspirated engine.

Chevrolet made a big deal out of the added 1.25 inches of legroom in the back seat for 2014. Apparently, people complained that it was too tight back there. And I can understand that complaint, because if you wanted a cramped back seat, you would buy a compact car, not a mid-size sedan. The back seat in the 2014 Malibu seemed adequate; the front seats have been reshaped to be more concave to accommodate the knees of your rear-seat passengers. There is a fold-down center console for times when you have two passengers, not three, back there.

As for interior amenities, Molly and I strongly disliked the shiny fake wood in an odd grayish hue. But the Chevrolet MyLink was a pleasure to use, as always: intuitive, clear, and simple. As a bonus, the screen flips open, secret agent style, to reveal a secret compartment big enough to hide your iPod or wallet...or that Snickers bar you are going to eat when the kids get out of the car at school.

Here's the thing about the Malibu: it's never going to be an exciting car. Nobody ever fell asleep at night dreaming about someday getting to drive one. But as your mother told you (and I tell my kids), there's a whole lot going on in life besides that. There's a different kind of excitement that comes from knowing you have a reliable, economical straight shooter of a car out in the driveway that will take you, your kids, and your stuff through the carpool and down to the Brownie meeting without drama.
Make fun of fleet-style cars all you want; they're (as that old commercial used to say) the heartbeat of America.

The Verdict:

Are you looking for a mid-size sedan? There are so many competitors, from the sleek and attractive Ford Fusion to the reliable standard Toyota Camry and Honda Accord to the quirkier Volkswagen Jetta. The Chevrolet Malibu has not stood out against that backdrop, and I'm not sure it does now, but that doesn't mean there's nothing to like about it. The stop/start technology, the voice to text, and the general user-friendliness of this car might be just what you're looking for. If so, you won't be swept off your feet, but that's not to say it might not be the beginning of a beautiful friendship for you and your family.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Malibu is in the uber-competitive family sedan segment, and this segment is in my opinion is also uber-bland. That being said, the Malibu is a perfectly fine-looking car, both inside and out. I was a little offended by the fake gray wood, but not too much. An awful lot of engineering has gone into the start/stop technology to help eke out better mpg numbers, and it is indeed a seamless movement. However, if you would like a turbo that also gets truly great mpg, you should consider the Volkswagen Passat TDI instead. The Malibu's turbo delivered instant acceleration but failed to give an exciting driving experience.

As I drove it, I repeatedly thought that the Malibu would be a perfect car for my husband—sensible, inexpensive, and not showy. I would recommend this car for someone who believes a car has one purpose: to shuttle people efficiently and have creature comforts that make the experience pleasant. It will not excite, but will suffice.

metaTitle: What I Drove Last Weekend! - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: What I Drove Last Weekend: Coming off a week in which I drove twenty-seven different cars, you wouldn't think a car could impress me much. You'd be wrong. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: On Wednesday and Thursday of last week, I drove a Porsche Cayman S, and then I drove twenty-six other cars.

I was at Gingerman Raceway on the west side of the state, working out what car would be Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Automobile of the Year. I was exhausted by Friday, climbed into a $113,000 Mercedes-Benz S550, and...wow! I was suddenly ready to drive another 500 miles.

This Mercedes-Benz is brand-new from the ground up for 2014 and highly anticipated because it’s the flagship. And now that there is no uber-luxurious Maybach as part of the Mercedes-Benz family, this would be its replacement as the limo-like sedan, the car that is not only fun to drive but exquisite to ride in.

I never in a million years expected it would look the way it did when I opened the door. It was absolutely and completely silver. Except for the outside, which is Anthracite Blue, a color I mistook for black all weekend. In my defense, anthracite does mean coal, after all.

The first thing you see when you open the door is a mesmerizing amount of silver wood trim. The steering wheel, the doors, the dash—all Metallized Ash wood trim. I couldn’t believe it was only an $800 option. It looked like a million bucks, and it suddenly made the wall-to-wall Crystal Gray/Seashell Gray nappa leather option ($2,290) look kind of normal by comparison.

To bring it all together, every switch, every button, plus the stereo speakers on the doors, was wildly beautifully designed of satin-finish silver metal. Everything you see, including the wheel you’re holding in your hand, is silver. And it is all delicately bathed in an atmospheric blue light. The only thing that was missing was a chandelier to complete the whole LIberace vibe.

Not that the Liberace vibe is a bad thing. And with 449 horsepower and 516 lb-ft of torque, there’s a goodly amount of power backed by a wallop of thrust. Translation: it was an absolute joy to drive. It has a torque vectoring brake system, which in practice means that when you go into a turn, the inside rear brake applies itself just enough to smooth your trajectory. Translation: you can go a lot faster in turns. For such a big car, the new S-class is incredibly agile.
You can also switch between Comfort and Sport mode, which changes the steering and suspension from cushy to boy racer.

Speaking of cushy, let me help you choose your options: the Premium 1 package ($4,500) is where you will find heated and active ventilated front seats, active multicontour seats with massage function (heated massage seat, better than your nail salon’s pedicure chair; it has active seat bolsters that bulk up and hold you firmly as you turn left and right; weird but comforting) and Seat Heating Plus (which heats the seats at warp speed) in the front, among other things. You also want the Warmth Comfort package ($2,600), where you will find a heated steering wheel and the new bar in cold climate luxury, heated armrests. You’ll also find the most amazing rear-seat functions, including hot and cold power-adjustable rear seats, the fast-acting Seat Heating Plus, and rear heated armrests. You can probably skip the Air Balance package that you see here ($350), which is perfume filtration and ionization by way of a diffuser bottle that sits on a little metal pad inside the glove box, delicately perfuming your interior surroundings. Kinda creepy.
And just in case you were worried at all about your back-seat passengers, they have fat, squishy suede pillows on top of the headrests like the pillow top on a high-end mattress.

I didn’t want to stray far from the television due to the opening games of the American League Championship playoffs. We went to dinner, we played golf, we saw Captain Phillips, I cried. We walked the dogs, ate apples, and ran Ray the Stray through the fields. I swapped my winter clothes for my summer clothes and hats. A very tedious thing that we in Michigan do this time of year.

The payoff? The Tigers beat the Red Sox in Game 1. Let’s not talk about Game 2. Let’s just say that if you, the Tigers fan, went to bed early on Sunday night, smirking about our 5-1 lead, you woke up Monday morning to a horrible, horrible surprise.
But I resumed my Monday morning in the Liberace limo, knowing the Tigers were going to win the next one.

Love,
Jean

title: Another Alarming Teen Driver Study
promoTeaserSmall: More to worry about! Teen accidents are much more likely when friends are in the car, a study shows.
promoTeaser: More to worry about! Teen accidents are much more likely when friends are in the car, a study shows.
metaTitle: Another Alarming Teen Driver Study - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Another Alarming Teen Driver Study: More to worry about! Teen accidents are much more likely when friends are in the car, a study shows.  Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Thinking about teenagers out on the road can scare a parent on the best day. But there might be a good reason for feeling alarmed: researchers at the Texas A&M Transportation Institute are out with a new study about teen drivers that has some less-than-encouraging statistics.

New research shows that novice teenage drivers, those ages fifteen to seventeen, are about eight times more likely than young adult drivers, those ages eighteen to twenty-four, to have a fatal crash if teenage passengers are in the car.
Driver distraction, especially the explosion in text messaging by young drivers, may be behind the dismal statistic.

Institute researchers say they looked at ten years of national data on fatal crashes in which teen passengers were present at the time of the crash. Researchers then compared patterns for novice drivers with those of young adult drivers to arrive at a “relative risk index.” Basically, the research shows that the younger the driver, the greater the risk. And, unfortunately, the problem is growing.
For novice drivers carrying two or more passengers in 2011, the teen passenger/fatal crash connection was 7.7 times more likely, up from 5.9 a decade earlier – an increase of 30 percent.

“Researchers did not explore reasons behind the upward trend,” the institute said. “However, the study points out that the ten-year period of analysis essentially mirrors the time when text messaging grew from an occasional activity to a practice that now largely defines youth culture.”

Young teen drivers also must overcome other safety hurdles. They include an overall lack of driving experience, along with slow brain development.
“Judgment and decision-making activities are centered in the prefrontal cortex of the brain, the region of the brain that is the last to develop and isn’t fully developed until about age twenty-five,” the institute noted. “Consequently, teen drivers lack full adult capabilities of understanding and avoiding the negative consequences of risky driving behavior.”

A recent YouTube video by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration advises parents to “find a way–any way” to lay down the law when it comes to safe driving. The video shows parents hiring an attorney to develop a driving “contract” for their son that includes such restrictions as “no cell phone use.”

But what power do parents really have to keep their kids safe? First of all, focus on the very real problem. American teenagers are more likely to die in a car crash than by any other means, according to U.S. Centers for Disease Control statistics.

Check out the CDC Teen Drivers Fact Sheet, which says that comprehensive graduated driver licensing, or GDL, programs are associated with reductions of 38 and 40 percent in fatal and injury crashes, respectively, among sixteen-year-old drivers. This is good news, but let's think about why that's the case. It's because a full license is delayed while teenagers get their initial driving experience under low-risk conditions.
“When parents know their state’s GDL laws, they can help enforce the laws and, in effect, help keep their teen drivers safe,” the CDC says.

As parents, let's go beyond just handing over the car keys. Let's pay attention to what our teenagers are allowed to do (and not allowed to do) under graduated licensing laws and reinforce that with talk, rules, and even contracts (here are some examples, from Toyota, the National Safety Council, and CDC).

But beyond that, we can think about why graduated licensing helps cut risks to inexperienced drivers. It is, in effect, a way for teens to get valuable experience behind the wheel while limiting such potentially dangerous behaviors such as late-night driving and ferrying a car full of other teenagers. Let them spend some of that time with you instead. During this probationary period, we should not stop setting a good example behind the wheel, spending time in the car with our teens while they drive, and finding opportunities to continue teaching safe driving techniques while they get their first few hundred miles in.

So, parents, let's put our own cell phones away, stop driving distracted, and set a good example. Let's mentor our kids during their early driving years, and let's also focus on being the drivers we want our kids to be.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text:
photo at top courtesy of Indian Motorcycles

Hello! I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. If you read my previous article, Falling in Love with Motorcycles, you know that I have logged a few hundred thousand motorcycle miles around the world, have owned seven motorcycles, and have formally tested 200 others as a motorcycle critic.

If you're interested in starting out with motorcycles, congratulations! But first, read my list of Five Things Every Woman Should Know before you get started.

Five Things Every Woman Should Know before Starting to Ride a Motorcycle


1.You need formal safety training. Ninety-two percent of motorcycle riders who end up involved in accidents either taught themselves or learned from family or friends. Motorcycle rider training not only reduces your chances of getting into an accident, it's correlated with reduced injuries in the event of an accident, according to the Hurt Report, the classic major motorcycle safety study. Motorcycles account for twelve percent of U.S. road fatalities, even though they make up less than one percent of vehicle miles travelled overall. Don't let yourself become a statistic.

2. Take the training before you buy your bike. I used to teach the Motorcycle Safety Foundation Basic Rider Course, and I can't tell you how many times students in the class decided they didn't actually enjoy riding or recognized they shouldn't be riding simply from taking the class.

3. Don't feel pressured to buy a first bike that's too large. It's tempting, when first starting on a bike, to buy the dream bike that inspired you to want to ride in the first place. Resist that temptation. More than half of the motorcyclists who have accidents have owned the bike on which they had that accident less than five months, so buy a beater bike instead. Start with a used 250- or 300-cc machine, and ride it for six months first. Doing so will build your confidence and your skills and will also save you money that's easily recouped by selling that bike when you've reached your six-month milestone. And it's likely to save you costly repair bills from dumping your dream bike early on. It might even save your life.
4. Never drink and ride. Not even a single beer. Almost half of the deaths that take place on motorcycles involve alcohol.

5. Wear proper riding gear. Fifty percent of motorcycle injuries are to the ankle/foot, lower leg, knee, and thigh/upper leg, but those injuries are less likely simply by wearing proper gear. Women make up about twelve percent of U.S. ridership and have been demanding higher-quality and better-looking gear that doesn't make them resemble brutish football players.

Whether it's motorcycle boots with slip-resistant soles, armored ankles and leather that won't burn when it comes in contact with a hot tailpipe, or pants and jackets with reinforced joints, be sure to buy it. And make sure you love what you buy, because protective gear can only do its job when it's worn.

title: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Has Your Back
promoTeaserSmall: All sizes of people should find the new sedan's seating comfy, thanks to extensive testing.
promoTeaser: All sizes of people should find the new sedan's seating comfy, thanks to extensive testing.
metaTitle: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Has Your Back - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Has Your Back: General Motors engineers studied all sizes of rear ends to make the big Chevy's seats just right. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: I’m probably not the only person who has arrived at a rest area after a long stint behind the wheel to feel my back snap, crackle, or pop on that walk to the bathroom. If an uncomfortable seat has ever been part of your driving experience, you'll appreciate that the human factors engineers at General Motors had your spine in mind when they designed the seats for the new 2014 Chevrolet Impala.  By marrying state-of the-art technology with low-tech methods, GM aimed to design a seat that comfortably accommodates everyone from Kristin Chenoweth to Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson and every BMI in between.

Call it the Goldilocks approach.  GM asked volunteer testers to spend hundreds of hours, over thousands of miles, in prototype vehicles evaluating seat comfort and providing feedback. The testers spanned the range of human configuration, from petite women at five feet tall and 110 pounds to men reaching upward of six feet or more and weighing in at 223 pounds.  After sixty minutes in the driver’s seat, each was asked to go beyond the fairy-tale-like measurements of too hard, too soft, and just right and numerically rate the comfort level of all the seat’s components: cushion, back rest, lumbar support, head rest, and side bolsters.  Of course, one person’s ten is another person’s “get me to a chiropractor," so that’s where biomechanics come in.

You're Sitting on 4,600 Data Points Right Now

Engineers gave testers’ brains a rest in order to enlist another part of the anatomy, their behinds. By sitting people of various builds in prototype seats blanketed with state-of-the-art digital pressure-mapping technology, engineers were able to create a map of more than 4,600 data points along the seat surface. That massive collection of data was then used to illustrate the driver’s experience either at rest or in the act of operating the vehicle.

A Little Help from Oscar

Arriving at the most comfortable seat design by combining hard data with testers’ personal feedback is what Jill Green, GM seat comfort lab manager, describes as “both an art and a science.” That includes another GM technology, employed in the early days of the Impala’s cabin design, known as Oscar. This metal and plastic mannequin-like tool weighs up to 170 pounds. It has a head, legs, a torso, and the ability to be reconfigured, which allows engineers determine interior dimensions to suit a wide array of human shapes and sizes.

After discovering all the effort that went into the Chevy’s seats, I couldn’t resist stopping by a local dealer to sit my own unique derrière in an Impala.  My first impression was a comfy, supportive feel, which became heavenly repose once I found the power eight-way seat adjuster and the four-way lumbar controls. These customizing controls come standard on every 2014 Impala, from the $27,670 LS base model up to the top-end $37,625 2LTZ.  Now that’s a feature I can get behind.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: I’m a sucker for a good road trip, so when my cousin Ellen told me she was planning a move to Washington, D.C., about a month ago, I immediately hopped on board and told her I’d drive. I was looking forward to a weekend escape from Michigan’s fall chill and perhaps a visit to the zoo, my favorite destination in any city.

What better vehicle than a Mercedes-Benz GLK250 BlueTec for our drive? I’d driven the diesel burner once before and wanted to see how it well my opinion of it would hold up on a long drive. I was also interested to see what Ellen, who isn’t exactly a car fiend, would think of driving a diesel-powered car.

The GLK250 BlueTec starts at $39,495 after destination, but the one that showed up in my driveway tipped the scales at $50,485. Our options included the $3,450 Premium package, which added auto-dimming mirrors, a power liftgate, SiriusXM radio, and an MP3 media interface, so you can hook your iPod directly up to the stereo. Another $2,790 got us a navigation system, a rearview camera, and a six-disc CD changer.

The standard MB-Tex (Mercedes-Benz code for “not leather”) seats were comfortable and attractive enough to make you think twice before springing for the $1,850 leather seating package. Also standard are 4Matic all-wheel drive, LED running lights, and Mercedes-Benz’s Attention Assist technology.

The GLK’s cargo area would have been more than large enough for two or even four people with just a weekend’s worth of luggage each, but since we were carrying a bit of a heavier load, we had to fold the rear seats down to preserve a clear view through the rear window. With a cooler full of sandwiches and cookies in the back, we were ready to ride.

Mercedes-Benz representatives often joke that if you take one of their diesel cars on a road trip, you’ll need to stop for a bathroom break before you need to stop for fuel. Indeed, when we made our first pit stop after nearly three hours of driving, the GLK250’s tank was still three-quarters full. The GLK250 BlueTec is rated at 33 mpg on the highway, but I had averaged more than 35 mpg, even while driving closer to 80 mph than 70.

When we stopped for dinner, we had just over a quarter of a tank of fuel and about 100 miles of driving left. I was confident that we would make it to Washington with room to spare, and I was right. With two miles to go to our destination, the low-fuel light came on, indicating that the car had a comfortable sixty miles of range left. We had averaged 35.6 mpg, more than two mpg over the GLK250’s highway EPA rating.

When I got back behind the driver’s seat on Sunday morning for my solo return trip, I was a little concerned that I would have a hard time finding diesel fuel in Washington, D.C. I needn’t have worried. The navigation system’s POI database had a special category for gas stations with diesel fuel. The fillup cost nearly $60, which seems like a lot until you consider that was all the fuel I’d needed to travel across four states. When I got back in the car, the trip calculator indicated that I had almost 600 miles of range, roughly twice the range of my personal car.

The GLK was just about everything you want from a road trip car. It’s attractive, it’s comfortable, it’s fuel-efficient, it’s quiet. Our only real complaints were that the GLK would struggle to comfortably accommodate rear passengers on a long drive, and that the navigation system’s voice guidance was essentially inaudible.

Mercedes-Benz has done an admirable thing with the GLK250 BlueTec: the company has  managed to create an alternative-fuel vehicle that you’ll forget is different. Until you realize you’re driving by all those gas stations you used to stop at.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $30,425 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 178 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: MyFord Sync voice-activated system
Option I can’t live without: Power liftgate($495)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Equinox, Honda CR-V, Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4

See more specs on the Ford Escape lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

When my high school besties decided to take a whirlwind trip to the Lake Michigan town of Saugatuck earlier this month, I took the opportunity to get some seat time in the 2014 Ford Escape. And there were some good reasons to get to know this new model. The Escape had an extensive redesign in 2013, and for 2014 both a rearview camera and the Sync system are now standard. Ford’s smallest sport-ute is trying to push the Honda CR-V off the sales pedestal for this competitive segment. A bit of trivia for your quiver: the F-Series truck is the only Ford vehicle that outsells the Escape.

In high school, we were most often driving around in my friend’s AMC Hornet that we had named the Hornet Bomb. The Hornet was built to battle with the imports in the early 1970s, and our old Hornet Bomb would be proud that the Escape is standing its own ground against both Honda and Toyota. My besties, Julie and Teresa, are car enthusiasts and happily agreed to help me take a hard look at the Escape.

The Escape actually looks more like a tall Focus than an Explorer, and that is not a bad thing. In fact, it is a good-looking vehicle from every angle, and the inside looks great, too. The material choices in the interior feel and look good. Even though the majority of the cabin is plain molded plastic, it doesn’t offend, and the gray cloth seats were nondescript. There is a feeling of utility with an emphasis on durability.

Ford has paid attention to the need to be more eco-friendly in material choices and used a soybean-based foam for the seats and head restraints, and the carpet is made out of recycled fibers and plastic bottles. The Escape also works on its carbon tireprint with its standard active grille shutters that make the vehicle more dynamic and help with the fuel economy (which is 26 mpg in the city, 32 mpg on the highway). I think this earth-friendly strategy is perfect for the Escape's demographic, and besides, it yields good karma points.

There are three trim levels available, S, SE, and the all-tricked-out Titanium. The Escape we tried was in High Impact Blue SE with a convenience package ($1,340) that included an eight-inch touchscreen with MyFord Touch, reverse sensing, a perimeter alarm, roof side rails, dual-zone temperature controls, nine speakers, and Sync Services. The power liftgate added another $495. The top-end Titanium models get a foot-activated hatch.  I for one would pony up for the luxury of swirling my foot under the bumper and having the hatch magically open.

Teresa called shotgun and grabbed the front seat navigator spot. Even though she was a basketball standout back in the day, she is just shy of 5'5", but strangely her head hit the roof of the car. We were sure that there must be some way to lower the front passenger's seat, but after consulting the manual, we realized that the four ways it did move were not up and down. Granted, she does have an abnormally long torso, but if you plan on having any tall passengers, they will be most comfortable in the rear seat. Full disclosure: this vehicle did have the panorama roof that takes away some headroom. It is a very nice option but comes with a $1,495 price tag.

We quickly switched navigators so that Julie, who is barely five feet, could feel tall in the catbird seat. The ten-way power driver’s seat did not suffer from the same height problem, and I was extremely comfortable. Too-tall-torso-Teresa was content in the back seat and never complained again. That is, until I made her pump the gas.

I am not a fan of pumping gas. In high school, I lost too many gas caps, and I always think my hands end up with a slight smell of gasoline. The Escape, in fact like all Fords, has a capless gas tank—genius. Seriously, is there a prize for most obvious invention ever?

Julie was our DJ for the day and pecked around on the MyFord Touch, toggling between SiriusXM satellite radio and FM—she is one of those people who change the station for every song. I kept switching back to the navigation screen to try and keep us on track, since my navigator had no idea where we were headed. Like in the movies when drug dealers give away drugs until the users are hooked, Sirius is free for the first six months. As any satellite addict will tell you—especially if you live in remote areas—you will need rehab to kick this habit. To add the navigation component is a $795 upcharge, it worked effortlessly, but if you have a smartphone you may prefer to splurge on other options.

We used both the touchscreen and the voice-activated mode, and both worked without a hitch. We agreed that once you settled in with the Escape, you would probably use the voice method most of the time.

The Escape SE and Titanium come with either a 1.6-liter or 2.0-liter EcoBoost engine and your choice of front- or four-wheel drive in either size. The base S comes with only a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine and front-wheel drive. We had the 1.6 with front-wheel drive and were very impressed with the sporty handling. The EcoBoost engine is essentially a turbo that is engineered to be fuel efficient. Since we were mostly on two-lane highways, we did some aggressive passing, and the Escape didn’t hesitate when we needed to overtake Sunday drivers.

The steering was quick and responsive, and it actually felt more like a sedan than an SUV. The engineers also paid attention and added some more sound-canceling features. As a result, the cabin was indeed quiet, except of course for the incessant chatter of three old friends catching up on their lives. I was the only one who drove, but my passengers agreed that the Escape delivered a sporty ride that made the trip zip by, although Teresa would have preferred if I had driven a tad faster.

Since we were on a day trip, cargo space was not an issue, but we did note that it should be enough for a family of four on a vacation. If you are camping,  you might benefit from a roof-rack-mounted storage box. Both the Honda CR-V and the Toyota RAV4 have slightly more cargo space, but not by a significant amount.

The Verdict:

Since the Escape is no longer offered as a hybrid (in fact, there is not one in this segment), and most of the models in this segment are neck and neck with EPA numbers, it comes down to personal preference: which car do you want to fling down the highway? If the choice is which compact sport-utility vehicle, the Escape is a great choice. It is a winner for driving experience, good fuel economy, and adequate cargo space. If you are leaning toward a sedan with plenty of room, I would also give the Escape an extended test drive. You will find that it is actually fun to drive and looks great in your driveway. And remember, the good karma points will transfer to you.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: I don't know why, but I've always had a soft spot for small crossovers, and the Escape is no exception. It's got just the right mix of practicality and style. My only gripe with this Escape was that it felt a little cheaper than its $30K price. Sure, it's got navigation and a panoramic sunroof (both extra-cost options), but what does a girl have to do to get leather seats?

Laura Sky Brown: First, full disclosure: I am not an SUV fan. My household contains a Ford Explorer, and I've never liked how bouncy-jouncy it is, how narrow and enclosed the front compartment feels, or how high up it rides. Nevertheless, I entered this Escape with a somewhat open mind. I liked three things about it before even turning the key: the low, comfortable entry into the front seats; the low, friendly lift-over height in the back luggage compartment; and the auto-opening liftgate operated by pressing the key fob control twice. I didn't enjoy the driving experience, though. It's smaller and lower than the Explorer but still more bouncy-jouncy than I like. Having said that, I know lots of people do enjoy this kind of vehicle; I'm just not one of them. Would I get one of these for a college kid? Absolutely.

title: My Detroit: An Occasional Series
promoTeaserSmall: There are people making this city live again, and we're getting in the car and going to meet them.
promoTeaser: There are people making this city live again, and we're getting in the car and going to meet them.
metaTitle: My Detroit: An Occasional Series - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: My Detroit: An Occasional Series. We keep hearing about people who are making this city live again, and we're getting in the car and going to meet them. Read the introduction to our occasional series at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Detroit is the big city that has always been a part of our lives. On the Jean Knows Cars staff, everybody grew up in Michigan, and each of us has a set of important memories from childhood onward.

These days, we all use the city in just about the same way, though: we drive in for a specific reason, and we leave as soon as we’re done. Nobody ever says, “Let’s go in to Detroit and wander around,” the way they might take a day or weekend trip in to Chicago or Boston.  Detroit is a crumbling, bankrupt, downright scary place, right?
And auto manufacturing is dead there, right?
Despite everything, the Big Three are all still headquartered in southeastern Michigan. I wonder if we can make the mental shift to seeing what a good thing that is.

There’s no disputing that cars used to be made in Detroit and practically nowhere else, and now they are made practically anywhere else. But listen: despite everything, the Big Three auto companies are all still headquartered in southeastern Michigan. They make cars in Canada, Mexico, China, Europe, and other parts of the United States, but they're still Detroit based. And I wonder if we could do the mental shift to seeing what a good thing that is.

These three companies haven’t gone under. They have adapted to what is now a small planet and a global economy. You can still buy a Camaro and drive it up to Comerica Park off Woodward Avenue, and Annie and Molly did that last week, and it was great.

That’s not forgetting that the Camaro is assembled in Oshawa, Ontario; that Comerica Park, fabulous as it is, exists in a Disney-World-esque wedge of bright shininess surrounded by a whole lot of disrepair and abandoned buildings; that Woodward Avenue, that once glorious boulevard of gleaming shops and cafes, is now not much more than a big, wide bus stop for the proletariat.  You can drive down a main street in the central business district of the city on a weekday, and half the lights at intersections are not working at all. Yes, the city does have big problems.

Let’s not forget any of that. We don’t want to look at Detroit as tourists and focus on a few cute stores or ambitious startups, without making it clear that Detroit also has a really hard road to travel. We’re not writing a fantasy movie here. But it’s also totally unfair to Detroit to look at it as a Mad Max kind of place where bankruptcy is the final chapter in its decease.

Actually, the city of Detroit these days reminds me less of Mad Max, and more of the movie Fahrenheit 451. Do you remember how that ends? There were a few people left in a ruined city where education was forbidden and culture had disappeared. But these few people weren't buying it. Despite the dangers of going against the rules, each had stayed and secretly memorized an entire book. You wondered why they didn’t try to escape and go somewhere nicer.

But they didn't. And if you listened closely, under their breath as they walked, each was mumbling the text of a classic work of literature, so that it wouldn’t be forgotten. As the movie ended, you just knew that these people would find a way to make it be spring again in that forlorn place.

There are people in Detroit who are doing something like that, and those are the people we are going to meet and talk to. We're looking forward to telling those stories in the coming weeks and months.

In Search of Detroit: A Day at TedX Detroit, October 2, 2013

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
2014 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 Convertible

Price: $66,630 as tested (price includes destination charge)
Engine: 6.2-liter supercharged V-8, 580 horsepower, 556 lb-ft torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 12 city/18 highway – you’ll have to pay a $2,600 gas guzzler tax
My favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Option I can’t live without: Navigation system ($795)
You might also be considering: Dodge Challenger SRT8, Ford Mustang Shelby GT500 Convertible

My family has held season tickets to the Detroit Tigers since I was in high school, so Comerica Park and  environs is the part of Detroit I’m most familiar with. Despite its newness, the park is aware of Detroit’s history. Pewabic tiles, made in Detroit (and only in Detroit) since 1903, grace the stadium’s exterior. The old English D is, of course, everywhere, including on a special Pewabic souvenir tile.

Our seats behind home plate look out on the Chevrolet Fountain, which serves as a showcase for Chevy’s newest, hottest cars. During the darkest days of General Motors’ restructuring, when Chevrolet stopped funding the billboard, Tigers owner Mike Ilitch turned the billboard into a message of support for General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler instead of seeking other sponsorship (photo at right). It’s Detroit proud through and through, and you can’t help but feel fond of this city when you’re there.

So when I found myself with the keys to a Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 convertible on a sunny fall day—a fall day with a must-win playoff game, no less!—Comerica Park seemed like the perfect place to take it to see and be seen, especially since we could do it all with the top down. Could there be a crowd anywhere in the country that would appreciate the ludicrous wonderfulness of this archetypal 580-horsepower monster of an American muscle car more than the Detroiters walking up and down Woodward Avenue that Tuesday? I couldn’t think of one. Many (or even most) of these people either work for or have family members who work for one of Michigan’s automakers. Michiganders have appreciation for fine automobiles in their blood, and we can’t help turning our heads when we see one go by.

I’d driven the Camaro as soon as it arrived at our office on a glorious October morning, and I was immediately won over. As soon as you turn the key and the Camaro ZL1’s 6.2-liter supercharged V-8 engine roars to life, you’re reminded that this is engine bay is packing some serious heat. But that’s no reason to be intimidated. Thanks to an optional six-speed automatic transmission ($1,185), a navigation system ($795), heated leather front seats (standard), and other amenities, the Camaro ZL1 convertible feels accessible and drivable. Around town, it’s got perfect manners. But as soon as you add pressure to the gas pedal, it’s ready to go. It’s the kind of car that will be impossible to have a bad time in.

The Camaro ZL1 is also the kind of car that invites attention, despite its tame Ashen Gray paint coat. When senior editor Molly Jean and I drove into downtown Detroit, convertible top down, wind in our hair, to observe the revelry at Comerica Park, we drew more than a few looks. As we exited the freeway, a man in a Chrysler 300 pulled up and eyed our car. “Does that car go fast?” he asked. “It looks fast.” I assured him that it was, indeed, fast. Later, while we were waiting to make a left turn a young man leaned his head out the window of his own car and said, “That’ll rip corners, don’t matter if you are a girl!” I decided to take that as a compliment.

It wasn’t just that the ZL1 drew a lot of comments. It also seemed to inspire goodwill in our fellow drivers, who appeared ready to accept some bad behavior on our part because our car was so clearly special. It wasn’t the convertible top or the rumbling V-8 engine: this was a car that Detroiters immediately recognized as one of their own.

When Molly had me stop in my lane for a few minutes in front of Comerica Park so she could take photos, forcing the people behind me to change lanes, we heard not so much as a honk or an angry word from our fellow drivers. Later, I realized at the last minute that I needed to make a left turn and crossed two lanes and cut off a city bus to avoid having to double back. I gave a sheepish wave to the bus driver, who simply rolled down his window, gave me a smile, and yelled, “Pretty slick!”

I was sorry to see the Camaro leave us the next afternoon, and not just because it can go blazingly fast if you want it to. With a hefty as-tested price of $66,630, an engine so loud you might have to raise your voice to be heard over its growl, and a teeny tiny back seat, it’s hardly a practical choice for a daily driver. But the ZL1 is special enough to make you forget about all that, even if it’s only until you give the keys back. Yes, Camaros are practically littering the streets in Detroit. Still, this amplified version still delights drivers and passers-by alike, and once you’ve driven it you can’t help wanting more.
