contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. I have known Denise my entire life as an automotive journalist. On one of my very first press trips, I found out she was in the hotel, so I called her room and asked her to join me for a drink in the lobby bar. I was twenty-seven years old, fresh out of the Chrysler Proving Grounds, and I remember little other than how pleased she was that I'd called and how excited I was to meet her, an older woman who had raced against Fangio and Moss and Hill! Who won the Grand Touring class at Sebring driving a Ferrari 250GT SWB! I mistakenly thought she was at the end of her fabulous career. Hilarious.

For the next three decades, I saw my heroine working every kind of automotive event: walking the pits at F1 and Indy-car races, taking in the new-car reveals at international auto shows, judging the premier concours d'elegance events like Amelia Island and Pebble Beach, and driving the wheels off test cars at events all over the world. We'd pair up whenever we found ourselves together, and I'm not ashamed to say that I preferred her behind the wheel.
Her columns are the most exquisite writings you can find in automotive journalism: elegant, insightful, warm, deeply personal, as inside this business as you can get.

Oh, she could drive, but her columns for Autoweek, which morphed from a racing paper for which she had written from its beginning, remain the most exquisite writings you can find in automotive journalism—elegant, insightful, warm, deeply personal, and as inside this business as you can get. She won the Ken Purdy and Dean Batchelor awards for excellence in automotive journalism. She was the first journalist inducted into the Automotive Hall of Fame. And let's just throw in the fact that she's the only female driver in the Sebring Hall of Fame.

She is indefatigable, and only recently have I noticed her slowing. There she was this past August in the heat of The Quail event, part of the Monterey weekend, walking slowly with a cane across the show field. We sat for a bite and a chat. I was already tired. She, on the other hand, showed me the first book published by her new imprimatur, FulCorte Press: Jimmy & Me, by Lew Bracker.

"He was a Porsche driver on the West Coast who was Jimmy Dean's best friend for sixteen months when he was in his twenties. It's amazing. I can't wait for you to read it. I couldn't put it down. It's so genuine and real." She'd sat next to Bracker at a Porsche dinner and wrung a book right out of him.

"My second book is from Stirling Moss, who is allowing me to republish All But My Life, which he wrote with Ken Purdy. He wrote a new foreword, and I wrote an afterword about Ken and Stirling in the day. My third will be from Sue Mead. Do you have a book?"
I wanted to lie down.

Almost as an aside, she told me she would have brain surgery the following week for a tumor on her pituitary gland, which had dimmed the sight in her left eye. I was astonished that she'd traveled from her home in Santa Fe with a brain tumor, while she was miffed that she hadn't been invited to the Mercedes-Benz dinner that night.
"Are you coming to the Santa Fe Concorso next month?" She'd asked the same thing last spring at the Amelia Island Concours. "You really need to be there."

This time, I listened. The week after her surgery, she was on form: "Right now, it's uncomfortable because I have these nose stents into my brain. But I can see out of my left eye again. I'm having my knee done next, so I can hear again, too." What a joker! I booked my ticket.

So did Alma and Derek Hill, Phil Hill's widow and son, and Sir Stirling and Lady Susie Moss, who love this "boutique" car show. It was a collection of gems, both human and automotive. But I was there for the gem of all gems, the original Koh-i-Noor diamond gal of gals, Denise McCluggage, honoree of the weekend.
I spent my time capturing stories from some of her many friends for a video tribute.

One of those friends was actor and automotive historian Tim Considine, who moderated an evening with her and Sir Stirling.

"Do you remember your last race?" asked Considine.
After a pause, she said, "I haven't stopped yet." Of course not.

You can order Jimmy & Me from Amazon.com, but you also need to go to Denise McCluggage's website and her online store, where you'll find some of her classic photos and other items for sale.

pageElements.text: I took the 2014 Honda Ridgeline pickup truck home for the weekend mainly because I had a lot of errands to run, and also, who doesn't like to drive a pickup? I’ve owned three full-size pickups in my lifetime, one Ford F150 and two Dodge Power Wagons, all three with big gas-sucking V-8s. The last one—a Power Wagon—I customized under the hood with cherry bomb headers and a distributor I personally recurved for more power, which ensured that a) it would suck even more gas, and b) it would never run right again. But it did make a lot of noise.

If you have a pickup, you know you are everyone's best friend a couple of times a year. So I was my own best friend for the weekend, and I got a lot of errands taken care of in a tidy little truck that I have always loved, ever since it was first introduced in 2005 as a 2006 model.

Not everyone loved it as much as I. It was priced too high (a consideration pretty far down the list of an automotive journalist with free test cars and gasoline), it had a clunky front end to many (which was redesigned for the 2009 model year), and it was wimpy to others, who felt that it lacked all the important Big Truck stats, like towing, bed length, and the all-important V-8. Not that this 3.5-liter V-6 is all that economical at 17 city/21 highway mpg. (This Ridgeline, the RTL model with navigation, comes in at $38,335, including destination.)

The locking in-bed trunk is the 2014 Honda Ridgeline's claim to fame.
In-bed trunk in the 2014 Honda Ridgeline. Notice the drain plug and the spare tire.

2014 Honda Ridgeline RTL with navigation. Who doesn't love a little pickup?

pageElements.text: One man’s faults are another woman’s treasures. The Ridgeline wasn’t built for contractors. It is more ute than truck (built on the Acura RDX platform). Its hybrid mix of old-school ladder-frame truck construction and unibody makes it tight, tough, and capable of carrying 1,500 pounds in the short bed. Front-wheel drive makes it pretty easy to wheel around, and the Ridgeline stops a lot quicker than your average full-size pickup.

Honda has never made a V-8 for any of its production cars, don’t you know. And this truck's front-wheel drive automatically switches into all-wheel drive if the situation calls for it. The Ridgeline’s usefulness goes much, much deeper.
Once I spent Sunday morning licking my wounds after the Tigers lost to Boston, I recovered and got up and got about my business, exploiting almost every special features of the Ridgeline.

Job number one: Bring the winter hats home. Yes, I have so many hats that I have to store the off-season collection in a spare closet at work. It’s easy to pack the second row because the 60/40 seats release with the pull of a latch, then flip up with one hand and click in place.
Job number two: Take a couple of bags of clothes and shoes to the Salvation Army.

Job number three: Take toiletries to the women's shelter. I will admit right now that I bring everything home from hotel bathrooms. Everything but the towels and robes. I've been doing it for thirty years. I can't help myself, so now I'm channeling my Polish hoarding instinct. Everything goes into a bag, and when the bag is filled, it goes to the battered women's shelter.
Job number four: Fill the bird feeders at work in between ferrying hats from the closet to the truck.

Job number five: Visit Costco (holy crap, it’s a madhouse!) for storage boxes, specifically for one rather large box to hold my vast collection of the Tiger fan-girl gear, which I am putting away but only until next year.

I call Costco the $300 store, but apparently if you bring a truck it becomes something closer to the $500 store. Ahem. That little foray filled the Ridgeline’s hidden bed trunk and emptied my checking account.

The downside of most pickups is that all your stuff is exposed to the elements. The Ridgeline’s claim to fame is a commodious locking trunk within the cargo bed. Almost everything from Costco fit in the trunk. It’s easy to get to, because the tailgate can be opened like a door as well as in the traditional flop-down mode. The trunk is also perfect for tailgating. You can be the life of the party, fill it with ice and beverages, and empty the aftermath later via a handy drain plug.

Job number six: Grocery shop at the Produce Station on South State Street in Ann Arbor. It’s a hidden gem. I loaded up on heirloom apples and a bunch of other great-looking local fall produce, stowing the bags in the Ridgeline’s front seat.
Job number seven: Pick up the dry cleaning at Elite Cleaners II, on Stone School and Ellsworth, a rare example of an organic dry cleaner.

At this point, I have every single thing in the Ridgeline—the bags of clothes, the bag of toiletries, the dry cleaning, everything from Costco and the Produce Station, and all of the hats in their boxes.
And my purse.

I still had the entire bed free except for a large storage box for the garage—perfect conditions to get a flat tire, as the spare is accessed through the trunk.
The Ridgeline was as useful as I remembered it, not surprising since it’s remained virtually unchanged over its lifetime. The bigger surprise is that it has soldiered on, despite being a tiny blip on Honda’s sales chart. The best year was 2006 (50,193), and Honda never sold more than 20,000 Ridgelines after 2008.
So this is it. The Ridgeline now goes on hiatus for a year, returning completely reimagined from top to bottom. Fingers crossed it’s as clever as this one.

pageElements.text: The first thing my husband did when I bought him his very first computer, the original Apple iMac in the translucent turquoise case, was click on the bookmarks I created for him to make him interested in it. One was the Chesapeake Bay Retriever Club. And he bought a dog. Because he only had one, his boon companion RonDog, and he wanted Ron to have a playmate.

He got an address for the breeder in Illinois, and off we went on a late November day. I expected a four-hour drive, but as it turned out, it was on the Missouri border, so we ended up spending the night. The breeder had her puppies in the barn. There was only one girl, and that's what we wanted, so we swept her up into our arms, handed over the money, and got a hotel room.

The first thing she did when we set her on the bed was pee on it. I grabbed her up in mid-pee and got her outside, and that may be the only time she ever peed inside again. She has always been the sweetest, nicest, loveliest little dog we have ever had.

Our first Chesapeake Bay retriever, Ron, died at age thirteen, a few months after we brought our fourth Chessie, Bob, home. Bob had kept him going quite a few months, but he finally passed on. We didn't really expect how hard Louie would take it. She moped around for about a month, but she immediately took his spot on the little Persian rug by the door and his place of honor under the table at mealtime.

For the past three years, she has been the grande dame of the house. She sits quietly, like a sphinx, and the boy dogs have learned not to mess with her. You don't take her toy; you don't smell her butt; you don't touch her. She's like a Live and Let Live kind of dog, but when she gets ticked off, it sounds like a horrible dog fight, but it's over in a second, and Louie is sitting proudly in her place while the other dog has already slunk off to the other room. She has never started a fight, but she's finished every one that ever got started with her.
For the past three years, she has been the grande dame of the house. She sits quietly, like a sphinx, and the boy dogs have learned not to mess with her.

She was a genetic mess with a lower jaw that never grew and two rear knees that needed to be rebuilt before she was a year old, but it never seemed to slow her down, until this year. She can still hear the sound of the plastic lid being peeled off the dog treat box from two rooms away, and every now and then, when she's tired of lying on her dog bed, she'll hurl herself up into the middle of our king-size bed, where she'll lie proudly all afternoon in the sun.

Louie runs for a treat with her rear legs slid out from under her as she goes around the turn from the sitting room to the dining room, and my heart just leaps in my throat. She's as sharp as she ever was, happy as a lark. She's just having a hard time with those back legs. I absolutely refuse to put down a dog who is so bright and so happy, just because she can't stand for very long. We're investigating acupuncture right now, and by God, if I have to I'll build her a little cart.

Both Tim and I have put down many dogs. It doesn't get any easier, that's for sure. We were talking about it once to our friend who married us, the late Judge George Alexander, and he said, "The reason that dogs don't live longer than they do is so we have an opportunity to know so many good ones." Right now, I just want to know the ones I have. Happy birthday, my little bat-eared dog!

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s a strange thought, especially for those of us who love to drive, but the day of the self-driving car could be close at hand. Auto companies are working hard on technology that would allow vehicles to do most of the work of driving for us, and there are already vehicles on the market, like the new Infiniti Q50, that can manage semi-autonomous driving in certain conditions. But these cars won’t create themselves — there’s a lot of work to be done first to ensure the technology will be safe and reliable.

Right here in our hometown of Ann Arbor, the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute is emerging as a leader in connected vehicle research. We’ve told you before about UM-TRI. For over a year, they’ve been running a 3,000-car study on connected vehicles, with hopes that they will learn more about how connected vehicles could work in the real world. Now, they’ve announced plans for a $6.5 million thirty-acre test facility to test automated vehicle technology.

The facility should be completed by Fall 2014. It will include a five-mile test track designed to replicate real-world driving conditions, like curves in the road and lane merges. UMTRI hopes to test a variety of technologies at the track, including automated cars and vehicles that can sense changing traffic patterns, although no specific projects have been announced.
Right here in our hometown of Ann Arbor, the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute is emerging as a leader in connected vehicle research.

Peter Sweatman, director of the University of Michigan Mobility Transformation Center, said in a statement that the test track, and facilities like it, are crucial because connected vehicles and autonomous driving technologies will need to be extensively tested “before a significant number of vehicles can be safely implemented on actual roadways.”

Talk of implementation on real roadways isn’t just hypothetical for UMTRI – the institute, the auto industry, and the government plan to team up to develop “an entire system” of connected vehicles in southeast Michigan by 2021.

The reality of the self-driving car can be a little worrying for enthusiasts, but researchers hope the technology will drastically reduce traffic fatalities by minimizing human error. And that’s a goal we can all get behind.

pageElements.text: Every parent of a teen understands the simultaneous convenience and terror that comes with the acquisition of a learner’s permit. Another willing driver in the family? Fantastic. The fact that teens have the highest crash rate of any group in the United States? Terrifying. It’s almost a natural parental reaction to hold on to the keys or restrict a teen’s opportunity to drive and only let him or her drive in places that feel safe to you. AAA says there is something more you can do. Parents can improve their teen’s driving—and thus their odds—by coaching them to take on more challenging driving conditions.
We see gaps between parents’ understanding of what they should be doing and what they are actually doing in the car.

“We see gaps between parents’ understanding of what they should be doing and what they are actually doing in the car,” explains Justin McNaull, director of state relations for AAA. Nearly half of parents reported they wanted their teens to get “a lot of practice,” when asked about their plans for their teens’ driving. Yet only about one in four parents mentioned practicing under a variety of situations or conditions, such as in bad weather, in heavy traffic, or on unfamiliar roads. That's one reason why the auto safety association has come up with teaching aids for parents. They're a good deal anytime, but this week only, they are on sale here.

Five Ways You Can Help Your Teenager

This brief moment when your teen driver is under your supervision is an opportunity to convey some of your hard-earned road experience. It’s easy to forget how long it took you to acquire those driving skills you’ve accumulated over many years of experience. But those higher-order driving skills you picked up can be taught, too. Here are five ways you can mentor your teenage driver.

1. Take a minute when your teen first gets a permit to think about all the places in town you don’t like to drive—that scary traffic circle, the freeway on-ramp, a particularly confusing intersection—and come up with an inventory of challenging places and conditions.

2. Using the list, create an informal syllabus that will bring your teenage driver up to speed on the whole menu of traffic and road types. Start your teen off with simple roads and ideal conditions. Then gradually add traffic, poor weather, darkness, freeways, rural two-lane highways, gravel roads, tunnels, and traffic circles. “Your teen is going to end up driving in those places eventually,” says McNaull. Why not make her first experience a controlled one with you there to offer advice and suggestions? “Start working your way through that list,” says McNaull. “You don’t have to do all of it in the first month of driving.”

3. Make sure both you and your teenager go through a major attitude check before you get into the car together. Agree that you will both remain calm, patient, and positive, will listen to each other, and will take regular breaks to talk about how it’s going. Make sure you and your teenager both give feedback to each other about the driving experience as it happens, so that time together is learning time. AAA calls this “commentary driving.”

4. Brush up on your driving knowledge and pass along your own advice to new drivers by entering the AAA “Are You Smarter Than Your Teen Driver?” contest. It’s quite possible that some things have changed since you learned to drive, and this quiz will help you review how basic driving recommendations have changed (such as the hand position on the steering wheel). It’s set up like a contest, with a winner to be named in December.

4. Consider taking AAA’s online parent involvement course. The parent coach is considered such an important part of learning to drive that Connecticut and Massachusetts even require parents to enroll in a parent involvement session so they can learn to be better coaches. AAA’s online version is available to everybody, with some videos and resources free on the site—like this brochure, and a full DVD course and manual for $29.95.

Sale Alert!

Through October 26, AAA is discounting Driver-ZED, an interactive computer program that uses live-action video and 100 scenarios to teach risk management behind the wheel. It's available for only $7 using the coupon code “TeenZED.” Teaching Your Teens to Drive is offered for $12.95. A bargain at twice the price, if you have teenage drivers in your life now or will have in the near future.

Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/29 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Option I can’t live without: Blacktop appearance package ($495)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Malibu, Chrysler 200, Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry
See more specs on the Dodge Avenger lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

The best comments I heard about the Dodge Avenger while driving it came from hard-working solid citizens of commerce. At the McDonald’s drive-through, in the Target parking lot, places like that, I would hear: “Wow, I love your car. Coolest ever!” That was my first hint that the Avenger’s look appealed to somebody, because at first glance, it sure didn’t appeal to me.

It’s not that the black-on-black look doesn’t suit me; that’s pretty much the look I wear myself on a daily basis. It’s not that it’s ugly; it’s actually quite attractive in a retro kind of way. The Avenger was not my favorite look simply because it doesn’t seem quite modern. It wouldn’t have seemed out of place in a 1970s TV detective drama, perhaps driven by one of the bad guys. If he were still working out of Malibu, TV’s Jim Rockford might have driven this instead of the Pontiac Firebird he used to park outside the trailer. That’s not a slur on the Avenger: this is a solidly well-priced car that stands out from the modern pack of mid-size sedans specifically because it does look so old school and timeless.

What can you buy for under $25,000 that doesn’t look entry level? This car. Although it looks like a grownup’s car, it still starts at an entry-level-worthy $20,890 for the base model. That one comes with a 173-horsepower four-cylinder and a four-speed automatic transmission, which you can swap for a six-speed automatic for an extra $200.

But you can get something a little more interesting, like the car you see in these photos, without spending a whole lot more. Chrysler brags that it's "America's most powerful and affordable V-6 mid-size car." Opting up to the midrange SXT we tested, with its six-speed automatic transmission and 3.6-liter Pentastar V-6 with variable valve timing and 283 horsepower, only increases the price to $25,380. That price includes $300 extra for the V-6, plus the Chrysler UConnect telematics package ($995), which adds the very modern Bluetooth voice-command connectivity, GPS navigation, and a 6.5-inch touchscreen.

It also includes the indispensable Blacktop package ($495), which toughens up the look of the Avenger with eighteen-inch gloss black wheels, gloss black grille, black headlamp covers and a body-color spoiler. You can get the Blacktop package with other body colors—Redline Pearl, Bright White, and Granite Crystal or Billet Silver metallic—but the black-on-black look is hard to argue against. The black-on-black Avenger is the car equivalent of a black leather motorcycle jacket, and it should appeal to the same people who appreciate that look.

Once inside, the Avenger is surprisingly comfortable and well constructed, especially for its price. I am a big fan of the supportive, comfortable leather seating in this SXT, and I can’t say enough good things about Dodge’s large, solid, satisfying-to-turn knobs on the instrument panel. Our SXT had heated front seats as part of the $400 leather seat package.

This doesn’t look like a family car on the outside, and it’s not quite a family car inside. Its back seat would be best for two passengers with the center console folded down, as legroom is somewhat limited back there. If you’re not going to carry more than four on a regular basis, it would not be an issue.

Driving the Avenger was not indistinguishable from driving almost any V-6-powered sedan. There was more than enough easily accessible power, and it was capable and competent over a variety of road surfaces, while smooth and comfortable to drive around town. I wouldn’t go as far as to call it exciting; it’s a mid-size sedan after all. But I think it could stand next to any of the cars in its category for ride and for a solid driving experience. I not only enjoyed running errands in it; I felt a little like Stealth Mom, conventional on the inside but black leather on the outside. It was a whole different persona than I'd have inside a Honda Accord or a Toyota Camry, and it could grow on me.

The Verdict:

If you are looking for a mid-size sedan but are just a little bored by the common favorites like the Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, and Nissan Altima, go a little farther afield and check out the Dodge Avenger. You’re less likely to see one around every corner. Despite the comic-book name, the Avenger has decent fuel economy at 19 mpg city and 29 mpg highway, even with that 283-hp V-6 under the hood. It’s even a Top Safety Pick + from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, so it’s a more mature and modern sedan choice than you might think by looking at it.

Who's going to buy this car? It is priced very well for a young working-class striver to afford, but it's not necessarily a car that a younger person might go for. Comfortable, fuel-efficient, solid-looking, old school: I'm seeing a hard-working person on my side of forty, but one who is still interested in staying out late on a Saturday night. She might be asking herself, What would James Garner drive? And this might be the answer.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: I'm not a big fan of the Avenger's exterior styling, and even though the interior is comfortable and well appointed and our test car's V-6 engine puts out almost 300 horsepower, I still can't see myself picking this car over its (more attractive) competition.

Molly Jean: I think Dodge is missing its target audience by marketing the Avenger to customers who want an enthusiastic driving experience. This car is perfect for the older driver who is not technologically savvy. Three fifty-cent-piece size buttons control the climate control, and the UConnect system is very user-friendly. In fact, the entire car is very utilitarian and would appeal to a cost-conscious buyer who desires efficiency over modern design. To really seal the deal in the older-customer niche, Dodge will need to add a retirement beige exterior that can be completed with the already available frost interior.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Here we go again with a plethora of time-wasting gems I found on my way to finding what i was really looking for. Enjoy!
1. Happy Halloween a week early from Mini.
2. TreeHugger gives a quick chemistry lesson to explain Toyota’s new fuel cell vehicle. If my high school teacher had been this clear, I probably would have been to the moon and back.
3. So tell me what you want, what you really, really want. Well, what Spice Girl Mel B wants is an armored car that will actually shock unwanted guests.

4. Unfortunately for Sporty Spice, she was not invited to attend the Porsche Sport Driving School: Women’s Only Course, but Oakley’s athletes were. They learned driving skills both on the track and on an off-road course. Porsche made this video to promote their women-only program to all women who love to drive. It is a two-day spa-like experience that has a hefty entrance fee of $3,200. It takes place in September 2014, so if you start saving now you can be an expert driver by this time next year.

5. My family’s Buick Riviera had a sweet eight-track player, which is why I know all of the words to every song on An Evening with John Denver. (I know the people who once rode in this 1967 AMC Marlin fastback pictured here enjoyed the eight-track as much as we did.) But now I can actually watch him belt out “Rocky Mountain High” while my husband chauffeurs me along the highway. Fast Company takes a look at past, present, and future dashboards.

6. You may also enjoy this trip in Mr. Peabody’s WABAC machine to view some vintage dashboards.

7. Attention Rubik’s Cube masters: Toyota has turned the agony of the Rubik’s cube virtual. Now you can rule once again with your mad twisting skills. Full disclosure: I lasted about two minutes until I hit Solve.
8. The Big Three automakers lit the October skies in Michigan with a pink salute to recognize National Breast Cancer Awareness Month.
9. If I were teetering on the edge of buying a Honda CR-V, this would push me over the cliff.
10. And here is how they made the magic happen.

11. Let's close with a little Halloween ridiculousness, again from Honda. You already know how crazy we are about the Honda Odyssey's in-car vacuum; that's why we're passing along these eight seconds of fun in which it turns to Count Vacula.

title: Volkswagens Meet Their Canine Match
promoTeaserSmall: Which car is most like an Old English sheepdog or an Afghan hound? VW lays it out for you.
promoTeaser: Which car is most like an Old English sheepdog or an Afghan hound? VW lays it out for you.

metaDescription: Volkswagens Meet Their Canine Match: A British ad campaign matches a breed of dog to each VW in the lineup. Fun to watch. Which one is a Siberian Husky and which a Lab? Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: When you think about the experience of driving a Volkswagen, you may not automatically think about how happy your dog will be riding in it—but Jean does; her Jetta TDI Sportwagen was specifically chosen to ferry Bob the Reluctant Show Dog.
Now, I’m not suggesting that Jean and Bob were the inspiration for Volkswagen U.K.’s new dog-centric ad campaign, but stranger things have happened.

Each car is matched for personality and temperament with a breed of dog. A lineup of thirty-six dogs of every breed from small terriers (Polo, Up!) to a greyhound (Scirocco) and a Saint Bernard (Touareg) has been chosen to represent VW’s range of cars.

Volkswagen rolled out the canine-centric campaign with ads on The X Factor in the U.K. The automaker is following up with a print, digital, movie theater, and social media campaign over there, all under the silly (but no sillier than Fahrvergnügen) hashtag #woofwagen.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/65Rrl6Lka18" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

You may not be in the market for a VW out of the U.K. lineup—in fact, you probably aren’t—but it’s a lot of fun to click on the dogs and watch them wag their tails and jump. What a clever way to market to families and dog lovers of all types and to draw a parallel between the many breeds of dog and the many flavors of Volkswagen these days. Are we going to see this campaign in the United States? Mark Gillies of VW in the States says there are no plans yet. Another reason to love the global reach of the World Wide Web.

title: Ford Mustang's Colorful History
promoTeaserSmall: From lurid to lascivious to gorgeous: an appreciation of the pony-car's hues through the years.
promoTeaser: From lurid to lascivious to gorgeous: an appreciation of the pony-car's hues through the years.
metaTitle: Ford Mustang's Colorful History - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: historical paint color choices for cars
metaDescription: Ford Mustang's Colorful History: From the lurid to the lascivious to the gorgeous, here's a brief history of the pony-car's hues. Read about it (and admire the cars) on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: The Ford Mustang is an American icon. Since 1964, kids have pinned up posters of the muscle car on their bedroom walls and saved paper route money in hopes of getting their very own pony. Perhaps as important to those dreamers as the car’s sporty lineage was the color they would choose for their perfect Mustang. When I was growing up, red was the obvious paint choice for young drivers lusting after a ‘Stang. But that has not always been the case. Ford released data this week that exposed the Mustang’s color history, and it’s more varied than you might expect.

The data, provided by Marti Auto Works, shows that the all-time most popular color for a Mustang is, yes, red, with 21 percent of all Mustangs sold wearing that attention-grabbing hue. Perhaps more surprising, at least to those of us who don’t remember the 1970s, is that brown is the seventh most popular Mustang color of all time, thanks to a period of intense popularity in that decade. It’s impossible to buy a new brown Mustang today; they haven’t been built since 1989. Green was also popular in the Mustang’s early years, holding a slot as one of the three most popular Mustang colors for much of the late 1960s and early 1970s.

The most popular shade for a new Mustang today is black, gracing 28 percent of 2013 Mustangs. That’s also the color I would choose for my own hypothetical Mustang, thanks mostly to a black 2014 Mustang GT I drove that elicited multiple comparisons to the Batmobile. White, the most popular color for new cars overall, makes up just ten percent of today’s Mustang sales.

Ford maintains that color and personality are crucially important to Mustang buyers. Mustang marketing director Melanie Banker said that Mustang owners want their car’s color to reflect “what they want their Mustang to say to the world about them.” Sadly, “my favorite color is pink” is no longer a sentiment that a Mustang owner can project to the world—which was not the case in 1967, when Ford offered two shades of pink for the muscle car: Dusk Rose and Playboy Pink.

What color would you choose for your Mustang? Eye-gouging Gotta Have It Green? Yellow, the eighth-all-time most popular Mustang tint? Or would you seek out a 2004 SVT Cobra, available in color-shifting Mystichrome? Let us know in the comments below.

images.caption: His and hers pink Mustangs, anybody?
"Vibrant hues." Okay, if that's what you want to call this two-tone Mustang.
Back in the Jimmy Carter era, you might have had harvest gold appliances inside, and a brown Mustang in the garage.

title: Why I Love My 1999 Lexus RX300
promoTitle: Why I Love My 1999 Lexus RX300
promoTeaserSmall: Has any car since the Model T had such a revolutionary role as harbinger of a new era? I think not.
promoTeaser: Has any car since the Model T had such a revolutionary role as harbinger of a new era? I think not.
metaTitle: Why I Love My Lexus RX300 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Why I Love My 1999 Lexus RX300: Has any car since the Model T had such a revolutionary role as harbinger of a new era? I think not. Read as I make my case in JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: No one stops to admire my car, to remark on its not exactly sleek but most attractive rounded shape and pretty claret color (what they now call Matador Red Mica, although mine was called Venetian Red Pearl in 1999), all packaged in a handsomely matured fifteen years.

Why doesn't anybody fawn over my vehicle? Why are there no covetous glances from fellow drivers or winks of shared satisfaction of the kind given to other owners of the same model? How prescient we were, we ought to be declaring, with smug nods.

When I travel from Manhattan to the Hamptons in my cousin's 1964 Ford Mustang, strangers honk; I've even witnessed them running up to the car as she parks it, peering through her driver's-side window and offering piles of money for the car, which is most definitely not for sale. Yes, those early Mustangs are fabulous and innovative; they represented a new lifestyle, the kicky Sixties and all that.

But the same could be said about the 1999 Lexus RX300, except for the part about the kicky Sixties. It was a mold breaker, a game changer, a maverick (not a Ford Maverick) in the annals of vehicular history.

Look to the road now, and it seems that a quarter of all driving machines are modeled after my Lexus: sedan-sized sport-utility vehicles built for convenience and comfort rather than off-road activities. Why don't people observe the importance of my superannuated car? The innovation, the cutting-edge uniqueness? Why isn't the RX300 considered a sure bet for classic cardom?

All right, you laughers, it's not a sleek and elegant sports car. Some might even consider it a mom-mobile. It isn't sexy and temperamental. Its turning radius is wide. But it was the very first luxury SUV to be built on an automobile chassis rather than that of a truck. It is the precursor!

Prior to the RX300, I drove a Chevrolet Suburban for ten years. I wanted something smaller, but I still wished to be seated high and have access to four-wheel drive. I was tempted to buy a handsome Jeep Grand Cherokee, which fit the bill, but the ride was rather stiff and rough. It was a real off-roader, not the comfort car with off-road abilities I was seeking.

I tested the other luxury SUVs: the new Mercedes ML320 and the Infiniti QX4. They were definitely both appealing. Then I entered the Lexus showroom on Eleventh Avenue in Manhattan, and there, showcased, was cherry metal in a unique vehicular shape I had never seen before, with funny little triangular windows but great visibility. Dare I say it was cute without being girly?

Inside was a glabrous cream leather interior with super-comfortable adjustable seating, memory, and fine walnut trim. And the back seat featured something I'd never witnessed, except in limousines: a VCR. Here, it was mounted on the ceiling facing any would-be back-seat passengers. (After purchase, my kids watched Jurassic Park countless times, as that was the only tape that seemed to dwell in the car.)

I test-drove the RX300, and it was the quietest vehicle I had ever encountered. Its ride was so much smoother than the other luxury brands: the Mercedes, the Infiniti, and the larger Lexus LX, all built on truck platforms. The car that was to be mine was set on a Toyota Camry chassis. It had a V-6 engine, 220 horsepower, a 3.0-liter four-speed automatic transmission, and a 103-inch wheelbase, all-wheel drive, and front and side airbags. It propelled from 0 to 60 mph in 8.8 seconds. Some aficionados appreciated it right away: it became the first Motor Trend Sport-Utility Vehicle of the Year in 1999. And it had no problem with floor mat entrapment like some later Lexuses.

Over the past fifteen years, it has traveled back and forth across the country. It has masterfully handled harsh weather: snow, mountains, mud. Its drive has remained, if not quite as silky as it once was, still a pleasure, even though the steering wheel now squeaks, a reminder of how whispery quiet it formerly was.

Was the '64 Mustang more revolutionary than my RX300? Did it lead an innovation revolution of this caliber? Has any car since the Ford Model T been such a forerunner (not a Toyota 4Runner, which is truck based)? Millions of passenger-car-based all-wheel-drive vehicles have followed in the template tracks of my luxurious Lexus.

Once I owned the RX300, I began to notice more and more twenty-first century smallish SUVs that resembled mine. There were ultra-luxurious Porsche, Audi, Mercedes, and BMW models, and popular vehicles from Ford, Hyundai, Nissan, and Mazda. Someone even came up with a name for them: CUV, for crossover utility vehicle. There are dozens of them now, from the Acura MDX to the Cadillac SRX, from the Kia Sportage to the Buick Encore. But they were not the original. They were all copies, all followers, all metal acolytes of my Lexus.

Even the later Lexus RX models have tended to stay ahead of the pack. Lexus revamped my vehicle in 2004, although its appearance wasn't altered drastically. By then, the RX had 28 percent of the luxury-SUV market. And the 2006 RX400h became the first luxury SUV hybrid. Today, the 2014 Lexus RX350 doesn't look a whole lot different from mine (or from all the other crossovers out there). Lexus has even reissued the pretty claret color, not seen since 1999. I have heard that RX stands for Radiant Crossover.

title: Who's Afraid of the Interstate?
subTitle: Here's why you're wrong
promoTeaserSmall: Are you one of those people who fears the highway and sticks to the back roads?
promoTeaser: Are you one of those people who fears the highway and sticks to the back roads?
metaTitle: Who's Afraid of the Interstate? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Who's Afraid of the Interstate? Interstate highways
metaDescription: Who's Afraid of the Interstate? Debunking the belief that it's safer to drive on surface streets than on the highway. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Do you have an elderly relative who has stopped—or never started—driving on interstate highways? Do you know people who refuse to do highway driving because they think it’s more dangerous than taking the surface streets? Or, have you, perhaps, forbidden (or have been forbidden from) highway driving? We just saw a nanny blog talking about that issue: apparently there are people who ban their children's caregivers from driving on the highway. Let's lay their worries to rest right now.

Why Some People Hate Highways

It's true, driving on the highway can be a blessing or a curse, depending on your point of view. Highways allow us to go long distances quickly and with minimal risk of getting completely and hopelessly lost, but the limited access, high speed limits, and necessary lane changes can make taking the freeway feel like a dangerous proposition. For drivers who are nervous about taking to the interstate, driving on surface streets and back roads might seem safer, since speeds are lower and traffic congestion less prevalent. But is it really safer to stay off the entrance ramp?

And Why They're Wrong

Short answer: no. Federal transportation statistics say that, in 2007, there were just 0.54 fatalities per 100 million miles driven on urban interstates. Urban highways and arterial (main) roads saw 0.92 fatalities per 100 million miles driven, and local surface streets had 1.32 fatalities per 100 million miles driven. Rural roads, despite their low traffic and lower posted speed limits, are also measurably more dangerous than highways.

Rural Roads Are 2.5 Times More Dangerous, Actually

That same year, data from the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration reported that the fatality rate in rural areas was 2.5 times higher than the fatality rate in urban areas, regardless of road type. That may seem counterintuitive, since the high speed limit on a freeway can feel like a recipe for disaster, but there are several factors that make highway driving a relatively safer choice.

What's So Great About the Interstate?

Everyone is headed in the same direction at roughly the same speed. There are no pedestrians or bicyclists and no confusing intersections. In other words, highways have fewer unpredictable variables that can lead to accidents.

The back roads that nervous drivers may favor over interstates are more likely to have intersections with low visibility, unmarked railroad crossings, and traffic from pedestrians and bicyclists. It’s possible that those factors contribute to the higher fatality rate on those road types.

If you’ve been sticking to surface streets because highways seemed like the riskier route, now could be the time to brave the interstate. The fact of the matter is that driving always assumes a certain amount of risk, but the numbers don’t lie. It may be time to conquer that freeway anxiety once and for all.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $22,195 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $24,190 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 26 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Engine: 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 197 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Safety features: Front and front-side airbags, traction control, electronic stability control
Tech features: Recaro sport seats, aluminum pedals, Sony premium audio, navigation, ambient lighting in seven colors
Chief competitors: Chevrolet Sonic RS, Mini Cooper S

Key Points

• The ST stands for Sport Technologies, Ford's "global performance brand" that was first seen in the U.S. with the Focus ST.
• The Fiesta ST made its debut in Europe in 2005 but is new here this year.
• Compared with the standard Fiesta, the ST is 0.6 inch lower to the ground, has a different grille and hood, and wears dual chrome-tipped exhaust pipes and a unique ST high-mounted rear spoiler.
• Internal cosmetic changes include a leather-wrapped ST steering wheel, a leather shift knob, and leather-trimmed seats. There's also a power moonroof and seven-color ambient lighting.
• The suspension modifications include a stiffer rear axle for stability in corners, electronic torque vectoring control, and three-mode electronic stability control that provides Standard, Sport, and "off" settings.
• The car seen in this video had the ST Recaro option package ($1,995), which includes heated seats and mirrors in addition to the snug-fitting Recaro sport seats.
• If you're looking at this car, don't overlook the optional Molten Orange paint color (as if you could). It's a $595 option.
• Compare the price of the ST, at $24,190 as tested here, with the price of the base Fiesta S hatchback with manual transmission. It starts at $15,395, including destination.
• This little hatchback doesn't just feel powerful to drive; it sounds powerful, thanks to Ford's sound symposer, which pipes amplified engine sound directly into the cabin; Ford calls it an "enhanced soundtrack for drivers out tackling the open road."
• When Ford says this hatch has an "aggressive ride," it's not just hyperbole. Ride quality and sporty feel are on a different planet from the standard Fiesta.

Mr. Song and Me

As you may already know, I have quite a collection of Mr. Song hats.

The very first thing anyone always says about Mr. Song is that he made the purple hat that Aretha Franklin wore to sing at President Obama's first inauguration in January 2009. And that's how I found out about him. I loved it; it was such a standout hat.  I found out he was from Detroit, so I went and looked for him. By the time I found him, he had moved out of Detroit and into Southfield.

We became friends the first time I walked into his store. It was late on a Saturday night, and he was there. I didn't know it was him at first; he just helped me, and I asked him if he was Mr. Song, and he said, "Yeah," and we were off to the races. I had an instant bond with him.

We try to get together for lunch as frequently as we can. He loves cars, so I thought it would be cool to bring him a car.

Mr. Song has a lot of outlets around the world. It is not unusual in a good year for him to sell 13,000 hats for the Kentucky Derby and the parties around it, and that is his day because everybody wears a hat there.

Luke Song started out in biochemistry but decided it wasn't his forté, so he changed to studying fine arts at Parsons The New School for Design. Then he wanted more structured, classical training, so he went to Paris. He came back to Michigan to make enough money to go back to Paris, and his first hat factory was in London, but he's headquartered in Michigan now.
In his little back room, as you see in the video, it's floor to ceiling hats.

The blocking and molding are done in another building, but the fine work is done on the premises, in his back room: the hand work, the beading, the feathers. Among the staff working in the back room are Mr. Song's parents. Mr. Song's shop sends out thousands of hats every week.

You can buy Mr. Song creations of your own, or find out more about his work, here.
Next visit, we're going to trade services. I'm going to teach him to drive with a manual transmission, and he's going to teach me how to make a fascinator. The cameras will be rolling!

pageElements.text: If you’re an Audi fan, you probably already know about the brand’s recurring #WantAnR8 Twitter campaign, a contest that gives enthusiasts the chance to win seat time in the Audi R8, a V-10-powered supercar, with a price that can top out close to $200,000. The campaign first started in 2011 when a Washington, D.C., woman Tweeted at Audi using the hashtag #WantAnR8. The company brought one to her house so she could drive it for a day, then expanded the contest to give other R8 fans the same opportunity.

Audi brought the contest back in 2012, asking entrants to compose a Tweet proclaiming their love and desire for an R8. Last year, eight winners were given the choice between a day with an R8 in their hometown and a weekend on the racetrack at the Audi sportscar experience driving school in Sonoma, California.
Audi’s bringing back its successful campaign for 2013, offering entrants the same choice of prizes as 2012’s contest. You’ll have to do more than just write a Tweet this time, though.

The 2013 #WantAnR8 contest asks enthusiasts to edit a video from clips and music provided by Audi, which shows the R8 embarking on a lap around California’s Sonoma Raceway. The contest launched on October 23, and contestants can upload their video entries to YouTube or Twitter until November 10 for a chance to win time in an R8.

If you want to enter, head to Audi’s Tumblr page, where you can edit view the clips and music that Audi has provided to create your own interpretation of the R8’s trip around the racetrack. Audi has provided songs called Two Door Cinema Club, La Vida Boheme, Miami Horror, and others to serve as the backdrop to your video. Once you’ve edited your masterpiece, post the video to YouTube or Twitter with the hashtag #WantAnR8 to put your hat in the ring.

For some inspiration, visit Audi’s YouTube channel, where you’ll find dozens of short videos cut together using the footage that’s available to contest entrants. Then it’s up to you to create the perfect montage. Good luck!

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: Buying a used car can be a great choice for some buyers. You can get more car for less money, and certified pre-owned programs mean that you can trust your used car to be reliable and in good condition. If you’re not buying from a trusted dealer, though, you’ve got to keep your wits about you to avoid ending up with a lemon. A year ago this week, Hurricane Sandy pummeled the East Coast, flooding 250,000 cars. Some estimates say that as much as 50 percent of those cars will be resold, despite water damage. New Jersey-based nonprofit Kars 4 Kids takes flood-damaged cars as charitable donations, which makes it conversant with the problem. Here are five tips based on the group's advice to help you make a good used-car decision that doesn't involved unwittingly purchasing a flood-damaged vehicle.

1. Know Your Dealer

It may be tempting to snag a great deal off Craigslist or buy a car from your boyfriend’s second cousin’s roommate, but when you’re looking for a used car it’s important to work with a reputable dealer. Car dealers rely on building trust in their communities, so they’re not likely to sell a car if they know it’s been damaged in a flood. Buying from a dealer is also the only way to get a certified pre-owned car, which often includes an extended warranty and other perks.

2. Be Wary of Too-Good-to-Be-True Bargains

If you find a used car that’s priced significantly cheaper than other models just like it, proceed with caution. It may be a great deal because it’s been damaged in a flood or other accident. Make sure you know the going rate for the kind of car you’re looking for, and be cautious of vehicles that are priced far below the norm.

3. Carfax Is Your Friend

When you’re shopping for a used car, a vehicle history report that uses your car’s VIN to alert you to any past accidents or incidents could save you a lot of trouble. Carfax has an online guide to spotting flood-damaged cars, but a report on a vehicle's history is important whether you suspect water damage or not. Essentially a background check for your car, these reports can tell you if a car has sustained structural damage, had an airbag deploy, or if it was ever used as a taxi or commercial vehicle. This should help you sniff out a car that has hidden problems associated with past accidents. You can find a list of vehicle history report providers at vehiclehistory.gov.

4. Don’t Buy without an Inspection

You wouldn’t buy a new house without getting the foundations inspected, and the same goes for a used-car purchase. Before you close the deal on a used vehicle, take it to a mechanic you trust to look for signs of any damage that wasn’t reported to you by the seller. It may cost a little more up front, but it could save you money in the long run.

5. Do a Walkaround

Don’t just take the seller’s word for it that the car is in good shape. Do your own mini-inspection. Make sure to go for a test drive, and pay attention to any unexpected bumps or rattles. Look for water damage in the hood and trunk and rust inside the doorjambs. Sniff for moldy smells. Look for signs that carpeting has been replaced or excessive air freshening or perfuming is present, all indicators of possible previous water damage. Kars 4 Kids suggests that you feel some of the wires under the dashboard. Brittle wires are one sign that a car has sustained flood damage. Progressive Insurance suggests you get a look at the title to see if it's stamped Salvage or Flood: a dead giveaway that it has been damaged.

As long as you keep your wits about you, there’s no reason to be nervous about buying used. Just do your homework so you can make an informed decision, and before you know it you’ll be driving off into the sunset in your brand-new (used) car.

pageElements.text: Women drivers in the United States may be the butt of jokes from obnoxious young men or get occasional subpar service at dealerships, but we’ve got a lot to be thankful for. Women in the United States now make up more than 50 percent of the driving population and make 80 percent of car-buying decisions. But, perhaps most important, we can drive wherever we want, whenever we want. The same cannot be said for women in Saudi Arabia, the last country in the world to ban women from driving. But Saudi women are working to change that.

On Saturday, October 26, dozens of women in Saudi Arabia got behind the wheel in a much-publicized protest against their government’s ban on women obtaining driver’s licenses. Yes, the ban is on getting licensed; there is no law that specifically prohibiting women from driving. Some of the women posted pictures and videos on social media sites of their acts of defiance, calling worldwide attention to Saudi Arabia’s arcane law. Here's an example in which a woman can't disguise her excitement at getting behind the wheel. And here's another one, in which a woman drives her son to a doctor appointment. Revolutionary!

Saudi police were on guard against women participating in the protest and reportedly stopped several women who were caught driving. Fawaz Al-Meeman, a spokesperson for the Riyadh police department, reported to CNN that the police held women who were caught driving until a male guardian could come pick them up, and had the women sign a pledge that they would not drive again before releasing them.

Driving is hardly the only privilege that Saudi women can’t take advantage of. Without permission from a male relative, the BBC reports, Saudi women aren’t able to travel abroad, open a bank account, or work without the permission of a male relative. Although some of the videos posted on YouTube showed male drivers giving thumbs up and waving at female drivers in support, the Saudi government has shown no sign that it will change things. Some conservative Islamic clerics staged a counter-protest outside a royal court (since Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy) last week in support of the current law.

Supporters of the protest are encouraging Saudi women to make the protest last longer than just one day. A new hashtag has emerged for supporters of the event: #Nov31Driving. There aren’t 31 days in November, so protest organizers are using the date to signify an open-ended commitment to their cause, and to encourage Saudi women to keep driving, despite the risk.

pageElements.text: I made a whirlwind tour of Southern California last weekend. It began with collecting a 2014 Soul Red Metallic Mazda CX-5 at Wally Park. Does Wally Park know how stupid that name is? A wally is a stupid person, and I felt stupid climbing on the Wally bus. No offense to the Wallys out there, of course. I don’t believe there are any in my extended family. Hold those calls and letters; I’ll make it up to you in the Christmas letter.

As soon as I climbed into the CX-5, I felt a lot better. I fact, as soon as I saw my lovely compact sport-ute, I felt a lot better. The CX-5 was exactly what I needed to travel the hundreds, and I mean hundreds, of congested miles I was about to drive. The first thing I did was connect my phone, which happened in a second and which completely downloaded my phone list and all my music. But during the whole weekend, I couldn’t figure out how to make the music stop while phone calls were coming in, without reading the owner’s manual, which didn’t happen to be in the glove box. I tried turning the volume way down, but that also turned down the volume of the caller. It finally occurred to me to unhook the iPhone cord from the CX-5 and use the phone on Bluetooth.

I started with meetings in Irvine, so I had to go south from LAX, on to San Clemente, back up to downtown L.A. the following morning, back down to San Clemente, south to San Diego, back to downtown L.A., back to San Clemente, and finally back to LAX.

The first thing I did was head south to Irvine to meet with our great Jean Knows Cars team who built and maintain our website. It’s always fun to be with those people. We went to some Brazilian steakhouse, where an endless procession of guys with swords full of meat come to your table. It was the most meat I’d eaten in about a year. It was a blast, and we spent the whole time talking about our big plans for the rest of the year.

I stayed with friends in San Clemente and didn’t need to get back up to L.A. until lunch on Friday. When I got up in the morning and told my friends what time I needed to be there for lunch, they looked stricken and said, “You need to leave right now.” It was 8:30 a.m., leaving me a paltry three hours to drive sixty miles. “It’s going to be even worse trying to get back here in the afternoon,” they said. Driving here is reason enough to just hate L.A. You never know if it will take forty minutes to go thirty miles, or two hours. I ran for the CX-5, plugged in the downtown address, and…

… discovered the most incredible nav system I have ever experienced. This was not what I was expecting, because the previous CX-5 had one of the worst nav systems ever. The new system is powered by TomTom with IQ Routes™ technology, and it’s part of the Grand Touring Tech package ($1,625) that also includes HID headlamps, adaptive front lighting, keyless entry, and smart city brake support. But let’s just focus on this nav system, because it is life altering.

It’s not one of the biggest screens at 5.8 inches, but it’s a responsive touchscreen, and the display is very crisp. It has a lot of information, and the information is very easy to read, with type and icons as big as they can possibly be. Every time you need to change direction, the arrow takes up most of the screen, so you can tell right away if you need to be left or right, or for upcoming turns, so you can position yourself in the lane early at a glance. There’s a lot of other information on the screen that is easy to access once you get used to it.

Most important of all, this system, IQ Routes, displays a spinning number of how many roads it’s analyzing. At one point, I saw that over 200,000 roads were being scanned for my route to downtown L.A. At first I thought it was a cool party trick, but during the course of driving in stop-and-go traffic, three different times, the system announced the delay in real time. Every time it registered a delay in my route on its software, it made an announcement: “Your traffic delay is now nine minutes. You are still on the fastest route,” or, “Your traffic delay is now twenty-six minutes. There is a new route that will save you twenty-two minutes. Do you want to take it?” and then you hit the button for Yes or No. It also asks you whether you want to use the carpool lane and toll roads. Once you answer these questions, it immediately reroutes you. The last rerouting it made took me off the stopped freeway and put me on surface streets past scrapyards and down some streets that were pretty sketchy, other than the fact that there was absolutely zero traffic on any of them. I arrived at my lunch appointment thirty minutes early. At one point I was going to be nine minutes late, so the reroute saved a total of thirty-nine minutes.

I immediately put all of my faith in the CX-5’s nav. Just knowing that you are "still on the fastest route" sort of takes the worry out of driving in L.A. It’s too bad there isn’t a system like that for buying a car, so you know throughout the negotiations that you are “still getting the best deal.”

My advice is, if you live in L.A., you need to buy this nav system no matter what car is wrapped around it. My review of the car is almost immaterial. Yeah, the CX-5 is really cute. It works really well. It has a lot of space. But OMG, that nav system. IQ indeed.

The next day, I had to go up to El Segundo for some corporate meetings, which left me stuck in the usual snarl of traffic heading south out of L.A. on Friday night. (I saved eight minutes on a reroute through Long Beach.) But I was finally aimed toward the weekend as I joined the traffic basically stopped on the 405. I was looking forward to staying with friends in San Clemente. I not only borrowed this CX-5 from Mazda, I was staying with a Mazda PR executive and his wife the whole weekend. When I pulled up, there were two CX-5s in his driveway: one was his wife’s, and one belonged to another journalist who was visiting.

Every year my friends have a magnificent Halloween costume party attended by people deadly serious about winning the prize for best costume, so the bar is always high. I had in my luggage the most exquisite couture hat from Mr. Song, a feathered cap that made me feel like Liza Minnelli. I had perfect makeup: red, red, red lipstick, false eyelashes; everything from the neck up and no costume to go with it. Of course I had to go to the costume store on Saturday morning, the weekend of all the Halloween parties in L.A. I miraculously found a flapper dress and size eleven patent leather tap shoes (I was lucky I didn’t have a fight in the aisle with a drag queen looking for her shoes for the evening).
Mission accomplished; costume complete.

On the way home, we made a quick trip to Costco to get a folding table and some butter. Have you ever gone to Costco with two things on your list? We ran in to the store, and my friends headed for the table while I went for the butter, yelling “No dicking around!” They beat me to the checkout, and we went through the line with just that table and three pounds of butter. Have you ever made it out of Costco with just two items? Not me.

Sunday, I went down to San Diego to visit my dad’s first cousin Marcella Hopkins on the somber occasion of her husband Jack’s death. He was ninety-two years old, and they lived an incredible life. In the house that he himself designed and built with an architect friend in the Frank Lloyd Wright tradition, Jack had a giant map of the world in the hallway with hundreds of of push pins marking the places he and Marcella had visited, from pole to pole and on every continent. They traveled in the Himalayas when they were in their seventies and had to pass a rigorous physical exam before their Sherpa would agree to guide them. They were the first Americans to visit Iran after the revolution; they snuck in.

I had just met Jack and Marcella, their daughter Sylvia, and Marcella’s sister Geraldine the year before. It was a bittersweet reunion on Sunday, with the other two Hopkins daughters, their spouses, husbands, and kids pouring in all day. I got to meet a side of the family that I’d only seen in letters and photographs. That's Geraldine at left, me in the center, and Marcella at right.

Sitting in the driveway was Jack’s 1969 Ford Galaxie 500 station wagon, which had taken the entire family, Mom, Dad, and four kids, to Alaska. The Alaska travel sticker was still in the rear window when Sylvia’s husband, Lee, decided he would slowly restore the car for his father-in-law. Sylvia said, “Whatever you do, do not remove that sticker.”

Lee found a guy on eBay who had old travel stickers, so he removed the worn-out sticker and put the exact replica in its place. When she saw it, Sylvia said, “How did you restore the sticker?” I don’t think he ever told her.

On Monday, I had to go back to L.A., where I was on the jury of the transportation section of the Spark Design Awards. I got to meet some really cool designers, who were not all car designers. Among them was a young woman who was working on a prosthetic leg for children that can be adjusted by the user to accommodate growth, and a man whose design company designed a gel pack that can be dropped in to Third World countries and can completely sanitize raw sewage into drinking water. One helicopter load of these chemical packs is the equivalent of fifteen helicopter loads of bottled water. He told us about it, and it was about tenth on the list of the innovations and designs and projects he and his firm had worked on. I felt kind of small sitting at that table.

So what I did this weekend was have corporate meetings; go to a Halloween party; visit my family; judge a design competition; and then fly home. I picked up Number One Chesapeake Bay retriever Louie from the kennel on my way home from the airport. She seemed a little older, a touch slower, a bit more deaf, but just as happy to see me as ever.
Her acupuncture treatments start this afternoon.
Love, Jean
