contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Detroit has earned the distinction of being the most dangerous city in the United States for the past five years in a row, according to Forbes magazine. In fact, it has been referred to as Murder City. However, there are hundreds of thousands of law-abiding citizens who call the Motor City home, and a growing number of them are rising up to the challenge of reinvigorating their hometown. Since Detroit is my closest urban city, I share their mission. So, when I heard about a nighttime bike ride through Detroit, my husband, Tom, and I loaded up a 2014 Ford Explorer, ignored the statistics, and put our faith in mankind instead.

How the Slow Roll Got Started

In 2010, these two guys, Mike MacKool and Jason Hall, were spending most days riding their bikes and playing Call of Duty. One night, after a heavy battle, they realized that their lives revolved around two things: bikes and murder. A few glasses of wine later, the two decided to put their passions together and created a bike club, fittingly named Bikes & Murder. They are quick to point out that it is a different kind of murder, as in “I murdered that sandwich” or “I murdered that job interview.” I am a fan of urban slang, so I was picking up what they were layin’ down.
MacKool (seriously: that is his real name) explained the progression from a bike club to community organizers.

“Bikes & Murder is our roots in cycling," he told me. It's "a bike club we started with a group of guys that we rode and gamed with. It was a small club that ignited our passion for cycling in Detroit and laid the groundwork for everything that came after. The natural progression from bike club to bike advocates brought us to create Detroit Bike City, a bike show/expo/swap meet at Cobo Center. Because we wanted to grow as an organization, we have done everything as Detroit Bike City, our #1, and kept Bikes & Murder as simply a club and apparel company. It is important to us to note that we are more focused on Detroit Bike City than B&M.”

This Is How They Roll

Detroit Bike City hosts a ten-to-twelve-mile bike ride every Monday night in downtown Detroit from March until October, and it's dubbed the Slow Roll. The event rolls deep: more than 1,700 riders have participated in some of their recent rides. It is indeed a slow roll, and since Detroit is quite flat, any bike will do, and pretty much anyone can keep up with the group.

The information on their website is pretty slim, so basically all we knew was to meet at Saint Andrew's Hall at 6:30 p.m. This time, rollers were encouraged to dress up for Halloween, since it was Oct 28. Saint Andrew's Hall is now exclusively a music venue, but it was once home to the Saint Andrew’s Society of Detroit with the mission to provide assistance to fellow Scots and to encourage the love of Scotland through its history, customs, music, literature, and national games. Who knew that the Scottish population is so large in Detroit that they have been organized since 1849? Underneath Saint Andrew's Hall is The Shelter, which also hosts live music. It is credited with being one of Eminem’s first venues. And looks it.

Tom was more worried about lights on our bikes than whether he should dress up as a superhero or a gangster. I ran around town buying enough gadgets and gizmos galore to make us visible to our Canadian neighbors on the other side of the river in Windsor. And I taped a jaunty little hat on top of my helmet so that I was at least partially in character.

Rolling in the Explorer

The Explorer came sans hitch, so we needed to put our vintage mountain bikes in the back. We were straight up impressed with the power seats in the far back that folded into the floor. You can actually fold just one side or both! We needed all the space, so we went for both down.

The middle seats fold forward, and their headrests tuck, so we didn’t need to remove them—sweet. It took a few attempts, but amazingly the bikes fit,  and we only needed to remove the front tire of one bike.

We managed to be rolling toward Detroit on time, which if you knew the two of us is a miracle. I programmed the address into the navigation, connected my phone via Bluetooth, and used the voice commands to select our radio station. This whip was perfect for the mission. Obviously, if I actually owned this ride I would have a bike hitch installed so I could bring a bigger posse. But, truth be told, I was a little nervous to bring my teenage daughter to an event where we would be slow rolling through a town that has packs of stray dogs, murders on many nights, and a reputation for poor response time from first responders.

Yes, I was a little nervous, but mostly excited to be outside my comfort zone. I knew I wasn’t climbing Mount Everest or base jumping off a tall building, but it was still something of a leap of faith.

We paid a man $10 to park the Explorer, even though the sign clearly said $5—that is the way things go in the D. No questions asked. Somehow it feels like he owes you so he will keep an eye on your ride. But mostly, I believe he needed that extra $5 more than we did. We pulled our bikes out and bedazzled them with lights. Our neighbor's Ford Focus had carried three guys and three bikes without a hitch, literally.
It is indeed a slow roll, and since Detroit is quite flat, any bike will do, and pretty much anyone can keep up with the group.

800 Bikes, 600 Costumes

The group assembling in front of Saint Andrew's was a great mix of humanity. It was not a million man march but still a more than healthy crowd for a Monday night when the temperature was hovering in the high thirties. When I asked MacKool afterward, he said 800 riders were in attendance. Many of the bikes were decorated, and I would say that 75 percent of the riders were in costume. The group was a combination of Detroiters and suburbanites, but symbolically, for this night, we were all Detroiters.

The organizers shouted out the rules over a megaphone.
1. Stay right: Cars need to get around the pack.
2. Communicate: Shout out signals, stops, obstructions, etc.
3. Stick together: The tighter the group, the better it can move through the city.
4. Stay alert: Obviously.
5. No littering: They asked us to help police one another.
6. Encourage positivity.
7. Respect: The neighbors, the cars, each other.
8. Be prepared: Spares, helmets, lights.
9. Have fun: duh.
10. Make friends: Meet your fellow riders.
11. Corking: There is a team of marshals positioned at intersections to inform drivers that the group is about to ride through.
12. Wear a helmet: Duh again.
13. Music: Riders who have music need to make sure people can still communicate.
14. Roll slow: This is not a race.

The Roll

I have never ridden a bike in a large group, and certainly never at night. At first it was difficult to ride slowly with bikes all around, but I got into the rhythm pretty quickly. I did feel like I needed to be uber-alert to any pothole in the road, so I wasn’t able to look around as much as I would have liked.

The route took us past four cemeteries, but it was difficult to tell because it was so dark out. Even though it was only eight at night, and we were in central Detroit, there was no one outside—in fact we saw fewer than a dozen residents on our two-hour ride. The roads they chose were actually in good shape, but as we rolled by the neighborhoods it was very post-apocalyptic, with porches falling off houses, boarded-up windows, and lots of empty lots. We did see some homes that were cared for, but it was so dark that the whole ride was surreal.

Elmwood and Mount Elliott Cemeteries

Elmwood Cemetery was the first fully integrated cemetery in the Midwest, and it is the final resting place to many of Detroit’s dignitaries of the 1800s as well as the controversial Detroit mayor (from 1974 to 1994) Coleman Young. As we pedaled by, the darkness loomed ominously, and I wondered if there were any illicit activities taking place in there. I felt oddly safe in the pack, even though I could hear dogs barking in the night.

Next we passed the Mount Elliott Cemetery, also home to Detroit’s movers and shakers of the past whose names are now those of major Detroit streets, including Beaubien, Campau, and Moross. But just as important, it is the home of the Fireman’s Fund monument. It resides within a special section reserved for those who have served their communities as firefighters. But the darkness held all of these monuments as its hostage. We vowed to come during the day, and see exactly what we had missed.

Directly across the street is the Capuchin Monastery and its soup kitchen, which appeared like an oasis in the deserted city.

The Heidelberg Project and My Introduction to Corking

We pedaled within a half block of the Heidelberg Project, folk artist Tyree Guyton’s now famous project that uses everyday, discarded objects to create a two-block area full of color, symbolism, and intrigue. We only knew that we were near because we saw Guyton’s signature polka dots on the street surface. As we rode through the darkness, marshals and the crowd itself patrolled the group, shouting “keep right,” “keep moving,“ “tighten the gap,” etc.

But my very favorite part was the corking. As the group would approach an intersection, volunteers would protect the group from perpendicular traffic. They did so in a gracious manner intended not to infuriate the delayed motorists. Honestly, the working together for the good of the group was so off the chain that it made my eyes well up. Adding to the ambiance, several corkers were dressed as Santa Claus for some reason.

The Slow Rollers I Liked Best

I never stopped smiling as the various decorated bikes and riders would pass us or we would pass them: a recumbent bike that looked like a racing car, Marie Antoinette, a butterfly, various angels, witches, ghouls, Gumby, and Beaker from The Muppet Show. My very favorite rider was a man who I don’t believe was in costume. He sat very upright on a Panama Jack beach cruiser from Huffy that was retrofitted with big high handlebars that had speakers integrated into them. A local Detroit rap station was escorting him along, and every inch of the bike was lit up with LED lights. To me it felt like he was dressed up as Snoop Dogg, and I loved him.

Adding to the festive feeling was the aroma of marijuana that would envelop the group from time to time. I was vigilantly watching for potholes and couldn’t imagine being high as we moved along—but then again, I am an uptight almost-fifty-year-old white girl from the small town of Roscommon.

Trinity Cemetery and Beth Olem Cemetery

As we neared Hamtramck on Detroit's north side, we stopped to let the group condense again. We could see the Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly plant off in the distance. This 362-acre site was once home to 4,200 residents, 1,400 homes, several churches, and 140 businesses. General Motors purchased some of the property and fought to obtain the balance of it through eminent domain. It was a highly controversial effort, but eventually the Michigan Supreme Court ruled in GM’s favor. Currently there are 1,600 workers at the plant, which builds the Chevrolet Volt, Malibu, and Impala, and it has produced more than three million vehicles. Still located on the grounds of the plant is Beth Olem Cemetery, a small Jewish cemetery that managed to remain in place. Interestingly, visitation is limited to the Sundays before Rosh Hashanah and Passover. It would be interesting to know if anyone comes.

Rolling toward the Renaissance Center

We pedaled on through the night, chatting with our neighbors and just listening to the crowd in general. One woman talked about how the Slow Roll had become her addiction, and how on her first slow roll she was so out of shape she thought she may need to quit part way through. She was sad that this was the final ride of the year. Even though it was near freezing as we moved along, I hardly thought about the cold. My mind wandered to the people who were hunkered down in their homes, and I hope it made them happy to see us rolling past. We were ready to be done when we spied the Renaissance Center guiding us to the starting point and our spanking new Explorer.

The party continued into the night inside Saint Andrew’s Hall. We chose to skip those festivities; instead, we ate at Nikki’s Greek Restaurant, a mere half a block away. The streets were desolate except for our fellow Slow Rollers and a few unlucky homeless people huddled around sewer vents for warmth. The main section of Greektown was one block away, but we felt better moving quickly between well-lit, populated areas.

Done Exploring

After dinner, we were done with the Slow Roll and wanted to Fast Roll back to Ann Arbor. After all, it was a Monday night, and Tom’s 4:30 a.m. wakeup call comes early. The Explorer delivered a smooth ride over the potholed highways that lead out of Detroit. The 3.5-liter V6 Ti-VCT (twin independent variable camshaft timing) engine was flawless as we followed the complicated highway changes that the nav was barking out. I mentioned to Tom that I barely remember how difficult it used to be to maneuver around Detroit while looking at a map. Now I would never venture to Motown without some type of a nav system.

The Explorer weighs in at 4,534 pounds, which is about the size of a small elephant, but it actually feels stable as it rolls on its twenty-inch wheels. The V-6 didn’t exhibit much lag as we barnstormed for Ann Arbor. It would be interesting to feel what a 5,000-pound trailer would do to the driving experience, that being its maximum tow capacity.

Obviously, we did not test the four-wheel-drive capability, but considering how many of this SUV's owners will haul various trailers and head to vacation destinations, I think it is a wise addition to any Explorer purchase. The cabin itself is upscale, and the blue lights that glow from the instrument panel and the cup holders make for a first-class cabin atmosphere.

Detroit Bike City has other events throughout the year to keep the spirit alive, but the Slow Roll hibernates until spring. The bike expo in Cobo center will take place the last weekend in March. That should give you plenty of time to choose your bike for the 2014 Slow Roll season. While you're waiting, here's a map of our route.

2014 Ford Explorer LTD 4WD

Price: $45,560 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 290 horsepower, 255 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Fold-flat second- and third-row seats
Option I can’t live without: Power folding third-row seat
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Traverse, Honda Pilot, Jeep Grand Cherokee, Nissan Pathfinder

pageElements.text: Here's this week's blend of crazy art, brilliant marketing, questionable ideas, and fun things to click on. As always, I ran across these while looking for something else...hope you like these post-Halloween tidbits as much as I did.
1. Detroit photographer Joe Vaughn teamed up with Ford to film an incredible pumpkin project. I really need to work on my carving skills for next year.
2. Can you believe what Chrysler did? We can.
3. David Ortiz, a.k.a. Big Papi, was the undisputed MVP of the World Series this year. He got a Silverado High Country from sponsor Chevrolet. Do you know what else is in his stable?
4. Who knew the Honda Element was so yummy.
5. It is not too late to save the clock tower.
6. Flo Rida is comfortable in pink.
7. Kia Canada wants you to stop putting on your makeup in the car, and I agree. My makeup just looks like I put it on in the car.
8. In the Eighties, Jeep Cherokee drivers were the definition of cool. After a long hiatus, Chrysler thinks the Cherokee can help you be cool again.
9. Explicit Language Alert: This guy is having a really bad day.
10. If you did not decorate your car this Halloween, you should hit up some post-holiday sales for next year.
11. You may despise graffiti, but Banksy makes it provocative and artistic. If you don’t know who he is, you should.

title: Two Reasons to Love Diesels
promoTeaserSmall: If you don't think luxury and diesel are compatible, may I present the 2014 Audi A7 TDI and Q5 TDI.

metaDescription: Two Reasons to Love Diesels - If you don't think luxury and diesel are compatible, let me present the 2014 Audi A7 TDI and Q5 TDI. Read the rundown on these two vehicles on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s not exactly a secret that we’re pro-diesel here at Jean Knows Cars. Jean owns (and loves) a Volkswagen Jetta Sportwagen TDI. I drove a Mercedes-Benz GLK250 BlueTec twice and loved it both times.

Why should you love diesels, too? Diesel vehicles can earn significantly higher fuel economy than their gasoline counterparts, and new technology means these cars are no longer loud or smelly. But even though today’s diesels are virtually indistinguishable from gasoline-powered cars and even though diesel engines are available in everything from sport sedans to full-size pickups, they’re still not the first thing that comes to mind when you think “luxury.”
Or are they? Enter Audi's TDI lineup.

Oysters, Champagne, Diesel Fuel

Starting with the 2014 model year, Audi is now offering diesel versions of its A6, A7, A8, Q5, and Q7 models. Previously, only the Q7 and A8 were available as diesel models. We had the pleasure of welcoming a 2014 Audi A7 TDI and Q5 TDI to our offices in the past few weeks, and we found that, in the case of these two, luxury and diesel go together like oysters and champagne. Audi’s TDIs command a premium over gasoline-powered versions of the same car, but they also earn significantly better mpg ratings. Our A7 TDI with its 3.0-liter, 240-hp V-6 engine is rated at 38 mpg on the highway. An A7 with the 3.0-liter, 310-hp supercharged gasoline-powered engine is rated at just 28 mpg highway. The Q5 TDI ekes 31 highway mpg out of the same 3.0-liter diesel engine; that's 5 mpg more than a Q5 with a 3.0-liter gasoline engine.

With an as-tested price of $81,395, it’s safe to say that few of the people who buy an A7 TDI are interested in the money they will save on fuel. The more modest (but similarly equipped) Q5 TDI we tested still commanded a $55,445 asking price, and even a Q5 TDI with no options costs upward of $10,000 more than the base-model Q5. Both vehicles came standard with sumptuous black leather interiors and the Audi MMI infotainment system, and both sported the optional S line exterior styling. The turbo-diesel engine pumps out a smallish 240 horsepower, but with an impressive 428 pound-feet of torque you won’t lose many stoplight races.

Spending time behind the wheel of either of these cars is enough to turn you into a diesel convert. The all-black leather interior is as sleek and stylish as the cars’ modern exteriors and should impress even the most jaded passengers. Audi’s MMI infotainment system is simple and intuitive to use. Both cars are plenty powerful and capable, and when you’re driving them they feel exactly right: comfortable, responsive, attractive, engaging. They also have the advantage of conferring a certain status upon the driver. They say: “This person can spend twice the average annual salary on their automobile.” It’s the kind of thing we all hope our cars might say about us one day, although most of us will never be able to afford it.

That’s perhaps the biggest problem with Audi’s TDIs: it takes serious mental gymnastics to convince yourself that they’re worth the multi-thousand-dollar premium. The EPA estimates that the A7 TDI will save drivers $1,500 in fuel over five years, compared with the average new vehicle, while owners of a Q5 TDI will save $750. If buyers are contemplating one of Audi’s TDIs instead of something significantly more affordable, they’ll probably get tired of the car before they realize much fuel savings, making their TDI purchase essentially a very expensive way to achieve longer range between fill-ups.

But that all changes if you are planning to buy an Audi anyway. The gasoline-powered A7 is significantly less fuel-efficient than the average new vehicle, causing drivers to spend $2,250 more in fuel over a five-year period than the TDI version, which is right at the average mark. The same goes for the Q5. The gasoline-powered 3.0-liter V-6 version will cost you $2,250 more than the average in fuel over five years; the TDI will save you $750 off the average cost over five years.

At the end of the day, it’s unlikely that drivers of the A7 TDI or Q5 TDI will choose their car because it makes financial sense. Drivers will choose these cars because they make a statement, because of their excellence, and because their impressive gas mileage will allow roughly 500 miles between trips to the pump. After spending some time with both cars, I can’t say I’d argue with them.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. pageElements.text:
Seventy-four times. That’s about how many times I drove the 600-mile round trip between Ann Arbor, Michigan, and Bloomington, Indiana, between 2010 and 2013. Each time, I was piloting my silver 2004 Mercury Monterey, and each time, my teenage daughter was with me in the front passenger’s seat. But today, time seventy-five, I would be driving the 2014 Chrysler Town & Country you see here, evaluating how much the original minivan has matured now that it's turning thirty.

Rose, an aspiring violinist, joined a pre-college music program at Indiana University early in her high school career. It required her to be present all day every Saturday during the school year, plus a month every summer. No trains run between Ann Arbor and Bloomington, and there were no flights that got her close enough—especially considering the expense of flying. So drive it was. Maybe this sounds familiar to you travel soccer parents out there, only in our case, the adventure had a Brahms soundtrack.

You might ask, how in the world could anyone stand to drive 300 miles on Friday night, followed by 300 more miles on Saturday night to get home, seventy-four times over three years? There were only two ingredients I needed: belief in my daughter and her goals, and a minivan.

Say what you will about minivans; you can really get comfortable in one. No, it’s not a fun-to-drive sports car. It’s more like the house your sports car gets parked next to. The basic idea is that it’s your own personal surrogate home on wheels. And I drove the wheels off that Monterey. With Rose’s violin securely packed between the first and second seats, our overnight bags in the back, and frequently a gown in a dry-cleaning bag hanging from the side hook in the second row, we had a routine going.

We liked to stop in Jackson, Michigan, for snacks. The first exit at Fort Wayne, Indiana, was halfway. When we got to the giant bunny outside the Nestle factory in Anderson, we knew we were ninety minutes from Bloomington. More than once, I cursed the state of Indiana for its reluctance to salt the highways in winter. More than once, I found myself unable to make it the whole way, because of bad road conditions or just simple fatigue, and stopped at a motel, which then meant getting up at 6 a.m. and back on the highway to get Rose to the school on time.

We would take turns going in to the gas station for snacks or the bathroom at McDonald's, since we couldn’t leave the violin unattended in the car and she didn’t want to cart it in with her. We'd spend the night with the helpful parents of local kids from the music program, then I'd spend my Saturday hanging out in a cafe, waiting for it to be time to pick up Rose at the end of the day.

But then, the rides home! Luxuriating in Rose’s euphoria when her lessons and rehearsals had gone well; convincing her to recline her seat and nap under a fleece blanket on the times she was disappointed or frustrated in her day. And always, we would listen together to a peculiar blend that only the parents of young classical musicians must know: half Top Forty pop music, half sonatas and concertos.

How many moms get to spend as many hours with their teenage daughters as I did, one on one, with no interruptions? Even though I was mostly watching the road and she was mostly reading, sleeping, or in her own world, Rose and I will always have those seventy-four drives—even if I did use up that Monterey. I’ve replaced it with a sedan, now that half my kids are away from home, but reluctantly.

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: Rose is in the middle of her freshman year now, studying violin performance at IU, and on one hand, I am thrilled that I don’t have to make that long drive anymore. On the other hand, I am not used to two months going by without seeing my child, and it was high time I went for a visit. What better way to go than in a newer, fresher variant of the silver van that took us all that way for all those years?

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: I climbed in to this attractive silver 2014 Chrysler Town & Country, then, as no minivan virgin. I greeted the ticking of the analog clock on the vertical dash, the high and wide seating, the bus driver grip on the wheel, and all that delicious, nutritious visibility like I was seeing an old friend. I was home again.

Immediately, I started up the shiny refrigerator on wheels and headed off on the familiar route. Aside from the much improved, much cleaner interior, the other thing that changed was that I was alone in the Town & Country.

I only wish I had more people to transport or stuff to carry, but it’s frequently the lot of the minivan driver to fall short of filling up all that glorious capacity. So off I went, happy to reconnect with the easy-to-use Uconnect Chrysler telematics, the tall seating position, and the feeling of being at home in my own living room while cruising down the freeway.
The best part was just going down the road in a minivan with my daughter again. What can make you feel more like a mom than that?

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: The safety features on this minivan, appropriately, are first-rate. The blind spot and cross-path detection systems are part of the SafetyTec option package ($1,695), which in practice means little triangles that light up on the side-view mirrors when a vehicle is approaching on either side. I have already established that I am easily addicted to the latest driver alert features like rearview cameras. That’s standard on this car. So, not only are blind spots a thing of the past; you also don’t need to worry you’re going to back over a shovel or a kid.

The comfort features are equally first-rate. The Town & Country has always seemed a little less hip, a little less plush, than the Toyota Sienna or the Honda Odyssey, but hipness and plushness are not what I’m looking for in a van, anyway. And Chrysler has long been ahead of the pack in kid-friendly interiors. Case in point: the Stow 'n Go seats that make the already spacious center row into a yawning cavern of spaciousness. You’ll get no argument from me about the general awesomeness of Stow 'n Go seats. However, when you flip that handle on the side of the seats, you’d better jump back—you, and any grocery bags, purses, or heaven forbid small children who might be standing in the way of that seat leaping to attention and flinging itself closed. It’s shockingly fast and efficient. Also, shockingly easy to use, so that makes it all okay.

The Town & Country S I drove is number two in a lineup of four trim levels. The Touring is the base model, and there’s a Touring-L and an ultraluxe Limited model of the Town & Country above the S. But, even on the S, you’ll find seventeen-inch black-painted wheels, an entertainment system featuring Blu-Ray for the second and third rows, with one fold-down screen per row, and cloth and leather seats. Bonus: S lettering on the front seats. Gracious living by minivan!

This year, there's also a 30th Anniversary special edition. Thirty years seems like a long time, but I clearly remember when the first ones came out, in 1983. I was at a Chrysler dealership, a young, broke single woman looking for a cheap car, and the salesman tried to get me interested in the just-released Dodge Caravan. "This will hold seven people!" he enthused. "Well, I don't have seven people," was my very reasonable response. I got that it was groundbreaking, but I didn't realize how soon I actually would have a family of six and be glad minivans had been invented. In fact, before I had the Mercury, I owned a 1996 Town & Country, and I drove it for almost a decade.

The Town & Country was pretty refined by the mid-1990s, but the very first minivans of the Eighties were a little, well, underpowered. I think it was Tom and Ray Magliocci of Car Talk who used to joke that you needed to take seven people so six of them could get out and help push it up hills. The Chrysler minivans have come a long, long way since then, selling more than 13 million and adding power, amenities, and luxury as market appetites have evolved.

Cruising along I-69 heading south through Fort Wayne and Indianapolis, I appreciated the perfectly adequate power of the V-6 with its 283 horsepower. I am pretty sure I used it all as I passed dozens of trucks on the unremarkable flat roads of the northern Indiana landscape. But Chrysler is thinking about fuel economy, too, fitting the Town & Country with a fuel economizer function; just push the Econ control, and the engine adjusts to operate at lower speeds while the transmission shift pattern is changed, garnering 25 mpg on the highway.

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: Eventually, I arrived on IU's leafy campus. Nearly all the buildings are made of the justly famous local limestone (fun fact: the area around Bloomington is called the Stone Belt, home of one of the world's largest limestone deposits). It's also a Big Ten school, with all of the football and basketball craziness that entails, but, more important to my family, it's the home of the Jacobs School of Music. The other kids on campus may be partying it up, but Rose is totally geeked to go to a school with a 55,000-square-foot music library and five orchestras.

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: I had business to handle: a trip to Target to replenish dorm supplies, and a recital to attend. I was reminded that, dang, teenage girls use a lot of personal-care products. Those add up at the cash register. I also realized that it was unbelievably great to hear Rose perform after two months away from the sounds of her daily practice. But the best part was just going down the road in a minivan with my daughter again. What can make you feel more like a mom than that?

You just don’t know what you have—whether the sound of violin music or just the sound of your child’s voice—until it’s gone. And that goes for minivan ownership, too. I already miss owning one. It gave me my own private comfort zone that could take whatever, or whoever, wherever we needed to go.
Minivan ownership is a lot like parenting in general: most of the time, it’s not about your fun or your needs. But that doesn’t mean it won’t give you some of the happiest times of your life anyway.

pageElements.text: I had big plans this weekend. I was joining Chevrolet in Las Vegas at the annual Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) show, the biggest, wildest show to overflow the massive Las Vegas Convention Center (and every hotel in town), every year, even the lean ones. It’s the dream of every speed merchant, every pinstriper, every hot rodder, every custom-wheel seller, every tire manufacturer, every Hot Rod cover girl, every racing team and racing team sponsor, to gather the first week of November in an explosion of hot metal and hot times.

But despite the flu shot I so diligently lined up weeks ago, I was slammed to the mat by Saturday morning. I pulled on flannels and the neck gaiter my friend Debra knitted for me, grabbed my pillow and fleece, decamped to the couch, whistled for Ray the Stray, and passed out for two days in front of a roaring fire. It wasn’t enough to get me ready for the week ahead.

I hate being sick on the road, and I’ve been so sick in Vegas (medically, I’m talking about) that they had to bring a vaporizer to my room. I was very happy to be in my own bed, but I couldn’t help feeling sorry for myself—my SEMA dance card was triple booked, and this was what I was missing:

I had a little bird. Her name was Enza.
I opened the window, and influenza.
popular 1918 children's rhyme

• Staying at The Palazzo, part of the Venetian Resort, a true oasis from the seedy Las Vegas scene. The Guggenheim Museum residing within the Venetian opened with a motorcycle exhibit that lured me from Los Angeles, and I’ve been fond of it ever since.

• Driving tricked-out Chevrolet Sonics and Camaros for four hours at Las Vegas Motor Speedway. Chevy has been a wildly enthusiastic player at SEMA for years. In headier times, they would completely change their massive display every single night, so you had to travel to the Chevy corner every day in order not to miss a trick. And that’s what it’s all about, tricking out your ride—from Sonic to Corvette to Silverado and everything in between—with go-fast parts and look-cool visuals. Driving hyped-up Chevys (the Camaro parts were developed from Chevy’s ZL1 and 1LE programs) at the Speedway would have been a riot, wouldn’t it? Right.

• Admiring the new Source Interlink Media corporate booth. SIM, the parent company of JeanKnowsCars.com and Automobile Magazine, also happens to be the parent company of Hot Rod magazine, among some seventy-plus other titles, the biggest of which is Motor Trend. But at SEMA? Hot Rod rules the roost. Editor in chief David Freiburger is a rock star at SEMA, as is former publisher and Mr. SEMA, Doug Evans. The SIM booth is smack in the center of the action in the Central Hall, an oasis of leather loungers and thick carpeting. I shook rapper and car guy Nelly’s hand there once. He looked totally normal, other than the $250,000 diamond stud in his ear.

• Drinking champagne with the Queen of Motorsports, Miss Hurst Golden Shifter, Linda Vaughn, to celebrate the reveal of the Linda Vaughn LV-1 Camaro, designed in her honor by old compadre at Hurst Jack “Doc” Watson, former president of Hurst Performance Research. “You had better be there,” was her last e-mail to me on Friday.

• Partying with Pete Brock. For the third year in a row, I am missing Shelby Cobra designer Pete and Gayle Brock’s house party. They’re the only people I know who live in Vegas, other than Celine Dion, and she moved back to Canada. And I didn’t really know her. You can only imagine that guest list!

• WeatherTech’s ritzy party at PURE nightclub, high above Caesar’s Palace. At least the metal VIP invitation and encrypted pass were ritzy. WeatherTech not only makes the best heavy-duty floor mats in the business (I buy them for all my vehicles), it’s part of MacNeil, great Midwest guys from next door in Hinsdale, Illinois. College junior Cooper MacNeil (he of the excellent last name) also happens to race the WeatherTech Porsche in the ALMS series, winning the GTC championship in 2012 and 2013, with Jeroen Bleekemolen. You can only imagine that guest list!

• The never-to-be-missed Continental Tire party, also at PURE nightclub. Continental is the founding and sole sponsor of the Grand Am racing series, and the company's massive tire operation at the Rolex 24 Hours of Daytona is the most impressive thing I’ve ever seen at a racetrack. They party as hard as they work.
Continental also launched a new Nurburgring-tested, high-performance tire for track and street, the ContiForce Contact, which is for sale exclusively at Tire Rack.

That’s just off the top of my head. Ford’s booth is massive and fabulous. Honda announced a new performance parts division for its production cars, along with the next-generation Civic (right). Mazda Racing, Dodge, Jeep, Kia, Toyota, racing heroes signing autographs—everywhere you turn, you find a friend. And all the little guys with their DayGlo doohickeys and crazy thingamabobs that make our Cool Tech stories cooler. I could go on, but I didn’t make it, and I need to go lie down again.
Let me wrap this up by saying there was only one thing I didn’t miss (along with driving a rental car to the Brocks' party).
Really, really sore feet.

pageElements.text: Not to be partial, but Jean Knows Cars is a sister publication to the venerable Motor Trend, which has been around since 1949 and handing out Car of the Year awards every year since then. When they’re happy, we’re happy for them.

And we are also very proud when good things happen in Michigan. When we learned that the 2014 Cadillac CTS sport sedan was named Motor Trend Car of the Year, it seemed important to point out that the CTS is built in Lansing, Michigan, as a product of General Motors, the recovering giant that is soldiering on from its downtown Detroit headquarters.
I wonder what car won the very first Car of the Year award in 1949? Hmm, let me look that up… It was a Cadillac.
It’s interesting to note that Motor Trend chose the second-generation CTS as its Car of the Year six years ago, too.

But that’s not to take anything away from the 2014 CTS’s accomplishment in winning a coveted award after being evaluated against a strong field of finalists from around the world. The CTS is an amazing product from a General Motors that has been working at getting better for many years. Lately, they’ve brought out one hit after another.

The CTS is a rear-wheel-drive sport sedan in the best tradition of that genre. Jean calls it “an amazing car from Cadillac, especially in the most aggressive CTS Vsport version [shown here]. It’s every bit the luxury rocket ship that its German rivals are.”
What’s more, it does that while being a thorough all-American that looks like an American car. It doesn’t try to look like a German car, as Jean points out, “other than on the track and the road.”
In announcing the award, Motor Trend editor in chief Ed Loh praised the 2014 model for its “responsive powertrains and masterful balance of smooth ride and sporty handling.”

The 2014 Cadillac CTS starts at $46,025, including destination, and comes with Cadillac’s first use of an eight-speed automatic transmission. The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder turbo that makes 272 horsepower. A non-turbo 321-horsepower V-6 is an option. Then there's the twin-turbo 420-horsepower V-6 in the CTS Vsport, a version of the CTS that starts just north of $60,000.
Is it hyperbolic to say that Cadillac is back?

pageElements.text: One of the very best things about cars is that they can take you to far-off places where you can meet new people and experience new things. But once you get to that far-off place, sniffing out the coolest places in town—you know, the places the locals actually go to—is easier said than done. That job just got a little easier for iPhone users, with the launch of the CO Everywhere app.

CO Everywhere is available for free from Apple's App Store (iPhones only, for now). It allows users to choose a spot on a map, say their neighborhood or a city they’re traveling to, and see a stream of aggregated social media posts from users in that area. CO Everywhere’s developers are aiming to fill a gap they see in hyperlocal news. There’s plenty of information out there for a person seeking a restaurant in Chicago, but what if you’re looking for the best restaurant in just one neighborhood of Chicago? Or just one street? CO Everywhere can help with that.

It works like this: once you’ve downloaded the app, you can pick any spot in the world, draw a circle on a map, and see a real-time stream of social media updates from that area. CO Everywhere picks up location-tagged posts from Instagram, Twitter, Yelp, Facebook, and other sites to give users a picture of what’s going on in the selected area. You can choose multiple locations, too. So you could have one map keeping you updated on what’s going on at home, another in the town you grew up in, and a third gaining intelligence on your destination for the weekend. The results can range from mildly interesting to genuinely helpful.

I drew a map around Ann Arbor this week and was confronted with a predictable string of Halloween-related Instagram photos from Ann Arbor’s student population. A map of my college campus in Boston that same day flooded my feed with posts about the Boston Red Sox's World Series victory. More helpful than the tweets of strangers, though, are the restaurant reviews sourced from Yelp and local deals from Yipit, a site with daily deals to local establishments. My Boston map showed a coupon for 50 percent off food at a popular restaurant and deals to a local cycling gym. Ann Arbor’s Yelp reviews suggested brunch at Café Felix, a restaurant that’s been languishing on my to-try list.

I’m generally against downloading every iPhone app that crosses my path, since most of them end up going unused for weeks or months at a time. But with its innovative approach to local information sharing, CO Everywhere may just earn itself a place on my home screen.

pageElements.text: Every fall, the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) descends on the Las Vegas Convention Center for what is, by all accounts, a completely over-the-top car show. Carmakers, tuners, and aftermarket equipment manufacturers all show up with their most outlandish creations, stuff we mere mortals could never dream up. We’ll be bringing you news of SEMA’s hottest concepts and products all week, starting today with Volkswagen and the three hot-rodded concepts it brought to Vegas.

Jetta and Golf Upgrades

This year, Volkswagen brought two tarted-up Jettas and a racy Golf to showcase the Jetta’s upgraded engines and the Golf’s seventh-generation redesign. The next Golf goes on sale next year as a 2015 model. The 2014 Jetta is available with an all-new 1.8-liter, 170-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder engine. This new engine gets 36 mpg on the highway. That's 5 mpg better than the Jetta’s outgoing standard engine, a 2.5-liter normally aspirated five-cylinder powerplant.

Helios Special Edition Jetta GLI Tribute

To showcase this new engine, Volkswagen and FMS Automotive teamed up to create a tribute to the 1989 Helios Special Edition Jetta GLI, thus the name. The 2014 reincarnation features the same blue exterior paint as the classic it’s based on and wears custom side moldings, a rear spoiler, and custom side mirrors. The interior features Recaro seats sporting the Helios color scheme of blue, black, and gray; brushed aluminum accents; and a navigation system and rearview camera. But they didn’t stop with surface upgrades. The Helios Special Edition Jetta GLI also got a sport-tuned exhaust as well as a set of brake calipers from the Golf R, a performance version of the Golf hatchback.

Racer's Dream in Black and White

VW’s second SEMA show car is also a Jetta. This one, also created in concert with FMS Automotive, uses the Jetta GLI’s recently tweaked 2.0-liter turbo engine, which, in its production version, makes 210 horsepower. In this concept, dubbed “Racer’s Dream in Black and White,” the same engine has been tuned to make an astounding 426 horsepower.

To accommodate this extra power, the car also has stronger brakes, a special cold air intake system, a coil-over suspension, and anti-roll bars, among other modifications. To make the car’s looks match its track-ready insides, it has been outfitted with Recaro seats and interior trim and a full body kit. As the name suggests, the car has been painted white with a black roof.

A Modified 2015 Golf

Not content with these two pretty extreme concepts, Volkswagen and H&R, a suspension tuning firm, worked together to modify the 2015 Volkswagen Golf. The Golf gets a coil-over suspension and front and rear sway bars for a sportier ride. It also has a body kit, rear spoiler, and dual exhaust kit from VW Accessories.
The public may never get the chance to drive these one-off creations, but I'm happy just to know they exist. A little excess is good for the soul.
Keep checking in with us all week as we bring you updates on the crazy concepts and products from SEMA!

title: Keys to the Kingdom
promoTeaserSmall: Anna and Suzi have found a simple, brilliant way to support Saudi women's right to drive. Join them!
promoTeaser: Anna and Suzi have found a simple, brilliant way to support Saudi women's right to drive. Join them!
metaTitle: Keys to the Kingdom - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven
metaDescription: Keys to the Kingdom : Suzi and Anna of our G-7 are campaigning to support Saudi women's right to drive. How you can help.

pageElements.text: Have you been following the movement of Saudi Arabian women to gain the right to drive? It is almost unbelievable that women there are not allowed to have driver's licenses and are therefore unable to do something we women in the United States take for granted: get in the car and go where we want or need to go on our own. It’s the only country in the world where women aren't permitted to drive.

Well, in the past month, there is a small but significant movement of Saudi women getting in the car and driving.  Hashtags including #LetThemDrive and #Nov31Driving have sprung up on Twitter from both inside and outside the country, supporting their brave efforts to join the twenty-first century.

At Jean Knows Cars, we know a little about women and driving. Two members of our Group of Seven consumer panel, Suzi Hileman and Anna Eby, are right up there with the most car-crazy women you’ve ever met. They, like us, have little patience with limits placed on women’s ability to do what we want to do. The two of them have been following this story, and they've come up with a brilliant idea to let you make a statement about it.

Join Project Keychain!

It’s called Project Keychain, and like most great protest movements, it’s simple. Yes, women supporting women: it’s an idea as old as civilization. (Probably older.)

Here’s the simple plan. Go root around in your junk drawer and find a keychain or two. Put them in the mail to this address that Suzi and Anna have set up. Add a note of support. They're going to collect a whole lot of them as a show of solidarity, photograph them, and post the images. And we have no doubt they're going to make a hell of an impact, with your help.

4500 Williams Drive, Ste 212
PMB 258
Georgetown, TX 78633

You can also go to their Facebook page, Let Them Drive, and add your voices to theirs. And follow their efforts on Motorista, Anna's blog, and The Burrow, Suzi's blog. As Anna writes: "You can also post about this…everywhere! On Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, you name it. Please use the hashtags #Nov31Driving, #LetThemDrive, and #ProjectKeychain, so that we can create a unified effort, support each other, and, most importantly, support the women of Saudi Arabia."

Here in the United States, we may think we don’t need to think about organized feminism anymore. It has been decades since anybody looked askance at a woman doctor, a woman executive, or a woman in sports. We women may be far from equal on the pay charts, and there may not yet be a female president, but the glass ceiling is looking thinner and more vulnerable by the year.

It's all too easy to stay wrapped up in our First World Problems, such as: which $30,000 car do I like best?, and forget that in a country that has been a longtime U.S. ally, one with plenty of resources and wealth to call its own, women can’t even get driver’s licenses. Let’s stand behind the brave women who are flouting this ban.

pageElements.text: Tuesday was the first press day of the Specialty Equipment Market Association’s 2013 trade show, and there were plenty of hot cars to be seen. From beautifully restored vintage cars to insanely modified new vehicles, there was something for just about everyone. One of the stars of today’s show, earning accolades for the Hottest Car and Hottest Truck of SEMA 2013, was the Ford Motor Company. Those honors came for the Ford Mustang and the company’s F-Series trucks. Not content to rest on its laurels, Ford had a few more tricks up its sleeve today in the form of a couple of hot concepts and a classic truck restored for a good cause.

Hot Wheels Transit Connect

At a press conference on the show floor Tuesday afternoon, Ford unveiled a special collaboration with Hot Wheels (yes, that Hot Wheels): a race-inspired Transit Connect cargo van, designed as a support vehicle for drivers spending a day at the track. The van features an eye-catching blue and orange paint scheme, a sporty grille reminiscent of Ford’s Focus and Fiesta ST models, and custom wheels. On the inside, there’s everything you might need for a day at the track: a tool box, a fifty-five-inch TV, and two Hot Wheels tracks, in case real-life action gets a little dull. Hot Wheels also created a 1:64 die-cast model of this one-of-a-kind Transit Connect, which will hit toy stores in the fall of 2014.

Snakebit 1956 F-100

Ford didn’t save all the glory for brand-new models this year. The automaker also displayed a custom 1956 Ford F-100 pickup, dubbed Snakebit. The F-100 has been lowered, and features a grille that’s inspired by a Shelby Mustang, a stretched wheelbase, custom headlights and taillights, and a billet silver paint coat. The Barrett-Jackson Auction Company will auction off the truck in 2014 to help fund a children’s hospital in the Canadian province of Saskatchewan. The truck was unveiled Tuesday by rocker Gene Simmons and his wife, Shannon Tweed. Tweed hails from Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, and has taken a special interest in the project.

Chip Ganassi Daytona Prototype, Now with EcoBoost

Ford also announced that it has developed a new 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 engine that will be used by the Chip Ganassi racing team in their Daytona Prototype cars, and it showed a real-life version of the Fiesta ST that gamers can drive in the upcoming Forza Motorsport 5 Xbox game.

pageElements.text: The Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) show is a little like a Paris runway fashion show: you’re never going to the grocery store dressed like that, and neither is your car, but it’s a lot of fun to admire the artistry. And one of the most outrageously wonderful concoctions at this year’s SEMA show is this DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma Ultimate Snow Team Truck.

I think what I like best about it is that it started with such a workmanlike vehicle as the Tacoma pickup and then turned it into a snowboarder’s fantasy. I have bought my sons more than enough DC brand skateboarding shoes and apparel to get why DC Shoes was the perfect choice to customize a pickup to represent the snowboarder’s lifestyle.

Could any student slouched in the back of a classroom have drawn a better fantasy vehicle for winter adventures? It all starts with a pop-up tent on the roof, accessed by ladder. There’s a snowplow on the front to get you farther into the wilderness, and a telescoping ramp so you can put your snowmobile into the truck bed and take it along. A secure Jobox container for snowboards and gear completes the weather-readiness profile of the Tacoma. Making this work on the mid-size pickup was the off-road suspension specialist Camburg, which put one of its racing suspensions on the snowboarding Tacoma.

But the fun goes on. All-weather Scosche boomBOTTLE speakers work in the snow, a forty-inch LED light bar illuminates the outdoors for nighttime snowboarding, and an iPad Mini is mounted high on the dashboard for navigation or video watching. The seats are black-and-white with the DC logo on the seatbacks. The DC Snowboarding team promises to take it out on the road post-show.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: We’ve been bringing you updates about the Specialty Equipment Market Association show all week, and now, on the last day of SEMA 2013, we’re bringing you a rundown of three of our favorite cars from Vegas.

Chevrolet Performance 1978 Chevy 4x4 Pickup Concept

It’s all well and good to celebrate the newest, hottest thing in automotive technology. But there’s something to be said for celebrating the classics. That’s exactly what Chevrolet did with its concept version of a 1978 4x4 pickup. Chevrolet gave this old Silverado a 5.3-liter V-8 engine that pumps out 326 horsepower, nearly twice the truck’s original output. The truck also has a shiny new black and red paint coat, an updated dashboard, and a red leatherette interior with red and black hound's-tooth inserts.

Linda Vaughn LV-1 Camaros

Linda Vaughn is an old friend of Jean’s and is known to drag racers as the First Lady of Racing, so it’s no surprise that two custom LV-1 Chevrolet Camaros inspired by the legend herself were unveiled at SEMA. During her heyday, Vaughn was Miss Hurst Shifter—Hurst as in the manufacturer of aftermarket shifters for automotive enthusiasts—and these cars feature Hurst/Oldsmobile coloring. The two LV-1 Camaros that were unveiled at SEMA will be auctioned off in Scottsdale this January at the Barrett-Jackson Auction. Proceeds will benefit Dreamakers, a nonprofit organization that uses automotive marketing and product development to raise money for charity. Funds from these cars will be directed to IKAN, the International Kids Alliance Network, which focuses on education and fighting illiteracy.

2014 Kia Soul, Music Editions

Kia brought not one, not two, but five music-inspired editions of its funky, redesigned-for-2014 Soul. My favorite is the one inspired by NBC’s The Voice, a show I’ve recently become a fan of. The car is fitted with four chairs custom designed to match the coaches’ chairs on the show, airbrushed logos on the exterior, and the words “I Want You” (a phrase used often in the TV show) emblazoned on the lower grille. Inside, there’s a forty-inch LCD TV paired to a wireless microphone and an iPad Mini with The Voice app. The setup is specifically designed to allow driver and passengers to showcase their karaoke skills. Sounds like a party to me.

2014 Lexus IS350 F Sport by VIP Auto Salon

Remember when we told you about Lexus’s contest that allowed deviantART users to submit their dream IS350 F Sport design, with the winner to be unveiled in the flesh at SEMA? Well, this week, Lexus announced the winner of the contest and brought along the real-life model of the car, built by VIP Auto Salon. The car features a wide-body kit with sculptural wheel wells, twenty-inch wheels, Brembo brakes, and a 143-mph electronically limited top speed. A run-of-the-mill white paint job can’t disguise the fact that this Lexus is one of a kind.

These are just four out of dozens of standouts from this year’s SEMA show. There was much, much more stuffed inside the 27,000-square-foot convention center. And while this year’s extravaganza may be drawing to a close, we’ll take solace in the fact that SEMA will be back in just twelve short months, crazy as ever.

pageElements.text: Yes, there was a Tesla fire two days ago (11/6/13), the third in six weeks, and the breathless national news corps is in full hyperventilation mode. (Stop breathing through your mouths, maybe?) Let’s regroup.

1. The first fire began when a Model S hit a curved piece of metal in the road in Washington State, which breached the battery pack’s protective shield. The curve of the metal and its angle at impact magnified the force of the impact to the equivalent of twenty-five tons, said Musk in a blog on Tesla’s website. "At no point did fire enter the passenger compartment." After a systems warning, the driver pulled over and exited the vehicle unharmed. The fire that broke out was contained in the damaged cells by firewalls built between the battery’s sixteen cell modules. Vents designed to direct fire down toward the road and away from the vehicle did just that.

2. The second fire (10/18/13) began after a Model S in Merida, Mexico, crashed through a concrete wall at a high rate of speed and then hit a tree. Oh, ouch. The driver fled the scene, seemingly indicating that he wasn't hurt. There were two small explosions from the resulting fire captured on video by a bystander. The fire was contained in the front of the Model S.

3. Wednesday’s fire began when a Model S hit a trailer hitch on a Tennessee road…yes, that pesky hunk of metal in the road again! Here is the full story on that one from the car's owner, who walked away unhurt and says: "This experience does not in any way make me think that the Tesla Model S is an unsafe car. I would buy another one in a heartbeat."
Will they find a smoking gun? Are two Model S drivers really unlucky and the third just an incredible moron?

In the wake of the first fire, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) went to the unusual trouble of announcing that there would be no formal investigation of the Model S because there was no evidence of a safety defect or breach of safety standards. This newest fire has prompted NHTSA to send a team to Tennessee to investigate the car. Will they find a smoking gun? Are two Model S drivers really unlucky and the third just an incredible moron?
Is the Tesla Model S dangerous? Or can we all agree that ALL CARS ARE DANGEROUS?

Gasoline-powered cars have been exploding in fireballs for more than 100 years, and they continue to crash and then burn furiously under much less dramatic circumstances than faced by these three Teslas.

Highest Safety Ratings Ever

In fact, NHTSA just gave the Tesla Model S its highest safety ranking ever recorded. Not only did it achieve five stars in every single test performed—a feat accomplished by just one percent of all cars tested—the Model S aggregated an unprecedented 5.4 total stars in the testing. After the additional and onerous side pole intrusion test, the Model S retained 63.5 percent of driver residual space compared with 7.8 percent for the Volvo S60 (the only other car to get a Good rating in the side pole test). Tesla explains the advantage by comparing the Model S’s safety engineering to that of the Apollo Lunar Lander. And that sounds right, doesn’t it?
Elon Musk, for all the quirks and bristliness, is more likely than anyone in the world to be able to fix this problem.

Elon Musk, for all the quirks and bristliness, for all his brash posturing and unforgivable brilliance (just who does he think he is?), is more likely than anyone in the world, anyone in the world, to be able to fix this problem, if the problem turns out to be random metal debris in the road. Musk has a hard-core following on the Tesla Forums who’ve started a thread to brainstorm a solution.

Meanwhile, the stock price, which Musk himself says “has a higher valuation than we have any right to deserve,” has taken some hits over the course of these six weeks in the wake of intense press coverage, but by Friday afternoon it was already starting to recover.
Overvalued or not in the market, Tesla is a brilliant player in the automotive space, where you would think that one man could never be able to achieve such automotive brilliance (COUGH Fisker).
Don’t count Tesla out. Elon Musk isn't.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: This is a story of two rebirths: Detroit's, still in progress, and the Dodge Challenger's. After an over twenty-year hiatus, the Dodge Challenger reemerged onto the marketplace in 2008, and it was a stunner. Back in 1983, when it ceased production, it had devolved into a subcompact that held little resemblance to its heyday as a Detroit muscle car in the 1970s.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text: It seemed fitting to take the 2013 Challenger SRT8 392 to the Cass Corridor in Detroit. Once the part of Detroit with the worst reputation, the neighborhood is reemerging from its years as a crime-ridden, downtrodden district of Detroit to become a re-energized cultural center. The juxtaposition of the iconic muscle car and the gritty rebirth of the corridor provided the perfect backdrop.

As long ago as the 1950s, the Cass Corridor had already been abandoned by the middle class, and its once opulent homes and apartment buildings had become rooming houses and seedy apartments. It was no longer the hub of commerce and entertainment but rather was known as a dangerous, poor area of the city. Detroit’s original Chinatown had been displaced by the construction of the Lodge Freeway, and its businesses and residents had migrated into the Corridor. The auto shows that had been held in Convention Hall had moved to Cobo Hall. Even its architectural gem the Masonic Theater fell into disrepair.

But counterculture loves a gritty home. Wayne State University is located just to the north and the Detroit Institute of Arts and the Society for Arts and Crafts (now known as the College for Creative Studies) to the east. Combine that with low rents and a racially diverse population, and the Cass Corridor was the perfect incubator for the subculture of the turbulent 1960s and 1970s.

Meanwhile, the first-generation Dodge Challenger was built as a muscle car from 1970 to 1974 in the city of Hamtramck on the edge of Detroit. I can imagine it rumbling down Second Street in the Cass Corridor along with its peers of the day like the Plymouth Barracuda, the Ford Mustang, and the Chevrolet Camaro. The cultural revolution of the area did not, however, bring prosperity, and the corridor continued its downward spiral.

The Challenger returned, rebadged as a Mitsubishi Galant Lambda, from 1978 to 1983. It was rear-wheel drive and had no resemblance to its predecessor. Meanwhile the corridor continued to have a seedy reputation throughout the 1980s and 1990s. Since my college days, a group of my friends from school meet at Mario’s, an Italian restaurant in the Corridor reputed to cater to Mafia types, at least once a year. In the worst years, we would drive through the desolate neighborhood and only Mario’s would be gleaming in the night. We would pull up and hand our keys to the valet and get inside as quickly as possible. It felt dangerous. At the end of the night, when you got back on the highway, there would be a wave of relief. Businesses such as Mario’s, the Traffic Jam and Snug restaurant, and the historic Temple Bar still held on through the darkest days.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
Avalon Bread

In 1997, Avalon International Breads opened in the heart of the Cass Corridor. At the time it was a bold move, perhaps even crazy. The concept was to hire local residents to create artisan bread with 100 percent organic flour in a blighted area of a dying city. But, in fact, they were not crazy, and their business has thrived. The owners have put in a lot of sweat equity as well as being community organizers and are currently building a 15,000-square-foot bakery in the city and relocating the original storefront to a larger space.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
The Bronx Bar

This place was built in 1921 as a grocery store, but it has been a bar for decades. In fact, the bartender, Charlene, has been behind the bar for thirty-seven years. You know the type; she calls you honey, is brusque with her coworkers, slightly impatient—but efficient—and makes you feel welcome. It is a great old bar that serves really good food. On the day we visited there was a group of young tech developers at one table, a young college girl typing away on her computer taking advantage of the free wi-fi, and several more customers eating at the bar and enjoying a nice cold beer on the sunny fall day.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
City Bird and Nest

Slowly, other ventures have joined the effort to brighten up the Corridor, and honestly the area is downright vibrant now. Yes, there are still lots of buildings in disrepair, and you need to be cognizant of your surroundings, but it is definitely an exciting, hip place to be in 2013. When we ducked into City Bird, we found a store, studio, and gallery rolled into one. The focus is on Detroit-themed housewares, accessories, and paper goods as well as work by hundreds of other artists and designers. They have also opened a second store next door, Nest, that sells upscale housewares. In true Corridor fashion, the brother/sister team behind City Bird are real, sixth-generation Detroiters. She earned an MFA, and he holds a master's degree in urban planning, both from the neighborhood's Wayne State University.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
Shinola

Across the street is Shinola, a completely different concept. There is nothing Detroit about this venture. It is the brainchild of the founder of Fossil watches, Tom Kartosis, whose company Bedrock Brands has also purchased the outdoor apparel company Filson. Shinola sells high-quality, desirable watches, bicycles, leather goods, and journals. The company's shtick is that it is based in Detroit because of our rich manufacturing heritage, but in reality the watches and bikes are just being assembled here. It is surreal to walk into the high-fashion showroom with its very expensive products and pair it with the real world outside the door.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text: The showroom sports highly fashionable sales professionals and a security guard who I am confident would make many Corridor residents feel uncomfortable. Don’t get me wrong; I think it is great that this company has chosen to have a presence in Detroit, but it is a marketing-driven company that sees Detroit’s gritty image as manna from heaven.  I wish them well, but scratch the surface and you can tell shit from shinola.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text: Our shiny Challenger looked right at home in the Corridor, and I felt proud to be driving it. Unlike Shinola, it is a Detroiter, not a poser. The name alone speaks volumes. The SRT (Street and Racing Technology) moniker denotes that the performance-tuning engineers at Chrysler were involved in the development of this model. The wide silver stripes on the glittery black body stretch from tip to tail, and its retro styling screams, “Look at me.” And indeed, the locals did turn their heads as we purred through the streets.
The Challenger SRT8 392 feels like a big car, and there are some blind spots to be aware of, but this is a car that is damned fun to drive.

I am inherently lazy, so I was thrilled that our Challenger sported a five-speed automatic transmission to tame the 6.4-liter V-8 Hemi. And when the driver wants to put his or her driving shoes on, the steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters can double the fun. It feels like a big car, and there are some blind spots to be aware of, but this is a car that is damned fun to drive.

Be careful when parking that you don’t nick the big low nose, and leave plenty of space when parking. The leather seat fit me perfectly, and the seating position felt just right (like the littlest bear's bed)—I am 5’7” and think a more vertically challenged driver may have trouble getting a comfortable seat with adequate sight lines. The Harmon Kardon sound system was appropriate for a car that will most likely be kickin’ out some tunes, but it makes sense to dial back your sound so that you can appreciate the exhaust note that has been lovingly tuned to perfection.

The steering is responsive, and although there is a slight roll it feels generally stable. I am not a boy racer, so my impressions are more in line with using this as an everyday driver, rather than as a street racer on Woodward. The ride was incredibly smooth for a muscle car, and I would recommend the Challenger SRT8 for anyone who wants to up their cool. But you can also up your cool by spending some time in the Cass Corridor. I only scratched the surface of this vibrant community that will welcome you with open arms.

2013 Dodge Challenger SRT8 392

Price: $51,665 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 6.4-liter Hemi V-8, 470 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated steering wheel
Option I can’t live without: Harman Kardon eighteen-speaker audio ($1,995)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Camaro, Ford Mustang, Hyundai Genesis, Nissan 370Z
