contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. Key Points

• With top-end models like this, the Korean brand once known for its bargain-basement cars continues its march upmarket. Notice how close this is to the psychologically important $40,000 mark.
• There are at least twenty-one other “affordable” mid-size SUV/crossovers on the market that compete in this category, and the Santa Fe is a solid competitor.

• In 2012, the Hyundai Santa Fe was only available with five seats. This year, the five-seat model has been renamed the Santa Fe Sport, and the Santa Fe name is reserved for a stretched-wheelbase, seven-seat model.
• The two-part Santa Fe strategy is part of Hyundai’s lineup plan as it killed off the Hyundai Veracruz.

• This is a very well-heeled version of the Santa Fe with solid safety features, lots of comfort features, including second-row captain’s chairs, which means it only seats six and not seven. Yet it still offers the industry-leading ten-year/10,000-mile warranty.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. pageElements.text: There are still green leaves on some of the trees in Ann Arbor, and it has barely even dipped below freezing here (yet). But Halloween was almost two weeks ago, so green leaves or no, it’s holiday shopping season. And that means luxury carmakers are clamoring for the attention of high-end shoppers. To this end, Aston Martin and Cadillac have teamed up with retailers Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue, respectively, to showcase their wares to their target audiences.

2014 Aston Martin Vanquish Volante, Neiman Marcus Style

Aston Martin is using a spot in Neiman Marcus’s famous Christmas Book to entice shoppers. They’re offering an extremely exclusive Neiman Marcus edition of the 2014 Aston Martin Vanquish Volante, as shown above. Only ten will be made, and they’ll feature a unique exterior color: NM Exclusive Seychelles Blue. It’s also got all the normal (if you can call them that) benefits of driving a Vanquish Volante: a 100 percent carbon fiber shell, a normally aspirated 6.0-liter V-12 engine making 565 horsepower and 457 pound-feet of torque, a 180-mph top speed, and, of course, the satisfaction of owning an Aston Martin.
All this could be yours (or your loved one's) for just $344,500. The department store will donate $3,000 to the Heart of Neiman Marcus Foundation for every Neiman Marcus Aston Martin sold.

2014 Cadillac ELR, Courtesy of Saks Fifth Avenue

Cadillac is getting in on the holiday shopping game with a window display at Saks Fifth Avenue’s flagship store in New York City featuring the 2015 Cadillac Escalade, and a spot in the Saks Holiday Catalog for the brand-new 2014 Cadillac ELR. The window display will be unveiled on November 25, featuring a 2015 Escalade in the act of breaking through a wall of faux ice.

Drivers looking for something a little more eco-friendly should check out the Saks Fifth Avenue catalog, where you can find a Cadillac ELR for $89,500. The ELR is a plug-in extended-range coupe; its drivetrain is similar to that of the Chevrolet Volt. These ELRs will be available exclusively in White Diamond.

Buyers can choose between a Light Cashmere or Jet Black interior and will have access to their own concierge service. Only 100 will be sold. Purchase of this limited-run package – also includes installation of an upgraded 240-volt charging station for the ELR’s 16.5 kWh battery pack. The battery can provide about thirty-five miles of all-electric range.

Luxury cars may not be in the cards for all of us this holiday season, but it’s still fun to see the lengths carmakers will go to to snag the coveted upscale shopper. Are you more tempted by the sultry Vanquish Volante or the slightly more practical (but still gorgeous) ELR? Let us know in the comments below.

title: Our Favorite Birth Year Cars
promoTeaserSmall: If you could drive any car from the year you were born, which one would you choose? Here are ours.
promoTeaser: If you could drive any car from the year you were born, which one would you choose? Here are ours.

metaDescription: Our Favorite Birth Year Cars: If you could drive any car from the year you were born, which one would you choose? Here are ours. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
1954

I met Nuccio Bertone in January 1981, under heavy guard. It was during the terrible times of the murderous Red Brigade terrorists. All of Fiat—its research facilities, design centers, museums, and favorite coachbuilders—was protected by heavily armed security.

Nuccio had a car show waiting in his courtyard for the arrival of our small band of journalists from the U.S. I went straight past the exotica, stopping at the charming little Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprint. He was delighted at my infatuation and found this black-and-white glossy photo, which he signed with a flourish and presented to me. When I discovered that the car had been introduced at the Turin Motor Show in 1954, the year of my birth, it sealed our bond.—Jean Jennings

1955

The 1955 Volvo PV444 represents something extra-special because of its importance to our family. We had a later model, the 544, but you'd have to know what you're seeing to tell the difference. Along with several other European brands, Volvo was just getting established in the United States in the mid-1950s. It became known for safety, but at first the brand was about efficient performance. In Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, the Volvo always stood out. Whenever I see one now, I marvel at the gawky but not unappealing shape and the details that really did set it apart. —Ronald Ahrens

1957

It’s almost foreordained to choose a favorite car from 1957: it has to be the Chevrolet Bel Air, doesn’t it? The '57 Chevy is one of the most desirable and iconic classic cars there is, and one look at it tells you why. I actually remember gracious, wide-hipped, tailfin-wearing turquoise cars like this from my early childhood. You can hear the Frank Sinatra music and see the saddle shoes when you look at this picture. It was the peak year for both Baby Boom births and quantity of chrome on the Bel Air.

The Bel Air was the top trim level of the '57 Chevrolet, with anodized gold trim to help it stand out from the lower One Fifty and Two Ten models, and it started at just over $2,200. I just learned that the first car Jean ever owned was a 1957 Bel Air coupe. It might have been my first car, as an infant, but I don't remember.—Laura Sky Brown

1963

Both the Buick Riviera and I came screaming into the world as 1963 models—and coincidentally, we were both conceived and delivered in Flint, Michigan. The Rivera, however, actually hit showrooms in October 1962 and cost $4,333. At the time, the Ford Thunderbird had been winning American hearts since 1958. The Buick's distinctive egg-crate grille, pontoon fenders, and razor-edged details made the American public pay attention. In 1978, my dad hit a deer with our station wagon on the eve of our family trip to the exotic state of Florida. We were concerned that we would not get to see Disney World or the gorgeous beaches that we had dreamed about. But that night, when he arrived home, he had a spankin' new Buick Riviera. It was white with a red velvety interior—and it was clear that my dad was cool.

The Riviera remained an American luxury brand until it started to lose its mojo in the late 1980s, and it was long in the tooth when it finally was put to rest in 1999, at the ripe old age of thirty-six. I have not given up hope for the Riviera, and this year there was a concept Riviera at the Shanghai Motor Show, complete with gull-wing doors. It isn't often that I see a Riviera on the open road, but when I do, I get a quick flashback to family trips in the velvety goodness of the back seat of my childhood.—Molly Jean

1968

I like the 1968 Jaguar for its long, languorous lines and elegance, but the 1968 Mercedes-Benz SL is what is in my head, because that's the car that emoted sophistication when I lived in Germany.—Catherine McCurrach

1976

As an automotive technology journalist, I tend to focus on cars emerging on the horizon and rarely peruse cars of the past. When I think about cars from 1976, only two come to mind: the pale blue 1976 Chevrolet Caprice my friend, Brandon, drove throughout high school, and my parents' Volkswagen Beetle of undetermined year (shown here, with me inside). The features I liked best about the 1976 Chevrolet Caprice aren't fit to print, and I am probably the only person waxing nostalgic about a '70s-era Beetle where my strongest memory is of the choke not working.—Liane Yvkoff

1983

I have to go with the De Lorean DMC-12, because of the movie Back to the Future which came out in the year of my birth.—Scott Allen

1991

I don't remember 1991 very well, having spent most of the year as a fetus and the rest of it crying. But as far as I can tell from a quick Wikipedia search, the best car that shares my birth year is the Audi S4, a performance variant of the Audi 100 sedan. Introduced late in the year, just like me. German, just like me. Drives fast, just like me. As a bonus, the nameplate has hung on and now graces a faster, sleeker version of the Audi A4. Perfect.—Annie White

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: All was quiet on the home front. I didn’t strain the Touareg TDI once I got it home, but I will say that, after a long day at work Friday, it was comforting to be in the familiar interior of a Volkswagen because I own a Jetta TDI wagon. Jumping into the Touareg wasn’t as jarring as it usually is jumping into a brand-new vehicle every night in the dark.

I immediately paired my phone and headed home. I didn’t know it was a TDI when I got in it, but it was so powerful I assumed it might be. There was literally no clue that there’s a diesel engine. No sound, no smell, nothing but a major whack of torque every time you press the accelerator pedal. When I got home, I looked around the back, and there was the logo. I found the Monroney sticker, and sure enough, it has 240 horsepower and a whopping 406 pound-feet of torque, which is that fantastic, dynamic twisting motion that, when you have a lot of it, feels like it’s propelling the car almost out from under your seat.  The horrifying thing on the Monroney was the price. Yes, the Touareg is quite lovely, and this R-Line version included all-wheel drive, a sport suspension, twenty-inch wheels, really gorgeous pebbly black leather seats, a beautiful panoramic sunroof (which, by the way, had a disturbing little rattle this morning all the way to the Interstate), and an extensive list of luxuries, all included in the price. That price, by the way, is $13,720 more than a base Touareg, for a total of $58,560. Holy Moses. I figured $50,000, but almost $60,000? Wow. And then, gulp.

As it turns out, the TDI has a great clean diesel engine and is worth every penny. When you first start the Touareg TDI, it doesn't fire up immediately. The dash gauges light up, and that’s where you see the little glow plug icon, indicating it has a diesel engine, and a split second later, the engine fires up. The glow plug superheats the spark plugs when the engine is cold. (By the way, my husband announced as I was heading to work with the Touareg that he also didn't realize it was a diesel the whole weekend.)

Because I spent the last week sick, I spent all of Saturday recovering from the one and a half days I was at work.  I put a pot roast in the slow cooker, and one of my brothers and his wife came over for dinner and to watch the ’Bama/LSU game. They’re terrible 'Bama fans despite the fact that our relatives live in New Orleans. Such traitors. We played euchre (women whipped the men) and then watched the game in front of a roaring fire. I saw the writing on the wall at the beginning of the third quarter and went to bed. I heard them cheering in the living room.

The wind was blowing like hell all weekend. My husband loved it because all of the leaves were finally blown from the trees except that one last holdout maple in front of the deer camp, and he could spend all Sunday morning blowing them out into the woods.

After that, we used the Touareg to ferry shotguns and black powder rifles to the gun range to sight in their scopes in anticipation of the opening of firearms deer season in Michigan on November 15. Bow hunters have already been out in our woods, but the real national “holiday” (it must be part of the UAW contract here) begins on November 15. The three main freeways feeding into northern Michigan from the lower part of the state are jammed wall to wall on November 14. Because the 15th falls on a Friday, this is going to be a major weekend in northern Michigan, and then the roads will be jammed again all day Sunday and undoubtedly Monday morning with people coming back downstate. If you don’t like seeing carcasses draped across roof racks, you’ll want to stay off the Michigan freeways that weekend.

If you’re a regular visitor to Jean’s Driveway reviews, you’ve seen the hunting camp. It’s that beautiful red barn surrounded by gravel. You can only imagine what the inside of that barn looks like. It’s a 100-year-old granary, and when we moved here, it had a nasty drop ceiling and a mishmash of carpet samples covering the 100-year-old wood floor. There was a broken-down pool table sitting in the middle of it. Over the years, my husband and his friends (and my cousin) have slowly turned it into the Taj Mahal of hunting camps, complete with a granite island, refrigerator, stove, a stovetop nicer than the stovetop in my own home, triple bunks, a potbelly stove, and when they got tired of getting up in the night to feed the stove, they installed a gas wall furnace. Last year, my husband lost his mind and had the 100-year-old barn floor sanded and polyurethaned. He just loved how it looked when they refinished our kitchen floor in the house. That's how he feels about his camp. The camp also has air conditioning so, in the summer, it’s Bob the Show Dog’s kennel to maintain his show-worthy coat, and in fact, Ray the Stray has now decided he prefers the hunting camp to his kennel, so he’s there every day sleeping in the bunks. He has never damaged one thing. I never worry about the alcohol; Bob and Ray are both teetotalers.

Some hunters see hunting season as a chance to drink a lot of odd alcoholic beverages (Jägermeister, Captain Morgan, and the Mason jar of moonshine that came from your cousin in West Virginia). All of those weird bottles seem to congregate at our house, because we have a camp dedicated to our hunter friends, and we don’t drink weird crap. That doesn’t seem to stop them from bringing all the weird crap from their bars to our bar, where it does nothing but collect dust.

Our hunting buddies aren’t big drinkers. In fact, most of them don’t drink at all. So if you imagine a camp with a bunch of guys in red long johns with the flaps hanging down playing cards, smoking cigars, hanging around the fire, eating red meat and lots of junk food, you’re only partially right. They don’t wear red long johns.
Oh, yeah, and they smoke the cigars outside.
A big round oak table is the center of jolly meals (frequently gourmet), card games, and stories about who missed what and why.
I can’t wait till they arrive.

I closed off the night with a visit to my mom, who is eighty-nine but tells everyone where she lives that she’s sixty-four. I asked her once how old she thought I was, and she said thirty-three. I’m going with that. We played Yahtzee and she beat me six out of six games, with a Yahtzee in every game, finishing off with three Yahtzees in the final game, including a one-roller of five fives. How do you compete with this? As far as I’m concerned, she can win every single game and I’ll give her as many rolls and she needs to do it, just to see her flash her rare beautiful smile and slap me five.

Love,
Jean

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pages.metaDescription: A guide to small, affordable motorcycles for those who are just getting started with motorcycles.
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: You've taken the safety course, and you're ready to ride. Now comes the part that's both fun and challenging: Figuring out what bike to buy. The best beginner bikes have low enough seat heights to make riders feel in control. They're both lightweight and nimble enough to be unintimidating, yet challenging enough that riders won't grow out of them before getting their money's worth.

Fortunately, there are more entry bikes than ever before to choose from. The down economy has had an upside for beginning riders. Long neglected by motorcycle manufacturers, small bikes are where most of the action is, in terms of all-new, affordable and easy-to-control models. The last couple of years have seen brand-new beginner bikes from all the Japanese manufacturers and, most recently, Harley-Davidson. And here they are:

Honda Grom

Honda is the global market leader when it comes to small-scale motorcycles, and its new Grom offers proof. The smallest, and least expensive, motorcycle on the market, the 125cc Grom has a starting price of $2,999, a top speed of about 60 mph, and fuel economy that exceeds 100 mpg. Diminutive in size but satisfying in performance, the Grom weighs about as much as many American men (225 pounds) and is probably even easier to control.

Honda CBR250R

Beginning riders who want to look more experienced than they actually are might want to consider the $4,199 Honda CBR250R, an entry-level sport bike that looks similar to its big-boy brethren, the CBR600RR and CBR1000RR. With a low weight of 357 pounds and a top speed of 87 mph, the CBR250R is agile and powerful without being overboard. Still, it's enough to get riders in trouble if they don't know what they're doing. At least the CBR250R offers combined and anti-lock brakes as an option. For 2014, the slightly more powerful, but even lower weight, Honda CBR300R is likely to replace the 250.

Kawasaki Ninja 300

The Honda CBR300R was developed in response to the $4,799 Kawasaki Ninja 300, which has become the entry-level sport bike to beat in the year it's been on the market. It's the most powerful beginner sport bike and the one that is designed to most closely replicate its larger, true-sport-bike siblings, the Ninja 600 and 1000, both in looks and aggressive performance. With a top speed that exceeds 100 mph and a weight of just 379 pounds, it oozes macho character with a surprisingly growly exhaust and joe-racer profile.

• Related stories:
    Five Musts for the New Motorcyclist October 16, 2013
    Falling in Love with Motorcycles October 9, 2013

Suzuki GW250

Suzuki is the last of the Japanese motorcycle makers to introduce an all-new beginner bike. Available since early fall, the $3,999 GW250 is a mini "naked" bike that's jettisoned the plastic bodywork common to sport bikes and modified the riding position so it's more upright and comfortable. Easy to operate, the GW250 weighs 403 pounds and uses a liquid-cooled parallel twin as its mule to offer good acceleration and even better fuel economy of 65+ mpg.

Yamaha SR400

Yamaha will capitalize on the raging trend for retro next year when it introduces its SR400, a throwback to its SR400 from the 1970s. Highly customizable, the 2014 SR400 can easily be converted into the most popular retro styles of today, from cafe racer to street scrambler. Powered with an engine that splits the difference between yesterday and today, its 400cc single cylinder is air cooled but also fuel injected, for improved fuel economy.

Harley-Davidson's Upcoming Street 500 and 750

Harley-Davidson shocked the world last week (Nov. 5) when it introduced two small-displacement cruisers for the entry-level urban rider, both of which will be available in the spring. The $6,700 Street 500 and $7,500 Street 750 are a radical departure for the country's largest motorcycle maker. Harley-Davidson has long had a rep as the builder of 900-pound status symbols. Its new Street models are powered with cruiser-style V-twins with a crucial twist for stop-and-go urban riding. They are liquid rather than air cooled, and they're far lighter weight than Harley's previously smallest bike, the 883cc Sportster. The Street 500 weighs 480 pounds, almost 100 pounds less than the Iron 883.

title: General Motors' Online Car Shopping
promoTeaserSmall: GM's Shop-Click-Drive invites you to handle the red tape without doing time in a dealer's cubicle.
promoTeaser: GM's Shop-Click-Drive invites you to handle the red tape without doing time in a dealer's cubicle.
metaTitle: General Motors' Online Car Shopping - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: General Motors' Online Car Shopping: Ready to buy your next car online? GM's Shop-Click-Drive invites you to handle the red tape without doing time in a dealer's cubicle. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I know what your parents did when they bought new cars. They flatfooted it down to the dealership under the tiki lights one September evening, probably with you in tow, and sought out their regular salesman, Vic, the one with the Ban-Lon shirt and the scratchy moustache. They picked out a car off the lot with very little comparison shopping. Did Vic give them a good deal? Maybe, maybe not, but they were loyal and didn’t have a lot of information to go on.

Unless you had “smart shoppers” for parents. Then they flatfooted it from dealership to dealership, trying to get a better deal, after thumbing through Consumer Reports until the pages fell out. You may or may not have been invited to go along, but it was a long, tiring, sweaty process.

And I even know what you did the last time you bought a new car. You spent hours upon hours online, surfing the car company websites, then on to the advice sites with their screens full of specifications and color choices. You played with configurators. You got pretty close to knowing what car you wanted to buy.

Then, of course, you made like your parents and flatfooted it down for a negotiation tango that was as unpleasant as it was exhausting. In the end, you drove off with the car you were ogling online all those lost hours ago. Did you get the best deal? You still weren’t that sure.

So go ahead, ask me: Do I know what you’re going to do next time you buy a new car? Why, yes, I do. It’s quite possible that you are going to buy it online from start to finish. Maybe the dealership will bring it right to your house for you, and you’ll never set foot inside a dealership. How do I know this? Because the first salvo has already been heard. This month, General Motors has rolled out online shopping and is said to be strongly encouraging its dealers to get on board with online sales. The Shop-Click-Drive website is up, and its logo proclaims: “worry-free, pressure-free, hassle-free.”

But not necessarily free of dealer interaction. You will still be hooked in to a dealer who will make the final sale, and you will still shop on that dealer’s website. It’s a five-step process: Get Started, Estimate Payments, Apply for Credit, Personalize & Protect, and Schedule Delivery.
Click Submit, and you get the dealer's offer without leaving your sofa. Negotiating can continue via e-mail before you even go in to test drive.

For the past several months, it was being Beta tested in Michigan only, which was lucky for us. I scrolled through the list of forty-eight participating dealers and chose the one closest to me, Art Moehn Chevrolet in Jackson, Michigan.

Chris Kudner, director of business development at the dealership, which is located about thirty miles west of Ann Arbor, told me the program has been up and running there since the early summer of 2012. Still, he said, only “half a percent” of buyers are using it, a sign that online shopping is going to have a slow curve toward universal acceptance.
“It’s a really great idea GM came up with,” he told me. “I’m just not sure if the consumer is ready yet, because it’s a big purchase. You really have to come and see the car.”

images.caption: General Motors claims "hassle free" car buying. Well, even if it's "reduced hassle," that's a plus.
The process starts at the home page of the dealer you choose to work with.
As on most dealer sites these days, you can browse specific cars online.
When you choose one, it comes with an Internet price offer.
The financial part of car buying is very well suited to an online shopping format.
Here's where you can browse add-ons and extras without a salesperson crowding you.
You can get through the whole process and print out the result before ever walking into a showroom.

pageElements.text: Of course, most people like the part about sitting in a car and taking it for a spin. It’s the endless sitting around in a salesperson’s cubicle filling out paperwork that we could do without. Kudner agreed that the best part of an online shopping program is that it cuts red tape. “It does take a fair amount of time to shop for a car in the showroom, “ he acknowledged, “just having the salesperson type in all your information, driver’s license, financing application, time on the job, income, Social Security number….” With online shopping, you can fill all that out on your timetable, from your home.

“To me,” he said, “that's the biggest advantage of the program, for somebody who’s strapped for time. Come in, and we’ve got it all waiting for you.”

Of course, online shopping doesn’t mean you can’t go see the car, and Art Moehn Chevrolet, like any dealership, wants you to come get a test drive.

“We handle online shoppers very similarly to the customer who just e-mails the dealership,” said Kudner. “We say, ‘What does your schedule look like?’ because we really want [them] to test drive the car; then we can talk about the numbers. It’s $30,000, $40,000, $50,000—you’ve gotta touch it, drive it, and see it. It’s not like toothpaste on Amazon.com where you can just buy it.”

But, you ask, what about negotiating? One reason the Beta program was concentrated among small-town dealerships around southeastern Michigan is likely that so many Michiganders are linked in some way to the auto industry. “I think they did that on purpose,” Kudner agreed. “With the new cars in our market, we do 98 percent of our sales as formula priced with GM, either employee or supplier or credit union discounts. It’s a set price from the factory, and people know that. It’s kind of a unique market. “

The dealership has recently rolled out online shopping to its used-car department, Kudner said. “Of course there’s always negotiation on them." A quick visit to the Used inventory on the Art Moehn website shows that you can get a lot of information, including Internet pricing, accessory discounts, financing applications, and trade-in estimates, by moving through the site. Click Submit, and you get the dealer's offer without leaving your sofa. Negotiating can continue via e-mail before you even go in to test drive.
It’s $30,000, $40,000, $50,000—you’ve gotta touch it, drive it, and see it. It’s not like toothpaste on Amazon.com where you can just buy it.

Once you've made your decision on a purchase or lease, Kudner pointed out,  state law in Michigan requires the customer to sign the paperwork in front of an agent of the dealership. That has meant a final trip to the dealer to take delivery. However, now that the program is out of Beta, he said, a customer can have a new vehicle delivered to his or her home or business and sign the papers there.
Wouldn’t that make you feel like a rock star?

Kudner noted that his dealership was one of the first twenty to have tried the Shop-Click-Drive program. “When they first came in and pitched it to us, there was some concern—especially with what’s going on with Tesla, with the manufacturer trying to go around the dealers. GM did a pretty good job of explaining that they weren’t trying to accomplish that, but looking for a way to help the consumer. They got us all on board.
“I get [the objectors’] point of view, but you can’t fight reality. I buy all my stuff on Amazon.com, from my phone. If you don’t adapt, you’ll get left behind.”

Will it be harder to negotiate a good deal over the Internet than over the desk? Speaking for myself, as a not very persuasive, perhaps even mousy consumer—but one with a lightning-fast typing speed—I can see definite advantages to negotiation by laptop.

title: Fiat 500 1957 Edition

pageElements.text: One of the most attractive things about the Fiat 500 is its styling that puts one in mind of the European minicars of the past. Fiat wisely builds on that La Dolce Vita appeal with the release of a 1957 Edition, which will make its debut at the Los Angeles Auto Show next week.

Why 1957? That’s the year that the classic Fiat Nuova Cinquecento came out in Italy—the “new 500”—and 2014 marks fifty-seven years since then. Between 1957 and 1975, there were almost 3.9 million of the affordable little cars built and distributed all over Europe.

The 1957 Edition will pay homage with cosmetic touches that echo the original, including vintage Fiat badging front and back, retro-looking sixteen-inch wheels, and white-painted roof and mirror caps. The interior has a special brown-and-ivory leather interior, including a leather-wrapped steering wheel with another vintage Fiat logo on it. Based off the 2014 Fiat 500's top-end Lounge model, it comes in Bianco (all white), or you can make it two-tone in either Verde Chiaro (light green) or Celeste (celestial blue), the color shown here, which is exclusive to this limited-edition car. Even the key fob is special, with a 1957 graphic and a casing that matches the car’s leather interior.

And, since this is a Fifties-inspired model, it comes with a five-speed manual transmission, although a six-speed automatic is an option, and a sport-tuned suspension with a driver-selectable Sport mode.

Fiat has done an admirable job of positioning the current 500 as a romantic and hip choice that’s still very practical, and it has worked. Since the 500 was relaunched in 2007, more than a million have been sold all over the world. I can see the Fiat 500 enthusiast being tempted to collect these like toys: one of every limited edition. If you’re interested, you can get this one next spring. Pricing will be announced closer to launch, but for reference, the 2014 Lounge model starts at $19,300. Orders will be taken starting early in the new year.

title: 2013 Subaru Impreza 2.0i Premium
promoTeaserSmall: Does love, plus a fresh Top Safety Pick Plus designation, make this all-wheel-drive car a must-have?
promoTeaser: Does love, plus a fresh Top Safety Pick Plus designation, make this all-wheel-drive car a must-have?
metaTitle: 2013 Subaru Impreza 2.0i Premium - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Subaru Impreza 2.0i Premium: A lot of people love this car, but is love enough to make you want to buy this Subaru? Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $21,065 base, $22,637 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 148 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: All-wheel drive
Option I can’t live without: Leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob
You might also be considering: Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Jetta

See more specs on the Subaru Impreza lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Lots of automotive brands have their adherents. You probably know Honda people, BMW stalwarts, and people who would only buy a Ford. (Some of those are in my own family.) But perhaps nobody is quite as unwaveringly loyal as the Subaru person. We could go into some stereotypes about Birkenstocks and recycling and the state of Vermont, or we could just accept that there are many perfectly wonderful people who want a timeless, reliable all-wheel-drive vehicle that will not surprise them or let them down, and Subaru does it for them. That “Love. It’s what makes a Subaru a Subaru” campaign is no joke. I have known dozens of people who swear by these hardy perennials and wouldn’t dream of driving anything else.

Timeless was indeed the first thing I thought of when stepping inside this 2013 Impreza 2.0i in Premium trim. “Timeless” as in, time has stood still. Every bit of the interior, from the waiting-room seat fabric to the throwback single-CD screenless radio, felt like 1999, or older. Where other small sedans in the Impreza’s class are making great strides in modernizing and adding technology, this car is holding fast to the good old days. Having said that, it doesn’t only look fifteen years old, it looks like it will last fifteen years into the future without showing a lot of wear and tear, and that could be a good thing.

And it’s not all old school: there’s Bluetooth hands-free phone connectivity and a USB port for your iPod. The uplevel Limited (which starts at $23,265) has a 4.3-inch LCD display screen and HD radio. Premium and Sport Limited models can also have voice-activated navigation, bundled with a moonroof ($2,200), which gets you a 6.1-inch touchscreen. The 2014 model is little changed from the 2013 we tested; it adds a standard rearview camera on the Limited, plus Aha infotainment and smartphone integration added on to the still-optional navigation package.

But the technology a Subaru shopper is interested in goes deeper under the skin. Subaru has been selling a full lineup of vehicles with its Symmetrical All-Wheel-Drive system since 1972, and every Subaru it sells in the U.S. market has had it since 1997—with a single exception at the moment, the sporty little rear-wheel-drive BRZ. A lot of today’s hard-core Subaru loyalists were created in snowy climates at a time when all-wheel-drive vehicles were rare and those you could get were trucklike (or trucks).

It is also an almost lovable trait of Subarus that they have horizontally opposed, or boxer, engines. This engine type, which has a lower center of gravity and is supposedly both more efficient and more durable, is a Subaru hallmark. Paired with a continuously variable transmission or, in the case of the car we tested, a five-speed manual, the Subaru Impreza’s mechanics are just not quite like other compact cars in its class.

In practice, this car doesn’t just have a different type of engine; it really sounds and feels different to drive down the road. The first few times I accelerated up to around-town speeds in the lower gears, I was afraid something was wrong with the car; that’s how much racket it kicked up. What Jean called a sewing-machine-like sound (below) was not at all like a "normal" inline four-cylinder engine sounds like, let me put it that way. On the other hand, get the Impreza onto the highway, and it’s surprisingly peppy and able for a four-cylinder engine that makes 148 horsepower. It took only a few drives until I was used to its eccentric sound quality and could tune it out to appreciate how sturdy and no-nonsense the Impreza really is.

I didn’t tune out the price, though: who else makes an all-wheel-drive sedan that goes out the door for under $23,000—one that gets 33 mpg on the highway? One that got five stars in the NHTSA rollover test, and the 2014 model of which was just named an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick Plus? Kind of makes me want to drive to Vermont. When there’s snow in the forecast.

The Verdict:

There are a few vehicles with all-wheel drive that come in under $25,000: the Nissan Juke and the Kia Sportage, for example. But if you want an all-wheel-drive car in a traditional four- or five-door body style, a Subaru Impreza is a very rational choice. Despite its conventional compact-car appearance, though, it’s not a very average choice. You’d want to buy one of these if you really need (or just want) all-wheel drive, if you buy into the Subaru brand identity, and if you are a highly practical car buyer looking for something with a value price that you can drive for years and years. You wouldn’t want to buy one if you’re looking for a buttery-soft, whispery-quiet driving experience, or if you have to have the latest gadgetry and goodies on board.
Like oysters, vacations in the Arctic, and the music of Schoenberg, the Subaru is an acquired taste, but if it’s to your taste, nothing else might do.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: One of my first attempts at driving a stick shift was on my father's Subaru Impreza WRX. The clutch was much twitchier than the one on the Saab 9-5 I'd tried earlier in the week, and the lesson ended in disaster. I've been wary of Imprezas ever since, even though I've now mastered the art of shifting. This Impreza still has a rough quality to shifts—especially in low gears—that I don't mind in a sporty car, but feels out of place in something with fewer than 150 hp. I just couldn't quite figure this car out.

Molly Jean: The curtains don't match the rug. On the outside the Impreza looks modern, but once you get inside it just feels old. That being said, it is classically old. Everything makes perfect sense, and the choice of materials seems built to last. I am confident that if you buy this car today your grandchildren can drive it to college—and everything would still work. If you want a car that you can drive the wheels off buy an Impreza today, but if you love technology and a modern interior you will need to keep looking.

Jean Jennings: The Impreza is old school—nothing sexy— but I’m pleased to note an interesting curvy rear and a strong grille that is most noticeable without following the latest bigger-is-better design trend.

It’s also not sexy inside, all black on black on black with hard plastic relieved only slightly by a small amount of soft surface on the doors and the tiniest bits of chrome and satin metal trims. There’s not a lot of extra padding anywhere, allowing the steady, sewing-machine-like ticking of the engine to filter through to the interior, which is graced with large buttons and rotary switches and little cubbies everywhere.

Here’s what’s important. You will love driving the Impreza, the impeccable foundation for the mighty Impreza WRX. The five-speed manual is so creamy, you can teach shifting lessons with it. Steering is responsive, totally connected, with crisp turn-in. The seats are simple and supportive with well-bolstered bottom and sides. This basic Impreza is good; it makes perfect sense that the WRX is so hot to drive.
One last consideration: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety just awarded the 2014 Subaru Impreza its rare Top Safety Pick Plus.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Give yourself a reality check when you go to the dealer to buy a new car. Think about three considerations:
    Who's in your car most of the time, and what do those people (or animals) need?
    Does fuel economy matter a lot to you? How much do you drive?
    How do you use your car, and where?
Take the time before you go into a dealership, and it will be a lot easier to get not only a good deal, but a car that is absolutely right for your needs.
Except for you midlife-crisis types: You should go get whatever you want.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Sonic Buyer's Guide: what we think about the new model. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: This small but mighty Chevrolet is aiming at the youth market with both barrels, and you can tell because of all the electronica: Bluetooth phone connectivity on every model, including Siri Eyes Free compatibility with your iPhone, TuneIn global radio, Pandorda and Stitcher radio apps, and Chevrolet MyLink (optional on LS and LT models, standard on LTZ and RS). After all, 30 percent of Sonic buyers are under age thirty-five and will actually know how to use this connectivity tech. But the Sonic is not just about music and cuteness: it’s the first car in the subcompact class to get the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s five-star overall score for safety, and the 2013 model was also an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick. It has ten airbags! Plus, it’s the only U.S.-assembled subcompact, GM says, so go ahead and look at this for yourself (or your college student).

Available in both four-door sedan and five-door hatchback body styles, the Sonic has a 1.8-liter four-cylinder with a five-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. A 1.4-liter Ecotec turbo is an option on the LT and LTZ models and standard on the sporty RS. It makes a pretty frisky 138 horsepower and comes with a choice of six-speed manual or automatic transmission. Remote start, heated front seats, and a sunroof make the Sonic feel a lot less like a penalty box. And how about the looks? Chevy calls this a “motorcycle-inspired exterior,” I guess because of the round headlamps. For those looking for a sporty Sonic, get the RS. It’s distinguished by a unique grille, a rear spoiler, and a lowered and stiffened suspension, plus an exclusive jet black interior that features a three-spoke leather-wrapped steering wheel with a flat bottom.

1. Ford Fiesta
2. Hyundai Accent
3. Kia Rio
4. Nissan Versa

3. Advanced Safety package ($) with forward collision alert and lane departure warning

pageElements.text:
Overview:

This year Detroit is the go-to source for going green. Doubt it? Just take a look at Ford’s updated C-Max Hybrid. Cute, yes, with a sporty comfort that makes driving fun. It launched last year but this year Ford has improved aerodynamics and gear shifting for even better fuel economy than last year. Ford was already claiming 7 mpg better economy than the Toyota Prius v’s highway numbers. The C-Max’s lithium-ion battery recharges while you drive using gasoline and regenerative braking recaptures up to 95 percent of the energy used in braking and uses that to recharge the battery. That’s some nifty energy recycling. The C-Max is not only efficient; it reminds you of how socially conscious you are by displaying more leaves and vines in the Smartgauge display as a “visual reward” for your good, as in energy efficient, driving, thereby making a game out of your urge to conserve. The C-Max’s popular price, starting just over $25,000—lower than its closest rival, the Toyota Prius, and some $10,000 cheaper than the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf—will help you conserve that other important green stuff in your wallet as well, always a plus.

Competitors:

1. Toyota Prius v
2. Toyota Prius III

Cool Tech:

1. SYNC with MyFord Touch
2. Hands-free liftgate
3. SmartGauge with EcoGuide display helps you drive more efficiently by showing how your driving impacts energy use
4. MyFord Mobile smartphone app monitors charging, sends car alerts, locates charging stations, and more

title: 2014 Ford Edge
promoTeaserSmall: A sport-utility vehicle, but one that loves technology.
promoTeaser: A sport-utility vehicle, but one that loves technology.
metaTitle: 2014 Ford Edge - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Ford Edge is a sport-utility vehicle that loves technology. Read our review of the new model on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Edge is a place where you find balance. This SUV crossover is not too big, not too small. Not too rich. Not too poor. It’s roomy, capable of hauling your family and your stuff—the rear seats and the front passenger seat lie down to accommodate more gear—yet the 2.0-liter EcoBoost engine is rated at up to 30 mpg. It’s an affordable mid-size SUV that comes in four series: SE, SEL, Limited, and Sport, each with a choice of engines. Yet some models come standard with rich luxuries like heated seats. One area where the Edge can boast about going  overboard, though, is technology. It sports blind-spot-aware mirrors that light up if something is in your path. Sync  with MyFord Touch has Wi-Fi capability, text-to-voice, HD Radio, and voice-activated Navigation—on an eight-inch screen—so you don’t have to disconnect from your peeps or your tunes to hit the road. Speak to place a call, control the atmosphere, or choose some music, and play it all through the standard Sony stereo system. A rearview camera lets you see behind when you put the car in reverse. There is plenty of technology here to keep you safe, as well, from the MyKey system that will harass your teen into wearing a seatbelt when he or she drives to the post-crash alert system that will dial 911 if the car senses an accident.

Competitors:

1. Buick Enclave
2. Jeep Cherokee
3. Chevrolet Traverse
4. Dodge Durango

Cool Tech:

1. Blind spot mirrors and available Blind Spot Information System (BLIS) with cross-traffic alert
2. MyKey programmable vehicle key

Looks:

1. New colors: Sunset Metallic, Oxford White and Ingot Silver (Edge Sport)

New for 2014:

Latest-generation SYNC® system with MyFord Touch features Wi-Fi, text-to-voice, HD Radio with iTunes Tagging and voice-activated Navigation System

Fun-o-Meter:

7

pageElements.text: The popular Ford Escape was cute last year. This year, it got sexy. The 2014 model has a smooth, trapezoidal lower grille and a shape that helps it move fluidly. The lines and shape increase aerodynamics ten percent over last year’s model. Just as sexy is the way it opens the rear liftgate for you if you kick your feet under it. Add to that a Class II towing package, and your sexy car will haul 3,500 pounds. Once inside, you can turn on the heated seats, check the cockpit-inspired dash, change the lighting to suit your mood, hit the push button to start, and connect to your tunes and friends through MyFord Touch. This car is loaded with tech toys. In fact, if your own driving isn’t world-class, the Escape will lend a hand. The optional BLIS system will keep an eye on the blind spot and alert you of what’s coming up alongside. The active park assist will take over the parallel parking—and execute it with the accuracy of a machine—so you can park like a pro. Oh, and with up to 32 mpg highway with the EcoBoost engine, you will have more money to spend on your own sexy self.

2. Honda CR-V
3. Kia Sportage
4. Toyota RAV4

Cool Tech:

1. MyFord Touch
2. Active park assist
3. Blind Spot Information System with cross-traffic alert
4. Curve Control

New for 2014:

Hands-free power liftgate and Class II towing package are now available together

5

Key Points

• This all-new entry-level car for Mercedes-Benz slots below the C-Class. In comparison, it is $5,900 cheaper than base 2014 C-Class, which starts at $36,725, including destination.
• The German automakers, most notably Mercedes-Benz and Audi, are duking it out for the souls and wallets of the young by rolling out these downsized yet upscale cars.
• The true battle is between the CLA250 and the 2015 A3. The two are priced on top of each other. But the standard equipment in the A3 includes a panoramic sunroof, Bluetooth, LED daytime running lights, leather seats and bi-xenon headlights. Several of those are extras in the CLA250.

• The base Audi A3 will get a 170-horsepower 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine, but Audi has not released horsepower numbers on the head-to-head competitor with the 2.0-liter engine.
• The CLA250 is just slightly bigger than a Honda Civic. The CLA250’s wheelbase is 106.3 inches; length is 182.3 inches. The Honda Civic’s wheelbase is 105.1 inches; length is 179.4 inches.
• Downsides: This Mercedes comes standard with a no-brand audio system with a single-disc CD; the base engine is peppy, yet noisy; the rear seat is cramped.
• Yes, it is oxymoronic that Mercedes calls the CLA a “four-door coupe.”
• The CLA lineup includes this base car, along with the CLA250 4Matic (this one is not priced and due out in spring) and CLA45 AMG, which is the cheapest AMG model in the lineup (starts at $48,375, including shipping).
• The as-tested price includes seven options or options packages, including special $720 Mountain Grey exterior paint ($720, a panoramic sunroof ($1,480), and bi-xenon headlights ($850).
• The Premium package ($2,300) includes heated front seats, Harman/Kardon audio system, garage door opener, compass, and dual-zone automatic climate control.
• The Multimedia package ($2,370) includes navigation system, rearview camera, seven-inch high-resolution LCD screen, six-disc DVD changer, and SiriusXM traffic and weathe.r
• The Sport package ($2,200) includes eighteen-inch AMG wheels with high-performance tires, brakes with perforated front discs, and AMG cladding.
• The Driver Assistance package ($2,500) includes Blind Spot Assist, Distronic Plus, and Lane Keeping Assist.
• That sexy witch hat I’m wearing in the video is not about Halloween. It’s about the sorcery required to get into the CLA250 at its budget-minded base price. The test car, which gets most of the available goodies, is $12,420 more expensive than the base price.

metaDescription: Four Electric Cars on the Horizon: Kia, Toyota, Tesla, and Nissan have EVs in the works that could be out on the roads in the next few years. Well, maybe not the Nissan. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: To hear some people tell it, electric cars are about to take over the world. And yet, there are only a handful of fully electric cars available for sale in the United States. Are we going to live in a world where everyone drives a Nissan Leaf? Probably not. More and more automakers are getting in on the plug-in car game, and that means there will be more variety for drivers thinking about taking the plunge and going electric. Here are four upcoming EVs you can’t help but get excited about.

2015 Kia Soul EV

An electric version of the Kia Soul will go on sale in 2014 as a 2015 model. Kia’s still developing the car but aims to get 120 miles of driving range out of a 27-kWh battery. They say the final product will charge in five hours on a 240-volt wall charger or twenty-five minutes when attached to a 100-kW charging port. Those stats are about in line with what we’ve come to expect from EVs (the Tesla Model S and its 200-plus miles of range excluded). What will set this EV apart from the crowd will be its funky styling, shared with the gasoline-powered 2014 Kia Soul.

2015 Tesla Model X

It seems as if startup automaker Tesla and its polarizing Model S sedan are in the news almost constantly these days. And Tesla’s hoping it can capture our attention again with its third production car (the company made a Lotus Elise-based Roadster from 2008-12). This time, they’ll bring us a seven-passenger crossover, dubbed the Model X and billed as "blending the best of an SUV with the benefits of a minivan." It will be available with a 60- or 85-kWh battery pack, shared with the Model S, and will feature all-wheel-drive technology and unique "falcon wing" doors, which hinge on the roof and open up instead of out. Tesla has said customers will see the first Model Xs in late 2014, but the schedule has already shifted once to allow for changes in Tesla’s business plan.

Nissan BladeGlider Concept

Nissan will unveil its three-seater BladeGlider electric car concept at this year’s Tokyo Motor Show, which opens to the public on November 22. It's unlike any other car, whether concept or production, that you’ve ever seen. Conceived as a street-legal version of Nissan’s Delta Wing racing car, the BladeGlider would have a center-mounted driver's seat with a two-passenger back row. It would also feature a removable hard top, so drivers can enjoy all the clean air they’ll be preserving with their zero-emissions vehicle. Sadly for those of us with a passion for offbeat cars, this vehicle is still an early concept, so don’t expect to see it on the road anytime soon.

Toyota FCV

Like the BladeGlider, Toyota’s upcoming fuel cell car is on display at the Tokyo Motor Show, and like the BladeGlider, it doesn’t have a firm release date. Or a name (they’re calling it FCV—Fuel Cell Vehicle—for now). Or a fully realized prototype. What it does have, though, is a fuel cell drivetrain that uses a chemical reaction between hydrogen and oxygen that creates electricity, which in turn powers the car’s electric motor. Unlike the electric cars we see on the streets today, which need hours of charging to replenish a depleted battery, fuel cell vehicles can be refueled using hydrogen gas, at a pump much like the one you’re used to using for your gasoline-powered car. The Toyota FCV will be based on the Lexus HS, a dedicated hybrid nameplate that’s sold in Japan, and if all goes according to plan you could see them for sale in select U.S. markets by the end of 2014.

We’ve still got a long way to go before EVs are as common as SUVs on American roadways, but if you’re hoping that day comes sooner rather than later, you should take heart in these grand plans from major automakers. I’m most hopeful to see the oddball BladeGlider whizzing by me a few years from now. Which of these green cars are you excited to see on the roads? Let us know in the comments below.

metaDescription: Michelangelo at the L.A. Auto Show: An Italian artist will paint the interior of a Fiat 500L during the auto show all this week. See his handiwork on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Michelangelo's stint lying on his back on scaffolding, slowly bringing the timeless masterpiece of his Sistine Chapel fresco to life, is one of art history's greatest moments. So it makes sense that Fiat had the inspiration to re-create it, after a fashion. After all, Chrysler or no Chrysler, Fiat is intent on being the most Italian brand on earth, more Italian than Barilla pasta or San Pellegrino mineral water.

So Italian artist Nicola Verlato (right) agreed to spend November 20-25 inside a Fiat 500L, flat on his back, painting a fresco inside it during the Los Angeles Auto Show's public display days. Fiat is calling it the Italian Masterpiece.

The larger Fiat was a good choice, compared with the diminutive regular 500. Nevertheless, Fiat took the precaution of removing the seats, installing a special paint-absorbing fiberglass headliner, and configuring the floor so that Verlato can swivel and change positions while painting lying down.

As to subject matter, luckily, he went with Michelangelo's style rather than something along the lines of the painting of three Michael Jacksons from the artist's website. Verlato used water-based paints for the underlayer of the work and then finished with oils.
What do you think of the result?

title: Secrets of Crash Testing
promoTeaserSmall: You've heard of IIHS Top Safety Picks. Want to see how the insurance group preps cars? Video here.
promoTeaser: You've heard of IIHS Top Safety Picks. Want to see how the insurance group preps cars? Video here.
metaTitle: Secrets of Crash Testing - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Secrets of Crash Testing: What the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety does to cars before it puts them to the test, with video. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Every savvy shopper knows to look at crash test and safety ratings from IIHS and NHTSA when shopping for a new car these days. Cars are far safer now than at any time in the past, and don’t overlook crash test ratings as one reason for that. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) is one of the big two crash testers. It’s a nonprofit organization backed by the insurance industry. The other is the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), a federal government agency.

Have you ever wondered how the cars that are being crash tested are set up so that they’re being compared with other cars on a level playing field? I know I have, and IIHS has just released this interesting video that explains how.
<iframe width="480" height="270" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/mHhSizn8hMM?feature=player_embedded" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Wow. Raise your hand if you thought they just chucked a crash test dummy in there and let ‘er rip? I kind of did. Well, actually, it makes sense to me that, before testing, they have to position the seats exactly the same in every car and set up the cameras and lights in the same way each time. But it wouldn’t have occurred to me that IIHS has to drain all fluids from the car and replace gasoline with a purple solvent to detect leaks. It’s like an automotive angiogram!

• Related stories:

    Understanding the New Crash Tests October 1, 2013
    Crash Tests for Dummies August 14, 2013

The IIHS puts cars through five kinds of crashes: moderate overlap front, small overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraints. Grades are good, acceptable, marginal, or poor on each test. IIHS’s Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick + awards are highly sought after, and to get the + designation, a car has to earn a Good rating on four of the five tests and no lower than Acceptable in the fifth. Automakers care deeply about these ratings, and so should you.
If you aren’t checking out your next car’s IIHS safety ratings here, you should. Has a safety rating directly affected your choice of car? Comment below!

pageElements.text: The Mercedes-Benz GLK250 took me to the airport for an overnight trip to New York City to unveil Automobile Magazine's 2014 Automobile of the Year on CNN's New Day. It is always a treat to celebrate a car instead of the usual hectoring and lecturing of the great unwashed media "elite." But CNN anchors Victor Blackwell and Zoraida Sambolin proved to be totally in the spirit of hot car love, so we had a good time.

First, I can't tell you just what it means to me to be able to award AOY to a Detroit automaker. It was a nightmare living through the dark days. I was born in Detroit and I will always be a Detroiter at heart. It is my spiritual home as far as cities go, although I grew up on a farm thirty miles away and live on one now. I'm from a big family, and isn't family defined as "where they always have to take you in"? Detroit is family to us. That is a big reason why we started the My Detroit series at Jean Knows Cars. I am your rah-rah girl, you brave souls committed to starting businesses in the strife-torn rubble of a city that was once great. We want to get past The Troubles, past the endless "artful" ruin-porn coverage of Detroit as a post-apocalyptic wasteland.

It is difficult for me to even talk about The Troubles without getting choked up. Three years on, the emotion is still surprisingly close to the surface. Automobile Magazine contributor Lawrence Ulrich won the Ken Purdy award—the most prestigious award in automotive journalism—taking a Corvette to Detroit and writing about both. The first sentence? "We almost lost Detroit." I read it aloud to CNN Money reporter Peter Valdes-Dapena. I read the sentence and choked up. The end of Automobile Magazine senior editor Joe Lorio's fine feature about AOY closed with: The 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray is a world-class car with no apologies to make, an expression of greatness from a town and a car company that have been dismissed as losers. It is also the Automobile of the Year.

Don't make me cry.

From what I can tell, GM North America president Mark Reuss feels the same. He has welled up so much over the raw emotion of really hitting this one out of the park during Chevy's darkest hours, that now he gets all gnarly and gruff, I suspect so that he won't just weep in front of his men and women.

That's where I am. I want to cry in relief that GM and Ford and Chrysler have put heads down to the task of showing the world their vast technical, design, and engineering talents. I am also YOUR rah-rah girl, Tadge Juechter, Corvette's brilliant chief engineer, for being the equivalent of MVP on the Corvette team. You and your team never wavered from the mission of making this the best Covette in its sixty-one-year history. You are unequivocally Automobile Magazine's 2014 Man of the Year.

And I am most certainly your rah-rah girl, brothers and sisters at the Corvette assembly plant in Bowling Green, Kentucky. God bless you, each and every one. And thank you for giving the world the best Corvette ever.

I arrived on the street in front of the CNN studios, expecting a gray Corvette. It was waiting at the curb, taking the first spot on the cab stand, and it was YELLOW. We threw the drape on, revved up for the live shot, and whipped that silk off as the producer frantically waved off yellow cabs trying to pull all around it. My people!!!

Then I flew back to the Motor City, where the Mercedes GL waited to ferry me back to the farm. I unpacked, repacked,
 and headed out on Sunday to the Los Angeles Auto Show, where I am now. There will be a lot of radio interviews first thing Monday morning about AOY, and I just hope the waterworks don't take over. It's so embarrassing.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text: The autumn auto show season is in full swing now, with shows this week in Los Angeles and Tokyo and new car previews as far as the eye can see. We’ll be bringing you updates from Los Angeles all week, but here’s a quick preview of some of the cars we’re looking most forward to.

2014 Porsche Macan

When Porsche started building the Cayenne SUV in 2004, some worried that the company was making a huge mistake. The Cayenne is now by far Porsche’s bestselling model. The brand is hoping to prove naysayers wrong again with the new Macan, a small crossover that shares much of its design language with the Cayenne. The Macan is likely to become Porsche’s most affordable model, so if you’re shopping for a new car, you could unexpectedly find a Porsche within reach, even if it’s not the one you’ve always dreamed about.

2015 Subaru WRX

The 2015 Subaru WRX will make its debut on November 20 (that's tomorrow!), although if you really can’t wait to see what it looks, like there are leaked photos all over the web. The WRX is a souped-up version of the Subaru Impreza and will come with a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine that puts out 268 horsepower. It will be available with a six-speed manual gearbox or a continuously variable transmission. The WRX concept made a big splash with enthusiasts when it premiered at the New York Auto Show last March. We’re confident the finished product will satisfy the Subaru faithful.

2015 Lincoln MKC

Last year, Lincoln’s Los Angeles Auto Show booth featured beautiful classic cars from the brand’s storied past. This year, they're showing us something brand-new: an Escape-based small crossover called the MKC. This will be Lincoln’s second all-new model since its rebranding last year, and early showings of the car have proven it to be both attractive and faithful to the concept version that was shown at January’s Detroit Auto Show.

2015 Jaguar F-type Coupe

Jaguar’s F-type, the brand’s first two-seat sports car in half a century, went on sale this year and captured the hearts of speed fiends everywhere with its rumbling V-8 engine and its modern, aggressive design. But it’s only available as a convertible. What are we Michiganders to do? Well, in case you didn’t give in to lust and buy a droptop if you live in a cold climate, you're in luck: the F-type coupe is here! Jaguar will unveil a closed-top version of the car this week, and from what we can tell based on grainy spy shots and heavily shaded teasers from Jaguar, it’ll be every bit as gorgeous as the cabriolet.

Mercedes-Benz AMG Gran Turismo Concept

Mercedes-Benz and its AMG performance division are using the Los Angeles Auto Show as an opportunity to have a little fun. Instead of unveiling a major redesign or a near-production concept car, AMG will bring its Vision GT concept to Los Angeles. It’s a futuristic supercar with extremely exaggerated proportions, a massive, aggressive-looking grille, and the brand’s trademark gullwing doors. Sadly, you’ll never see this one-off concept on the streets. It’s destined for the digital world, as one of the cars gamers can drive in the new PlayStation 3 game Gran Turismo 6.

And More

Of course, these are far from the only interesting cars at the show. We’re also looking forward to Chevrolet’s new mid-size pickup, the 2014 Colorado; the adorable 2014 Mini Cooper Hardtop; and BMW’s ultra-modern i8, a plug-in hybrid sports car. Stay tuned all week for more updates from the Los Angeles show, and let us know which cars you’re most excited about in the comments below!

pageElements.text: At the Los Angeles Auto Show this morning, the debut of the 2015  Colorado was announced with a booming country-rock soundtrack and a light show worthy of the Los Angeles setting. This tough little truck isn't Hollywood fluff, however. It's a solid contender that can be asked to do most of what a bigger truck can do while giving truck buyers a choice in the mid-size segment.

The 2015 Chevy Colorado promises to deliver refinement and versatility, and slotting in below the all-new Silverado in size, it should be perfect for those looking for manageable size in a truck that pairs comfort with muscle. A cargo management system in back for recreational gear was one accessory touted at the introduction. I was also impressed by the estimate of 20 mpg, although these numbers, like the price, won't be out till later. Two engine options will be offered: a 2.5-liter four-cylinder making 193 horsepower and a 3.6-liter, 302-horsepower V-6. Both are paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. A year after its fall 2014 launch, a 2.8-liter Duramax four-cylinder turbo-diesel engine will be added.

Of course, this Chevy is made in the USA: in Saint Louis for the four-cylinder, and Flint, Michigan, for the V-6. With its sporty looks, slim profile, and all the tech that Chevy can muster, the 2015 Chevy Colorado is a Tonka truck come to life. pageElements.text:
I was won over by the boy-racer charm of the 2015 Subaru WRX. As it was ushered in at the Los Angeles Auto Show this morning with a club-worthy soundtrack and light show, I was shaken out of
my cold-medicine-induced stupor.

The WRX, based on the Impreza, was shown in concept form at the New York Auto Show earlier this year (shown at right), where it was greeted with excitement. The production version is not quite the same, but that's no surprise. And it's still very good-looking.

But, more than just a pretty face, the 2015 WRX features a stiffer chassis, Subaru's Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive with torque vectoring, and 
a 2.0-liter horizontally opposed turbocharged four-cylinder engine that produces 268 horsepower and a healthy 268 pound-feet of torque. The engine is based on the one in the 2014 Forester 2.0 XT but is adjusted for more performance. The wheels are seventeen inches, and many exterior body parts are new to the 2015 WRX, including the hood, front fenders, bumpers, rear doors and quarters, and the headlights and taillight clusters. Do you like this "wide body" look? I do.
The new WRX will have a standard six-speed manual transmission (of course) or, optionally, a new continuously variable Sport Lineartronic transmission with manual modes.

Subaru forecasts 30 mpg for this car, along with a bigger interior, a new flat-bottomed steering wheel, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, and an enhanced audio system by Harman/Kardon. Plus, whiplash-reducing sport seats! Perfect for the combination of logical thinker and adventure seeker in us all.—Elaine Nadalin, Correspondent

Price: $24,930 as tested (including destination)
