pageElements.text:
2014 Subaru BRZ Limited

Price: $28,390 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.0-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 200 horsepower, 151 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 22 city/30 highway
My favorite standard feature: Keyless entry and push-button start
Option I can’t live without: No options on this model
You might also be considering: Honda Civic Si, Mazda MX-5 Miata, Scion FR-S

What I Think:

If these cars look identical to you, it’s not because you’re seeing double. The Subaru BRZ and Scion FR-S are, in fact, almost exactly identical. The cars were designed and engineered as a joint project of Toyota (Scion’s parent company) and Subaru, resulting in these two cars for the North American market and three other nameplates—Toyota 86, Toyota FT-86, and Toyota GT86—in other global markets.

These twins are designed to draw the eye. Low to the ground with aggressive front fascias and rear spoilers, and often dressed in eye-catching colors like Hot Lava and Lightning Red, these cars won’t go unnoticed. I spent a week going back and forth between a Firestorm Red FR-S and a Pearl Blue BRZ, and I got many nods of approval and looks of interest from passers-by. Even a man in a Mercedes-Benz CLS63 AMG—a car with nearly three times the BRZ/FR-S’s 200 horsepower—gave me an enthusiastic thumbs-up and a wave as he passed me on the way home from work.

These cars may impress from the outside, but their interiors aren’t particularly inspiring. The sport seats aren’t very comfortable, and it’s hard to imagine someone of greater than average girth settling in for a long drive. The back seat is too small to be useful on any but the shortest trips, and even then rear passengers will be cramped. The car is so low that it’s difficult to exit gracefully, especially when you’re laden down (as I often am) with a purse, a gym bag, and a stray coffee cup.

None of that really matters, though, because the BRZ and FR-S aren’t supposed to be comfortable or practical. They’re supposed to be sports cars, pure and simple. And they are. These cars are light, exceptionally nimble, and they’ve got rear-wheel drive setups and standard six-speed manual gearboxes. They may not have quite as much power as you’d want, but they’re still a riot to drive.

image.altText: 2014 subaru brz and scion fr s

pageElements.text: For drivers looking for a sport coupe on a budget, the question may not be,  “Should I buy an FR-S/BRZ?” but instead, “Which one should I buy?” Having driven the cars back to back, I can confirm that they feel exactly the same on the road. And they should, considering they’ve got identical engineering and design. The main difference drivers will feel will be in the comfort of the interior space.

The Scion FR-S comes in just one trim level, and our test car came without any add-ons, so we stuck true to the $24,930 asking price (destination included). The interior felt fairly spartan, with no steering wheel controls and a radio that looks like it came from Best Buy. Our BRZ test car came in the top Limited trim level, with Alcantara-trimmed seats, keyless entry and ignition, and a rear deck lid spoiler. Springing for the upper trim level will cost buyers $2,000. Unfortunately, it limped along with the same cheesy stereo we found in the FR-S. Of those options, only the rear spoiler is available in the Scion.

The Verdict:

For many drivers, the Scion FR-S and Subaru BRZ are not good choices. They’re impractical, a little uncomfortable, and refuse to fly under the radar. If that’s not your style, neither are these cars. If, on the other hand, you want a car that you can toss around corners and use to practice rev-matching your downshifts, this could be a match made in heaven. So, which one should you get? Since there’s no difference in driving enjoyment or looks—and, for 2014, both start at similar base prices, $26,390 for the BRZ and $26.010 for the FR-S (including destination charges)—focus on feature availability. If you’re fine with the bare-bones treatment or are tight on cash, the Scion is for you. If you’d like a few more features and a couple of creature comforts, get yourself to a Subaru dealership. Either way, you’re going to end up with a smile on your face.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The BRZ and FR-S are a bit low-slung for this bird, but they are both fun to drive and a perfect match for the buyer who wants a sports car but has a limited budget. Either would make an excellent first car for someone who has spent a lot of time in a go-kart, or wishes they had. And they have airbags.

pageElements.text: My day at the Los Angeles Auto Show was drawing to a close, and with my energy and blood sugar flagging, I took a seat in Toyota’s press area to hear about the automaker's Driver Awareness Research Vehicle, or DAR-V. As a hardy veteran of freeway driving, I’ve seen it all in terms of distracted drivers: texting, applying makeup, disciplining the kids, corralling the dog, you name it. All while the car is in motion.

Toyota is endeavoring to eliminate or reduce these distractions altogether, and as someone who has seen her fair share of distracted drivers, I can say that it’s not a moment too soon for this technology. The press conference was very detailed and comprehensive, but in a nutshell, Toyota wants to actively reduce the number of accidents caused by distracted drivers.

In a series of initiatives focused on enhancing vehicle design to reduce or eliminate distracted driving, Toyota has been working in partnership with Microsoft. You, the driver, would see a display of various pieces of highly personalized information as you approach the vehicle. Before even entering the car, you'd be able to check the weather and road conditions, get caught up on the news, and take care of any other tasks before you even start it up. Furthermore, since the system can recognize various passengers, children could encounter a game that encourages them to buckle up quickly.

Toyota presented a mobile laboratory for this upcoming technology: the Driver Awareness Research Vehicle shown here. Utilizing Microsoft Kinect technology, a series of icons appears on the side window, allowing drivers to gather the information they need to get through their day.
As a driver on Southern California’s crowded highways, this technology could be priceless and potentially lifesaving. I hope to see this come to fruition.

pageElements.text: I like to think I'm immune to Hollywood "glamour" and "magic." After all, it's all good PR and airbrushing, right? Things like that don’t line up with my solid Midwestern DNA. The only time I paid any attention to the Kardashians was when I binge-watched their show when I was sick a while ago. Hollywood stuff just leaves me cold. Except for the Los Angeles Auto Show.

The true stars of this event don't have entourages, PR people, or pending
court dates. None has done five stints in rehab or has had plastic surgery (although the Toyota Camry SE was rocking some serious nips, tucks, and tweaks that looked great). I got to meet these stars up close and personal, and no one shooed me away or tried to confiscate my iPhone lest any incriminating shots appear on TMZ later in the day. These stars were truly a class act, from the gorgeous Kia K900 to the I-just-wanna-pinch-its-cheeks cute Fiat 500 1957 Edition.

There were periodic crushes of media folk and bursts of applause throughout the day, but it wasn’t for an underweight starlet on the red carpet; the fuss surrounded a new-model introduction or debut. Each unveiling brought a storm of flashes going off and the momentary crush of photographers trying to get a closer shot. Part of me was so caught up in the excitement of each debut that I was surprised I didn’t wave my iPhone and squeal like a tween fangirl. There is so much to love about the L.A. show.

I loved how every stand reflected the personality of the cars presented.
(Honda, I'm still trying to figure out what your stand conveyed. Oh wait.
I got it. "Zzzzzz..." Duly noted.) There were splashes of light, color, 
and sound. Smiling PR reps handed out swag and press kits and answered questions. Press conferences were mobbed dozens deep, but I didn’t care because I was part of the action and had the chance to see some stunning introductions. Much more fun than I imagine a movie premiere to be.

There was really nothing for me to dislike about the show, except for the lack of device charging stations (do not die, phone. I need you stay with me now) and the lack of hours in a day to see everything there is to see. I was truly starstruck by it all. So much for being indifferent to Hollywood magic.
Air kisses, L.A. show. You look fabulous, I just loved your latest project, and we will have to do this again next year. My people will be in touch. Mwah!

pageElements.text: The Los Angeles Auto Show’s press days have drawn to a close, and automakers and spokesmodels are preparing themselves for the onslaught of public attendees who will flock to the show’s public days to see everything from the redone 2014 Honda Civic (above) to the most out-there concepts. The public show runs from today, November 22, through December 1. Here are five of my favorites from this year’s show; if you’re planning on stopping by the show before it closes, make sure you swing by these stands.

2015 Audi A3

Mercedes-Benz made a big splash this fall when it began selling the entry-level CLA-Class for just $29,900 (before destination). Now Audi’s getting in on the compact luxury game with the all-new 2015 A3, which will also start at, you guessed it, $29,900 before destination. The new A3 will also be available in a performance S3 variant, as a plug-in hybrid dubbed the A3 e-tron, and as a cabriolet. (See the photo gallery below.) The new model was unveiled this week in L.A., and it looks like it will give the CLA stiff competition. Among the enticing available features are Audi’s MMI system, leather seating surfaces, and the first in-car availability of 4G LTE connectivity with the new Audi connect system. Just don’t get too tied to that sub-$30,000 asking price. By the time you walk out with the keys, you’ll probably have spent several thousand more in options and extras.

2015 Chevrolet Colorado

Chevrolet is fresh off a total redesign for its full-size truck, the Silverado, but that doesn’t mean the company’s truck division is twiddling its thumbs. At the L.A. Auto Show, Chevy unveiled its brand-new mid-size truck, the Colorado. The new offering is aimed at young, active buyers who want the utility and flexibility of a truck but don’t want that truck to be gigantic. The Colorado’s dynamic styling is intentionally set apart from that of the big, boxy Silverado, but the two trucks share other features. The Colorado, for instance, makes use of the Silverado’s triple-sealed doors for improved aerodynamics and a quieter cabin. If this is the truck you’ve been waiting for, you’ll have to wait a little longer. The Colorado won’t go on sale until next fall.

2014 Land Rover Range Rover Long Wheelbase

In contrast to the Audi A3, the Land Rover Range Rover Long Wheelbase Autobiography is anything but small and economical. Instead, this is a stretched, ultra-luxe version of the already large, already luxurious 2014 Range Rover; the Autobiography Black model is long-wheelbase only. Jaguar Land Rover’s Engineered To Order division is behind the bespoke feeling of this special Range Rover. A limited build of around 100 units is planned for the U.S. market in the 2014 model year. The first twenty-five will wear Valloire White pearlescent paint.The Range Rover Long Wheelbase Autobiography Black will tip the scales at a cool $185,000, but if you want it in the even more exclusive Valloire White, it's $199,500 (including destination). Land Rover calls this SUV “the ultimate in peerless luxury” and says it will give rear seat passengers 7.3 inches of extra legroom over a regular-wheelbase Range Rover. If you spring for the Executive seating package, you’ll get power rear seats and power folding leather tables for each rear passenger. And, of course, if you need it to climb a mountain or cross a river, it can do that, too.

Ford Edge Concept

The Ford Edge may not be the most exciting car in Ford’s lineup (case in point: rabid fans will finally get their first look at the 2015 Mustang on December 5), but that doesn’t mean it’s not worthy of a spot on Ford’s L.A. stand. Ford debuted its Edge Concept at this show, and although the car didn’t have any earth-shattering design changes, it did feature a host of safety and connectivity technologies that Ford plans to bring to its cars in coming years. The Edge Concept has a self-parking feature that allows drivers to park it using a remote control device, new technology that makes steering at low speeds much easier, adaptive cruise control, and a lane-keeping assist system. Many of these technologies are available today in luxury vehicles, but we’re happy to see that Ford is interested in bringing them to mass-market vehicles.

Nissan Sentra Nismo Concept

The Nissan Sentra as it exists today isn’t exactly an enthusiast’s dream. It’s a safe, solid, but determinedly run-of-the mill compact sedan that makes just 130 horsepower and fails to inspire daydreams of any kind. But the Sentra Nismo Concept that Nissan brought to this year’s Los Angeles Auto Show is anything but boring. It’s got a more aggressive front fascia, nineteen-inch wheels fitted with performance tires, Brembo brakes, and performance suspension parts. The 1.8-liter turbocharged engine is mated to a six-speed manual transmission and makes 240 horsepower and 240 pound-feet of torque. contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Key Points

• Safety is often a prime consideration when people shop for a Volvo. The S60 received five out of five stars in National Highway Traffic Safety Administration front, side, and rollover crash tests. The 2013 Volvo S60 is a 2013 Top Safety Pick Plus by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, scoring Good ratings in every category, including the small overlap front crash test. The 2014 S60 is a carryover model.

• The Volvo S60 stands out from the growing pack of luxury cars because it’s a crash-test ace. When NHTSA launched its more rigorous crash tests in 2011, the S60 stood out as one of the only cars to completely ace all of the revised tests’ categories.

•  The Volvo S60 has also grabbed lots of safety awards, including receiving a rating of Superior in a new front crash program by the IIHS for cars equipped with auto brake and forward collision warning. In test results released in September 2013, among the seventy-four moderately priced and luxury cars and SUVs tested, Volvo’s City Safety was the only low-speed crash prevention system offered as standard.  City Safety prevents low-speed collisions by monitoring traffic in front of the car. When driving at speeds between 2 mph and 19 mph, the car can automatically apply brakes to prevent fender benders. The IIHS notes that users of City Safety wind up filing about 27 percent fewer at-fault claims than drivers without the system.

• The car we tested has four options: The Premier Plus package ($3,150) includes a power glass moonroof, leather seating, keyless drive with a personal car communicator, power passenger's seat, an auto-dimming rearview mirror with compass, side-window brightwork, adaptive digital display, HomeLink, a rearview camera, and a grocery bag holder; the Sport package ($1,200) includes sport seats, paddle shifters, sixteen-inch alloy wheels, and a dynamic chassis; metallic paint ($550), and heated front seats ($500).
• The S60 T5 is the value leader in the S60 lineup.

• When the 2015 S60 comes out in late January in the U.S., the car will features a new eight-speed automatic transmission and a new 2.0-liter inline four-cylinder engine that uses both an Eaton supercharger and a Borg-Warner turbocharger. It’s the most potent gasoline engine in Volvo’s new Drive-E family of 2.0-liter engines.

• The new T5 and T6 four-cylinder engines will only be offered on front-drive models for the 2015 model year. All-wheel-drive models will continue to use Volvo’s five- and six-cylinder engines for a couple more years.

pageElements.text: When deciding on what type of two-wheeler to buy, the choice often comes down to the clutch. Most motorcycles have one. Scooters do not, which is part of the reason scooters have twice the female ridership of bikes. But recent years have seen a growth in the number of motorcycles that can be shifted with the push of a button instead of the pull of a clutch.

For many aspiring riders, ditching four wheels for two is intimidating enough. Add the need to coordinate all four appendages to clutch with a hand, shift with a foot, and apply the front and rear brakes separately with the other hand and foot can seem like an insurmountable task, especially since the likelihood that a beginning rider has any experience with a manual is almost nil. Two-thirds of 2012 model year cars aren't even offered with manual transmissions.

Semi-automatic motorcycles remove the most complicated, and necessary, act of coordination required for motorcycle riding by replacing the clutch lever with a button, while automatic motorcycles do away with the need to manage shifting entirely. Here are some worth looking at.

Honda NC700X

Honda is the primary innovator of modern clutchless-motorcycle technology. Last year, it introduced its $7,499 NC700X sport bike with a dual-clutch transmission, or DCT. More commonly found on cars, the DCT is operated with a button on the left handlebar. Behind the scenes, the mid-size 670-cc NC700X uses two clutches that, together, combine the ease of an automatic transmission with the quick acceleration of a manual. All the rider has to do is twist the throttle with the right hand and push a button with the left.

Honda's Mid-Size CTX700

Honda first introduced the DCT in 2010 on its significantly more powerful supersport bike, the VFR1200. For the 2014 model year, it made the DCT available as an option on its new mid-size cruiser, the CTX700 (also shown at top of the page), for a $1,000 price premium. The CTX700 DCT costs $8,799.

Honda's DCT replaces the hydromechanical transmission it first introduced for a street bike with its short-lived motorcycle-scooter crossover, the DN-01. Produced from 2008 to 2010, the DN-01 could be operated in fully automatic or manual modes.

Aprilia Mana 850

Italian sport bike maker Aprilia makes a mid-size motorcycle that can be operated as a semi-automatic, like the Honda 700s, or in a fully automatic transmission mode. First introduced in 2008, the $11,199 Aprilia Mana 850 uses an "autodrive" transmission similar to the pulley-driven continuously variable transmissions, or CVTs, found in some cars and most scooters. Operated as a full automatic, the Mana 850 doesn't require any action from the left hand other than holding on. Just twist the throttle and go. Used as a semi-automatic, all riders need to do is push the shifter button.

Ridley's CVT Bikes

Billing itself as the company that builds America's Automatic Motorcycle, Ridley, in Oklahoma City, is the only motorcycle maker to specialize in twist-and-go bikes. None of its models even have the option of a clutch or foot-operated gearshift. Combining the look of a mid-size cruiser motorcycle with the easy rideability of a scooter, all Ridley bikes are operated with continuously variable transmissions.

Targeting women and new riders, Ridley's bikes have some of the lowest saddles available: just 24.5 inches. They also weigh a reasonable 450 pounds, though they are quite expensive: $13,500. Ridley has been building bikes since 1999 but was sued by Harley-Davidson for using the term "Auto-Glide" to describe its automatic transmission. It stopped producing bikes in 2009, but the company continues to sell its 2009 models. All of them are powered with a mid-size 750-cc V-twin.

pageElements.text: I have a crush on a luxurious composite material. It’s Alcantara, a fake suede that is popping up in the interiors of vehicles from General Motors to Lamborghini. The last time an interior material received fame and fortune was the "fine Corinthian leather" that had Ricardo Montalban as the spokesperson. But watch out: there is a new material in town worthy of a spokesperson—Alcantara.

Enter Rosa Clandestino, a fashion house led by founder and creative director Silvia Arguello. In an interesting PR move, Alcantara partnered with Rosa Clandestino to showcase the high-end material in a high-fashion runway show during the Los Angeles Auto Show. With invitees ranging from designers to auto industry executives, the show took place at the gorgeous Vibiana—the former Cathedral of Saint Vibiana, now an event venue.

You may have seen Arguello (seated at left in this photo) as a contestant on the NBC reality-TV series Fashion Star, or if you are an astute fashionista, from Vogue Italia, Vogue Latin America, WWD, Corriere della Sera, Elle Italia or Grazia. The likes of Eva Longoria, Milla Jovovich, and Willa Holland choose to show up for red carpet events in her pieces. Although not the ultimate winner of Fashion Star, this Milan-based, U.S.-born, Honduras-raised designer is definitely still on trend to be a superstar designer. She is known for her blend of high tech and natural fabrics, so she was a perfect fit for this collaboration.

The Alcantara collection shown that night has a Sixties flair with baroque-inspired laser-cut details. The dresses are gorgeous, the setting was dramatic, and it was a perfect beginning to the L.A. Auto Show. Although these works of art were not intended for sale, I am going to keep an eye on both Rosa Clandestino and Alcantara; either one is welcome in my driveway or closet.

pageElements.text: The 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe was our home away from home on a family jaunt to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, Ohio. The idea to make the pilgrimage had started on our summer vacation when my daughter, Elle, watched Almost Famous and declared that she loved rock music. Even though the movie is based on a fictional band, Stillwater, she did hear a lot of legit rock music on that soundtrack. For the remainder of that vacation trip, my husband, Tom, and I set out to share the music of our youth with her. We took a musical trip down memory lane with some of our favorites such as Janis Joplin, Eric Clapton, Jimi Hendrix, Led Zeppelin, and Pink Floyd. But we realized that she needed a more thorough education and decided to make the trip to Cleveland.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: Even though some may argue that we should have driven an American vehicle, I disagree. To me, rock and roll celebrates a lifestyle of freedom—just experiencing things as they come and not caring what others think. Hyundai’s headquarters may be in Seoul, South Korea, but the Santa Fe is an American car that was custom made for us. In fact the Santa Fe was conceived in Hyundai’s design studio in California, and the majority of Santa Fes are made in Georgia. The same Georgia that is the childhood home of the godfather of soul, James Brown.

The Santa Fe is not a complete unknown. It has sold over a million vehicles since its debut as a 2001 model. But the current model does not even remotely resemble its predecessor, which was intended as an inexpensive way to get into a sport-utility vehicle but was definitely not a looker. This generation of Hyundai has all the trimmings of a premium vehicle, including choice of materials, ride, and styling. It has both style and substance, and at $38,840 for our tricked-out Limited AWD version with Saddle interior to seat seven, it is hard to beat.

How does it feel
How does it feel

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: Elle brought her friend Gloria on our trip. They loved the second-row captain's chairs and immediately switched on the seat heaters. If you require a seventh seat, you will need to forfeit those captain's chairs, but the access to the third row is effortless. And folding half of that third row was a snap and provided a flat surface to accommodate our pup and her house. The panoramic roof allowed the sunlight to pour into the cabin, adding to the spacious feeling of this mid-size SUV. The interior sported handsome saddle brown seats that nicely contrasted with the black interior. There were excellent storage spots and ample cupholders.

We needed to make haste: it was a 169-mile drive each way, the Hall of Fame would require at least two hours of our time, and of course we needed to eat. The drive down gave us the normal experience of most SUV owners—highway driving with teenagers ignoring us in the back seat. The Santa Fe ate up the miles while showing us its manners.

There is only one powertrain available, a 3.3-liter V-6 with a six-speed automatic transmission, but the all-wheel drive is optional. Rough Michigan roads didn’t make the ride unbearable, and lane changes were nimble and smooth. There are three modes for steering, but this driver had trouble telling much difference. The navigation barked out directions and gave us notice well in advance. As we neared our destination, the computer helped us locate a restaurant.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: We settled on Barley House in Cleveland's Warehouse District. It actually has taps at individual tables, so you can pour your own. Clearly this is a genius move, but not for us on this trip. Adding to the charm, or rather lack of, there were a few birds loose in the restaurant and the girls were not digging it. Perhaps it was a ghost of the rhythm and blues band the Byrds trying to get our teens'  attention. Regardless, we persevered and had a lovely lunch, then hightailed it to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum to school these girls and get them to loosen up a bit.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The glass pyramid exterior of the Hall of Fame is a tad reminiscent of the Louvre. It celebrates our musical history, and it is not limited to what I think of as rock and roll. If you are wondering why Cleveland, let me tell you. In 1951 Alan Freed, a disc jockey from Cleveland, coined the term "rock and roll" to describe the up-tempo black rhythm and blues records he played. He hosted the nightly Moon Dog House Rock and Roll Party on WJW radio and organized the first ever rock concert in Cleveland. So enough said, Cleveland makes sense.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The curators have done an incredible job of exploring the context of the past and present of rock and roll, both culturally and musically. The museum is set up so that the first area visitors experience has listening stations of the influencers who helped create rock music, and it continues to showcase the opposition that the early years experienced. Then, bam, you run into Elvis. Giant screens tell his story and his various memorabilia surrounds you as you walk through.

The next section is set up by city, from Memphis to London to L.A., and by time period, from 1948 to the mid-1990s. It carries you through  the British Invasion, soul, grunge, and heavy metal. As we weaved our way through the cities it was amazing to see all the outfits and artifacts that we have all seen so much through the years. I especially liked the handwritten lyrics, and somehow shoes worn by the greats intrigued me.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The museum houses so much history that I actually think it would take two days to do a thorough job of absorbing all that it has to offer. It had listening stations that would show you the influencers behind a current artist, and another exhibit that was a tribute to one-hit wonders. There is a theater that showcases all of the members of the hall of fame, and if we had time to listen to the entire show that would have been worth the price of admission alone.

To be without a home
Like a complete unknown
Like a rolling stone?

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The featured exhibit was Rolling Stones: Fifty Years of Satisfaction. It was chock full of the band’s personal items, including many of their costumes that I immediately recognized. Even though it was all behind plexiglass, it somehow felt like you were getting to sneak backstage at a concert. I regret that we had to make the trip in just one day and felt like we still have a lot to do to help our daughter understand rock and roll.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: We headed back to Ann Arbor as the sun was setting like a rolling stone. We flipped over to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame station on Sirius radio to continue our education and spent the drive churning over all that we had just seen. Highly recommended! Go to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum website to plan your own musical nostalgia tour, or an educational trip for your kids. And if you can go there in a vehicle as all-around comfortable and luxurious as the Santa Fe, you'll be lucky.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: All parents want to know that their children are as safe as possible when riding in the car, and that means buying a good car seat. But with so many choices, it can be hard to know which one to buy. To help guide parents who are shopping for booster seats, which are recommended for children aged roughly four to eight, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) has released a report detailing the results of this year’s booster seat fit test.

Booster seats help safely position seatbelts on children who have outgrown their forward-facing child seats. Seatbelts should sit flat across a child’s upper thigh and snugly over their shoulder. They shouldn’t sit over the child’s abdomen or slide up onto their neck or down off their shoulder. To test whether booster seats provide proper fit, the IIHS tests them with a child-sized dummy in seats from cars, minivans, and SUVs.

The Ratings

The best booster seats provide safe seatbelt fit in almost any vehicle. Those seats earn a Best Bet rating from the IIHS. Seats that provide an acceptable fit in most vehicles earn a Good Bet rating. Seats that may work in some vehicles earn a Check Fit rating, encouraging parents to try the seat with their own child in their own car before buying. Seats that can’t stand up to the Check Fit standards are rated as Not Recommended. This year, the IIHS tested thirty-one current booster seat models. Of those, nineteen earned a Best Bet rating, one was named a Good Bet, and eleven more were rated at Check Fit.

Just two seats were rated as Not Recommended by the agency; both were three-in-one seats from Dorel. These convertible seats work well as rear- or forward-facing restraints but don’t quite pass muster as booster seats.
For a full list (with pictures) of the rated booster seats, visit the IIHS website.

images.caption: Two IIHS Best Bets: Recaro Vivo (left) and Britax Parkway SG.
IIHS Best Bets: Evenflo Chase (left) and Graco Nautilus Elite.
More IIHS Best Bets: the backless Harmony Youth Booster and Evenflo Amp, and the full-length Cosco Pronto.

pageElements.text:
Don't Rush into a Booster Seat...

IIHS also cautions parents not to prematurely switch children from a forward-facing restraint with its own integrated harness to a booster seat. They suggest leaving children in forward-facing restraints until they reach the height or weight limit for the seat. When you do decide to switch to a booster seat, check that the seat fits not just your child, but also your vehicle (and any other vehicle your kid frequently rides in) before purchasing it. Also be sure to keep an eye on the IIHS’s ratings. Three seats that had passed previous tests with flying colors slipped to a Check Fit rating this year after they were substantially redesigned; don’t assume that a seat is safe just because it earned a good rating a few years ago.

...And Then, Don't Rush Out of One

Once you find the right booster seat for your child, fight to keep him or her in it. As little kids turn into big kids, they may start rebelling against the oppression and fundamental un-coolness of a car seat. But until they’re tall enough to wear a seatbelt safely without aid, stand firm. IIHS says kids aged four to eight are 45 percent less likely to be injured in a crash if they’re in a booster seat compared to wearing a seatbelt alone. Enough said.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: Any power shopper worth her salt has already ogled the Saks Fifth Avenue limited-edition Cadillac ELR luxury coupe, for sale in the 2013 Saks Holiday Catalog. But the Cadillac excess doesn't stop with that electric luxury coupe.

Check out this Frozen Escalade in the shop window that's part of the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship store's stunning holiday display. Behind that fake ice is the all-new 2015 Cadillac Escalade SUV in White Diamond. The upcoming model's LED lights offer the extra brightness needed to catch shoppers' eyes as it appears to be breaking through a wall of ice.

Buyers of the all-new Escalade won't be able to try this, at least not this winter: It doesn't go on sale until spring. But the tie-in with Saks makes sense in view of the one-percenter marketing push. The Escalade's consumer website features banner text reading: "The Official Mover of the Shakers" and "The 420-hp Gated Community."

The 2015 Escalade is the sixth generation of the massive luxury SUV. It will be available in standard and extended-wheelbase (ESV) versions, in rear- or all-wheel drive, and with the aforementioned 420 horsepower from a 6.2-liter V-8. Luxury and Premium trim packages are offered above the already luxuriant base model. And yes, that White Diamond color is on the list of choices. As for the question, how much is that big dog in the window? Prices haven't been announced yet, but with the current Escalade already starting at about $64,000, you can hazard a guess.

But perhaps you just want to see holiday window displays. Who doesn't? Here is the best quick photo tour of store windows from around the world, including Saks, that I've found this year. Vicarious thrills!

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
In Which I Put in Play Virtually Every Vehicle in the Driveway

What happened to the weather in Michigan while I was at the Los Angeles Auto Show?!? Tornadoes, high winds, and power outages across the Midwest in the middle of November. Basically, Armageddon. Luckily, I left winter clothes back in Detroit at airport parking in Automobile Magazine’s Mercedes-Benz GLK long-term test car. It was waiting with heated seats beckoning and lots of room for the luggage, for my husband, Tim, to go fetch it while I hauled our bags from the carousel out to the curb. I will admit to being rigidly OCD about stacking bags on a pushcart and then packing them perfectly into the back of the car, ergo the division of labor. (Note: The GL has a split-screen rearview camera that includes an overhead shot, making it virtually impossible to screw up backing perfectly into a spot.)

Having Tim be the one to drive home, though, offers only a brief respite. I’m the one who will have to go the next fifty miles to get the dogs. They are big, they are insane from being at the kennel for a week, and I have to figure out how to lift sixty-two pounds of squirming old dog Louie up and into the back of the Chevrolet Suburban. Bob and Stella leap into cages in a single bound. And then there’s Ray the Stray. The young lad is totally capable of the jump, but no. Tim convinced him early on that it’s much better to be swept up in Dad’s big, strong arms and then be placed neatly into his cage. I use one good arm and a knee, and I throw a dog treat in the back of the cage. It’s still like handling an octopus.

Saturday was a day for Words with Friends in front of the fire, while snow swirled on and off outside and Tim stalked the wily buck in vain. There was a quick trip to our veterinarian in the family Volkswagen Jetta TDI wagon with Louie for her acupuncture treatment, which has been working very well in soothing her crippled rear legs. Our super vet, Dr. Tim, places pins along her bladder and gall bladder “yang” meridians for about twenty minutes. The longer the pins are in, the more pain relief she gets. This is also how a vet can completely drain a dog’s life force in the case of euthanasia, so we have to be very careful in this process. Watching the old girl bound up the steps when we get home assures me that there’s a whole lotta chi left in her old fuzzy brown body. (Tiny sob.)
I was running late and had to really give the Suburban the boot. At 95 mph, it was like driving the QE2 at warp speed into the wind.

That evening, I had to announce a fashion show in Ypsilanti at the quirky boutique Mix, so I hauled out the Suburban because the GL was too small for The Hat, by which I mean The Hat at the top of this website, The Hat shot against the red barn, a Mr. Song couture event of a hat. Its box is huge in every dimension.

I was running late and had to really give the Suburban the boot. At 95 mph, it was like driving the QE2 at warp speed into the wind. I swear I could see the needle on the gas gauge actually moving. It was the perfect week for local fuel prices to be under $3 a gallon.

The snow was really coming down by the time I got to Ypsi, but a parking spot was waiting right in front of Mix. Once on my head, the hat must go sideways to get in the door, so I sidled into the scene amid great excitement. Models were mingling and chattering in the back room, and the chairs were filling up, on their way to a packed house.

As usual, people approached The Hat, ignored the rigid wall of shaved ostrich feathers marking the border of my personal space, and came under and in for the kiss. I’ve been to runway shows at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week in New York City, but this was so much more fun, my own little Chevrolet Fashion Show at Mix, where you could see all the potential outfits off their hangers and arranged on a variety of heights and shapes of women, making everything look so much more desirable! As my husband would say, I’m not a shopper, I’m a buyer. (Love my new bracelet!)
Sunday was cold, colder, coldest. My remaining four brothers and I converged from all corners of Michigan on my mother’s nursing home for an early family Thanksgiving celebration.
Happy Thanksgiving everyone!

Love,
Jean

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. pageElements.text:
Price: $23,985 as tested, including destination
Engine: 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/36 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Leatherette seating surfaces with driver and passenger power recline
Option I can’t live without: No options on this model
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Cruze, Honda Civic, Mazda 3

What I Think:

I’ve always been a fan of cars with distinctive design and quirky features. The cars we drive say something about us, and I’ve always hated the idea of driving a car that labeled me as traditional or boring. But it seems as if today’s affordable-car market may be listing toward too much style, not enough class.

Cars like the new Toyota Corolla, the Chevrolet Spark, and the Fiat 500L are interesting to look at and they’ll set their owners apart. But what if you’re looking for a car that won’t break the bank with a design that will age like a fine wine? They’re out there; you just have to know where to look. And I suggest you look at the Volkswagen Jetta.

German cars are many things, but frivolous and faddish are not among them. I was surprised to learn that a Volkswagen Jetta can be had for around $20,000, because it has the class and sophistication of a more expensive car. You won’t find any weirdly shaped headlights or special edition pastel paint colors on this baby. Just clean lines and German engineering.

The 2014 Volkswagen Jetta SE I tested tipped the scales at $23,985 including destination, thanks to the Connectivity and Sunroof package, which adds $3,170 to the price of a base SE model. The package adds keyless access, push-button start, a power sunroof, and Volkswagen’s Car-Net connectivity features. It also makes a Jetta that might be just out of reach for someone looking in the low-$20,000s range. If you’re willing to forgo those features, though, an SE can be had for $19,715. And you’ll still get attractive leatherette seats, SiriusXM capability, partial power front seats, and a media device interface with iPod cable.

I liked the Jetta’s clean-looking interior. The touchscreen radio that came as part of the Connectivity package was easy to use, although not nearly as attractive as the systems offered by some of Volkswagen’s competitors. I found myself appreciating, too, that the steering wheel was relatively free of buttons. I may not have been able to launch a missile from the driver's seat, but I was happy to be holding a simple, uncluttered wheel in my hands for a change. No one will confuse the Jetta with a luxury car; leatherette’s no leather. But I did think our car’s all-black interior, like its inoffensive exterior, would age well. It’s the kind of car you could buy right out of college and still be proud to drive five years and a couple of promotions later.

And you’d be happy driving it, too. Our Jetta had Volkswagen’s new 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine. It’s a replacement for the Jetta’s outgoing 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine. This new offering makes 170 horsepower and feels quick and sure-footed on the road, while getting 36 mpg on the freeway. Yes, you could find a small sedan that earned 40 mpg on the highway if you really wanted to, but I for one would miss the Jetta’s pep.

The Verdict:

Buyers looking for a car in the Jetta’s size (small) and price range (affordable) are lucky to have a lot of good choices. I was impressed by the Jetta’s styling and driving dynamics, but it’s not the only worthy choice. Many cars in this class are more efficient than the Jetta and, to be honest, have a little more character. I’d be tempted by the Mazda 3, for instance. It’ll come down to personal preference for most buyers, but I think the Jetta’s classic looks and lively driving character tip the scales in its favor.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: I used to enjoy the quirky Germanic feeling all Volkswagens used to have: that train-station chime when you first turned the key, the tiny little fussy controls, and the seat that had to be dialed to move the seat forward. It’s slightly disappointing to find that the modern-day Jetta is very much like the modern-day Honda Accord or Chevrolet Cruze inside. That, I think, is a loss, but I’m glad that the Jetta still looks like a VW on the outside, and it still feels tight and controlled to drive, another fine Volkswagen trait.

Molly Jean: This is a great car. It has classic beauty. Like Cindy Crawford, it is still going to look good as it ages. The view of the instrument panel through the steering wheel is perfect; no need to twist your head around. In fact, the whole cabin is logical, and the materials, although basic, seem like they will hold up through the years. This is a car that I can see being handed down for several generations.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pages.metaDescription: 300-word story with photos -- Rosie the Riveter group getting together socially and talking about their lives since working at Willow Run during World War II
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: Military Appreciation Night at the USA Hockey game: this was not going to be a typical game. My daughter Sarah, USA Hockey’s vocalist, was singing the National Anthem with a full ROTC color guard, and the Ann Arbor Ice Cube, Ann Arbor’s main rink and home to USA Hockey’s National Development Team program, was packed. It must have been an off night for the NHL, for the place was crawling with scouts, and not of the Eagle kind. You can always tell NHL scouts: neatly coiffed and dressed in black with nice shoes, the scout uniform.
Through the sea of men in black, I suddenly caught a glimpse of a red and white polka-dot bandana, the signature of a different type of uniform.  Scouts are not uncommon at USA games, but a Rosie?

“Rosie the Riveter,” the alter ego of Jane Vass, was there to drop the puck for the game, in honor of the women who shored up manufacturing during World War II and to raise awareness of the Save the Bomber Plant campaign. You never know who you’ll run into at the Cube.

Jane was just as surprised to see me, having met me, in my guise as art historian and reporter, at the Willow Run Bomber Plant closing. “This must be fate! Tomorrow, I am having a luncheon for some original Rosies. Can you come?”

Lunch with History

As soon as lunch began, I realized that I was recording history as six remarkable women in their late eighties and early nineties recalled, as best they could, seventy-year-old memories of working during World War II. Toni Hunter was a “Wendy the Welder,” from the Philadelphia shipyard. Frances Masters, Lela Talbott Detrich, Ruth Webb, and Rachel Mae Perry spent their days “poppin’ rivets” at Willow Run, and Vivian Litchard (center in this photo) worked in the sewing department. Three were local girls; the others moved to the area for the work. Mrs. Perry (right), the daughter of sharecroppers and eldest of eight, came from Kentucky. Her paychecks went home for support. Mrs. Webb (left) said her whole family moved to the area from rural Indiana. She remembers the journey vividly: all twenty family members, including two babies, on the back of a flatbed truck. Her father refused to stop, so the only way to provide for the babes was to milk the goat they had in tow.

Through the individual stories, general themes emerged. They loved to work, and some of them continued in manufacturing after the war. They remember the visitors, such as when President Roosevelt or Marilyn Monroe, who herself started as a riveter, came to the plant. They were all barely eighteen then, so many of their memories revolved around gender relations. The male employees fell into two groups: “4-Fs,” ineligible for service for physical reasons (and, it seems, ineligible for dating), and supervisors, men beyond draftable age. Mrs. Litchard, who at eighty-eight is still striking, recalls her boss, twelve years her senior, asking her to dinner, but he didn’t want to pick her up in front of the other girls in the village—to "avoid appearances of favoritism."  She later met his wife.

At this revelation, they all had such stories to share. And, without bitterness but in recognition of injustice, they noted the inequities. They were paid five cents less an hour than the men in comparable jobs. When the war ended, the men received pensions, while they were simply laid off.

These women established the presence of women in manufacturing. Thinking of these six remarkable women, I can’t help feeling such admiration for the “Rosie the Riveters” who paved a path for the generations of women who followed.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
The Farmer in All of Us: An American Portrait ($45)

Yesterday was a day to be thankful, and I am personally thankful for all the farmers who grow our food. At the Super Bowl last February, the Ram truck brand ran an ad that featured American farmers and launched a year-long initiative to bring attention to American farmers. The Corvette turned 100 this year, and nothing says happy birthday better than neon. I can immediately think of three people on my list who would swoon for this.

Volkswagen Bus Tent ($650)

I have always wanted a VW bus. Now I can buy one for under $1,000. (Or many other, less expensive VW-logo-bearing items from the same site.)

Drop Stop ($19.95)

I am a sucker for infomercials, but I think these two guys will win you over, too. No free Ginsu knives, but there are two freebies.

Mini Car Wash (free)

This is my Black Friday gift to you. No need to say thanks, but if you insist, share a comment at the end of this article.

Ladies’ Vintage Derby Cap ($14.95)

For all the Mustang Sallys out there, here is a chapeau that is worthy of both you and your ride. Ride, Sally, ride.

BMW Baby Racer II ($108)

There is no reason to wait until your baby turns sweet sixteen to buy his or her first car.

Women’s Prancing Horse Ultra-Shiny Nylon Jacket ($357)

Everyone and your mother has a black puffy coat, but I have never seen one with a little red prancing horse, and I have a weakness for anything shiny.

Vintage Overnight Bag ($35)

When I was knee-high to a grasshopper, my swim bag looked exactly like this one, and I thought it was the bees' knees. Now Fiat has made one even better: it is red, and it says Fiat. Winner.

Richard Scarry's Cars and Trucks from A to Z ($3.99)

This book is not a new release, but it is a must-have for any little nuggets on your gift list. The crayon car is my fave.

pageElements.text: Have you ever taken your kids to a museum and let them put in a dollar to get one of those quickie injection-molded plastic souvenirs? This is the Hot Wheels equivalent for your house. There is no doubt in my mind that this $49.99 play set will get put to use within minutes of being unwrapped. Whether the novelty will wear off quickly is another story.

I am frowning on, but choosing to ignore, the Mattel advertising that reads: “Boys can make their very own vehicles in a matter of minutes!” After looking in vain for the Y Chromosome Locator that is needed to start the thing up, I chose to chuckle dismissively rather than, you know, run over the ad writer’s fingers with my freshly cooked Hot Wheels Car Maker car. Let’s all resolve to find girls to give this to.

How It Works

The Hot Wheels Car Maker starts with ten sticks of various-colored wax and two generic Hot Wheels molds. You choose your color and mold, set it into the Car Maker, and eight minutes later, the warm body is ready to go. Voice and music prompts, plus flashing lights, tell the user when to put the wax in, when to start the cooking process, and when it’s safe to take the mold out. (Do you think every kid is going to be that patient? But I digress.) You then set the body on your choice of three chassis types, and tart it up with the included sticker pack, and off it goes to race on whatever Hot Wheels tracks your kid has set up, or just down the sidewalk or across the carpet.

One reviewer on Amazon.com made me laugh: “The cars don't break, even when involved in traffic incidents. They bounce off each other like the product of some safety-minded car designer.” Wax cars for the masses!

This being a major toy company, you know there are refill packs, each sold separately, and you're going to need them. The Hot Rods, Street Muscle, or Beast Riders accessory mold packs include wax, molds, and chassis, and they cost $11.99. You can order this and other Hot Wheels products directly from the Mattel Shop online and benefit from free shipping and other discounts during the shopping season.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The week before Thanksgiving, I was thanking Volkswagen of America for hosting me along with a merry band of journalists at the Los Angeles Auto Show press preview days. They left a 2013 Tiguan for me at the airport because I arrived a day before everyone else in order to set up camp in my room at The Standard hotel.

I started Monday bright and early, ready to field back-to-back radio interviews across the country to talk about Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Automobile of the Year. Not quite early enough. I began the busy morning by missing my first interview with Detroit hometown hero and recent inductee in the National Radio Hall of Fame, WJR’s Paul W. Smith.
Arrgghhhhh.
Paul W. announced the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray as Automobile of the Year without my sugary, weepy patter, as he told me the next day, when I was graciously rescheduled.

After that, though, surrounded by a zillion notes (“don’t forget to mention automobilemag.com as much as possible”), I leapt from call to call, crisscrossing the nation’s radio waves, talking about Corvette; Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Man of the Year, chief Vette engineer Tadge “Don’t Take No for an Answer” Juechter; the city of Detroit; the industry; and even threw in a little JeanKnowsCars.com while I was at it.

I picked up JKC videographer Scott Allen and my husband, Tim, from LAX and headed to a late lunch and a stiff Bloody Mary at The Standard. I couldn’t wait to show Tim the shower and its clear glass viewing wall next to the bed. Enforced voyeurism is really not our thing. I checked at the reception desk to see if there was a room with a private bathroom. No luck. An entire hotel built for voyeurs. We decided on staggered breakfast shifts so the other could shower in privacy.
Enough of that visual. Good night.

You might have seen my chaotic auto show videos. It is always like that for me. But this year in L.A. I decided that Scott and I would focus only on shooting as many car designers as we could manage, talking about the hottest car on their stands. We’ll roll out these videos over the next few weeks in Jean’s Driveway, where we have a special section called Designer Walkaround.

In between designer appointments, I gave BMW design head Adrian van Hooydonk Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Design of the Year for the brilliant i8, a car the Automobile’s design editor, Robert Cumberford, praised as retaining “all the spirit and sense of the show car’s Blade Runner futurism in something we can buy and drive in 2014.” Amen.
I also gave GM North America president Mark Reuss his well-deserved 2014 AOY trophy for the Stingray. His favorite color Stingray is blue, so that’s where we posed.

Your title here...

I managed to miss all of the important reveals, which meant I missed (not) being mashed in the crowd with the other several thousands of journalists, bloggers, and people who managed to sneak in. Instead, I carefully timed my walk of the vast show (covering two large halls) to arrive when most everyone else had surged on to the next announcement. This gave me a perfect opportunity to do a lightning walk of the Audi exhibit. Four different iterations of the soon-to-be-hot A3 were on stage just on Wednesday, and we got the shorthand version of what and when from product manager Anthony Foulk:

No parties for me, which meant I missed (not) dubious celebrities Simon Cowell and Kelly Osbourne at the Jaguar party. Instead, I visited the new Jaguar F-Type coupe on the stand with chief designer Ian Callum and shared the great news of his brother Moray’s elevation to the top design job at Ford in the wake of the sudden departure of J Mays. I also ran into Moray, who was as calm and beatific as I had ever seen him. “Hold that feeling close,” I told him. “There will be blood.”
There always is.

Thursday was a much quieter day at the show, where I spent a pleasant morning looking at what I’d missed in the crowd and doing a live interview with another WJR radio luminary, Frank Beckmann. I also discovered that one of my interviews was picked up by Howard Stern. He made fun of my voice, which is only slightly more mockable than my overall demeanor. You go, Howard!
The best part of the day was heading out to Hollywood Park, a ripped-up, lumpy, vast parking lot in a dicey neighborhood, to drive some crazy VWs. Stand by for my report on that later this week.
