pageElements.text: There's a reason USA Today has a summary of the daily news headlines from every state: people move around, and they want to catch a glimpse of places they used to call home. That's the rationale behind this guide. What's the most interesting stuff you can get from various parts of the country without actually going there? Here are a few things we dug up that would make good gifts for the Wisconsin expatriate or regretful ex-Mississippian on your list. The other twenty-five states will be in part 2.

Alaska:

The University of Alaska's Musem of the North store offers Alaska-made crafts (soapstone polar bears, anybody?) and a selection of Alaska-themed books and publications. The "Eskimo Yo-Yo" shown here might not pass muster with PETA, since it's made from seal fur ("colors may vary") but could fascinate the right kind of kid or teenager.

Arizona:

If you want to share Arizona beauty, start with Arizona Highways magazine, for subscriptions, calendars, and prints of the breathtaking photography found in the magazine. Or spend $39.99, and get this coffee-table book with the amazing mountain view and the nearly as amazing split infinitive in the title. There's also the Navajo Nation's Arts and Crafts Enterprise for online turquoise jewelry and the like.

Arkansas:

The state of Arkansas wants kids to appreciate what's made at home, so it offers up (for all ages, really), this list of Arkansas producers with links.

California:

The California State Parks online store has a variety of park-specific shirts, caps, and posters to remember a previous road trip, or inspire your next one. From now until December 17, the site is offering 25 to 50 percent off to holiday shoppers.

Colorado:

The nonprofit Colorado Ski & Snowboard Museum Hall of Fame's glass ski gondola and ski boot ornaments ($8 to $14) might belong on your tree (or a friend's). More tasteful (and with a longer display life) are the dozens of vintage ski poster reproductions (starting at $20).

Connecticut:

It's not what you'd call historic (having been founded by Swedes, in 1995), but Bridgewater Chocolate is a Connecticut original and very popular. They're sold at five locations around Connecticut, including the factory store in Bridgewater, plus Dean & DeLuca in New York City. Or, order them here.

Delaware:

The Visit Delaware Store is small, like the state, but it does include a 2014 tourism calendar and souvenirs from the small but mighty Wine and Ale Trail.

Florida:

You can go beyond the bag of oranges or the citrus-themed ashtray with Viva Florida, a website celebrating th state's 150th anniversary in 2013. Viva Florida perfume (for Him or Her, $145 and up), a Ponce de Leon necktie ($75), and a Guy Harvey commemorative T-shirt ($25) are on offer. For a fuller listing of goods, try Florida's History Shop, where you can find all kinds of products bearing the state seal.

Georgia:

This state is paying a great deal of attention to the 150th anniversary of the Civil War, and this store has patches, books, and memorabilia for all ages and levels of interest.

Hawaii:

Forget leis and macadamia nuts, at least for a moment. The best thing out of Hawaii has got to be Lion Coffee, plus the well-designed packaging and related merchandise you can order online.

Idaho:

The First Lady of Idaho has a website offering children’s books and china in the official state of Idaho pattern. Live like an Idaho governor at $315 per place setting! I'm not even going to dignify your question with an answer as to whether there are potatoes in the design.
For Idaho fans on a budget, try the Idaho State Capitol Gift Shop for this year's official state capitol ornament. It's $21.95 postpaid, dated, in a gift box, with a pine bough inside.

Illinois:

Hey, Route 66 fans! The Route 66 Store in Pontiac, Illinois, has this kind of cool stuff.

Iowa:

The Heart of Iowa Marketplace offers "Keepin' It Rural" T-shirts in John Deere green, plus gift baskets that are heavy on the jam and other sweets, pig and cow novelties, and more.

Kansas:

The Kansas Historical Society has high prairie goods at low prairie prices, such as this Soul of Kansas essay compilation for $12.95, or a very wide range of refrigerator magnets and bracelet charms for under $5 each. Some have Carrie Nation on them.

Kentucky:

You can spend a happy hour touring the Louisville Slugger bat factory downtown, or an equally happy online hour perusing the Louisville Slugger Museum Gift Shop. A personalized bat in various colors, with your own (or your kid's) autograph on it, is $64.99.

Louisiana:

Storyville Apparel sells T-shirts and hoodies with New Orleans and Cajun themes. If you prefer to eat your Louisiana souvenirs, try Cajun Grocer ("Over 1,000 Authentic Cajun Food Products"). And Louisiana Travel has eight more Louisiana-themed websites on its Top Ten list.

Mississippi:

The Mississippi Musicians’ Hall of Fame shop has such treasures as these cigar-box guitars ($225-$385) that really play. There's also a Mississippi Blues Musicians Map, suitable for framing, that shows names, stage names, and places of birth of some 300 blues musicians from this state ($25 postpaid).

New Hampshire:

Goat-milk soap. "Live Free or Die" refrigerator magnets. This, and more, from the NH Made store.

North Dakota:

The North Dakota Tourism Gift Shop sells hoodies, neckties, T-shirts, and other apparel with a North Dakota script logo. Plus some nice ceramic mugs, as shown at the top of this page.

Ohio:

The state of Ohio has been important in some recent election nailbiters. So it's fitting that some of the most interesting Ohio memorabilia is politically related. Try the State House Shop for such things as Votes for Women mugs, Dogs Playing Cards style political art like the great Democratic Presidents poster shown here (there's a Republican Presidents equivalent), plus a range of Donkey and Elephant jewelry.

Oregon:

For official Pendleton woolens for which the state is famous, visit the Made in Oregon store. The Pendleton saddle blanket shown here measures 68 by 39 inches and costs $136. For another way to keep warm, order some Oregon wines, craft beers, and hard ciders from the same site.

South Dakota:

There used to be a sign by the Amsterdam train station stating that it was some number in the thousands of kilometers to Wall Drug. (Who knows if that billboard still exists in this post-ironic age?) But back here in the U.S.A., if you've driven cross country by the northern route, you couldn't miss the succession of signs telling you how many miles you were from the monolithic Wall Drug complex in the otherwise unremarkable burg of Wall, South Dakota. You can order a custom sign stating how many miles your home (or your gift recipient's) is from Wall Drug. It's on sale for the holiday season at $26.25, but delivery is four to six weeks, so hurry.
On a less commercial note, the South Dakota Historical Society Foundation shop has more serious items for sale such as pottery, glassware, and books, with proceeds benefiting the organization.

Texas:

I fondly remember a postcard I once bought during a trip: "The sun has riz/the sun has set; And here we iz/in Texas yet." That is no joke, as anybody who has driven the breadth of the massive state can attest. Visit the Texas HIghways website for bluebonnet, lone star, "Don't Mess with Texas," and other iconic Texas items, plus a calendar and an interesting shelf of Texas-themed books.

Virginia:

Take your pick between Virginia Is for Lovers merchandise that veers toward the mildly tacky, or a burlap bag of Whitley's peanuts for which the state is well known.

Wisconsin:

Discover Wisconsin is a TV show, and on its website, you can shop for solid middle American stoneware, coasters, and the odd Vince Lombardi themed item.

metaDescription: Volvo's Child Safety Manual is basic, but its message is compelling. Plus, it's free. Read about it and find out where to download it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Volvo has done really well in branding itself as the "safety company." Of course, all cars, not just Volvos, are safer today than they have ever been, and certainly children are riding more safely than they were, say, during my childhood, when my baby sister would lie in the back seat with her head on my lap and her feet on my older sister's lap. None of us wore seatbelts for the first several years of my life; nobody did. By comparison, kids today are very well protected.

But there's always more to know, and to do, no matter what brand of car you drive. That's why the Volvo Car Group puts out a guidebook called Children & Cars: A Safety Manual, which you can download here.

Facing Backward until Age Three?

The biggest take-away from this beautifully designed, globally aimed manual is that children need to be in a rear-facing child seat until the advanced age of three years old. Until a few years ago, it was accepted wisdom in the United States that children needed to ride in a rear-facing seat until twenty pounds or age one, whichever came first. Around 2011, that all changed, and we are now told that age two is much safer for children. But Volvo is no latecomer to the rear-facing mandate: It made its first rear-facing child seat concept in 1967. The reason? Because children's heads are heavy relative to their young bodies, and their necks and vertebrae are not fully developed, so they can be injured more easily when facing forward in the event of a crash.

Fun facts: Volvo thinks everyone riding in a car would be safer if they faced backward. (Not that it would be practical, of course.) And the Swedish scientist who made the first rear-facing seat was inspired by the way the Gemini astronauts of the Sixties were seated during takeoff and landing.

The Volvo manual has been praised in its two previous editions and even won a publishing award in Sweden in 2007. It's free; get into a Volvo frame of mind and download it, if you have children (or child passengers in your car on a regular basis). And comment below on the rear-facing question: did you keep your children facing backward for any length of time? How long? Was it a relief to turn those seats around?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The first thing you notice is just how tall this vehicle is from the outside. It’s HUGE!!! It could be bigger than the family Suburban. Wait; let me check the specs. No, it's just an optical illusion. The Suburban is more than two feet longer. At least I knew the Lexus would be big enough for our long Thanksgiving weekend plans.

The next sense of imposing bulk overwhelms you when you slide behind the wheel. The LX's seating position is very high. You can't lower the seats, so if you have a long torso, you may be banging into the headliner. In any case, it feels like you're at the wheel of a Greyhound. Getting coffee at the McDonald’s drive-through involves leaning down to the window to pay.

The price of this particular LX is also vast at a grand total of $88,555. Of course it’s absolutely loaded, but options account for only $5,860 of that, so you might as well enjoy the $2,005 DVD entertainment system, the $2,350 Mark Levinson nineteen-speaker (!) sound system, and the $1,510 luxury package (heated and ventilated leather seats, wood trim, and coolbox). I did, because it's been abnormally cold in Michigan this month.

It's a little bit fussy opening the center console to get at your pops, because the lid has two armrests side by side above it. The buttons you first see slide the armrests fore and aft. You actually have to reach under those armrests to find the release for the center console.

The rear hatch is split horizontally, so when you open it, the top flips up, and a simple lever lowers the tailgate, which is heavy. The third row splits and folds up against the sides and out of the way via electric controls mounted inside the cargo area by the tailgate. Side-folding seats compromise the available width somewhat compared with seats that flip and fold down into the floor, but the LX is so vast that you might not notice any lack of space. My bigger concern was whether or not it would fit in the garage next to the Volkswagen Jetta. It did, but it made the Jetta look like a miniature car.

We had a long trip to make to northern Michigan for Thanksgiving, and it was easy to put all the food we brought in the back. We hit the snow head on for three hours, but the full-time four-wheel drive worked very well.

It’s easy to appreciate the 5.7-liter V-8 and its 383 horsepower and 403 pound-feet of torque when gas comes free with your job. But why do all Japanese V-8s need premium fuel? It was kind of embarrassing (and this coming from an owner of a Suburban) that we were in such a large vehicle that got pretty bad fuel economy and needed premium fuel to boot.

The ride is pretty sloppy unless you select Sport mode, and then it settles down without being rough at all. If you have a lot of large adults, this is a super comfortable vehicle, almost wasted on kids.

We bought our Volkswagen Jetta as Bob’s show-dog kennel, so we wouldn't have to take the Suburban to dog shows with only one dog banging around in back. Bob had a big dog show on the weekend in Lansing, Michigan, and I wasn't about to take him in the Lexus, even though the gas was free.

The dog show was was good to Bob. He won both days.

I did a lot of cooking this weekend. I cooked a turkey that my husband managed to leave behind on the counter when he went hunting in Iowa on Monday morning. I at least made soup from the carcass. I also whipped up a pumpkin pie, and I made bread pudding with the leftover bread crusts in the freezer.

I couldn't bring myself to do anything on Black Friday but stay home, but while at the dog show on Saturday, I went out to lunch with my brother, who is a grad student at Michigan State University. We went to Best Buy, where all the deals that were happening on Friday were still in place in place on Saturday. Only no one else was in the store. Score!

I spent several days during the weekend talking to my niece about buying a car. We talked extensively about how to do the negotiations and how to evaluate the desirability of the options listed on the cars that she was interested in. This got me all exercised about helping my brother find a used car. Car shopping is not for the faint of heart if you do not have a dealer you can trust. You really need to do your research and take your time.

I found myself looking at all the used cars advertised in the weekend paper as Black Friday specials. You know, it's funny, even knowing what I know about buying cars, how these terrible feelings wash over me just looking at the ads for used cars. Am I getting taken? Is 2003 a good year for a Pontiac Vibe? Am I going to be able to negotiate a good and fair deal? Is it going to break in a year?

Heavy sigh.

Onward and upward,
Jean

title: Car Buying: What Do Women Want?
promoTitle: Car Buying: What Do Women Want?
promoTeaserSmall: Carmakers aren't good at selling to us. Expert Tinesha Craig tells how to get what we need anyway.
promoTeaser: Carmakers aren't good at selling to us. Expert Tinesha Craig tells how to get what we need anyway.
metaTitle: Car Buying: What Do Women Want?
metaDescription: Car Buying: What Do Women Want? So many dealers are doing it wrong! Expert Tinesha Craig tells us how to get what we need anyway. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s a fact: women make 62 percent of new car purchases and make nearly 80 percent of car purchasing decisions in the United States. So why are automakers still struggling to effectively target this huge buying audience? Tinesha Craig, director of the i on Women division of the market research firm Insights in Marketing, took a look at how women view the car buying process. She found that only 26 percent of women said they were "extremely satisfied"  with the options available to them in the automotive market.

Craig surveyed women about their habits and experiences in shopping for cars to try to figure out what needs to change. What she learned was that—perhaps unsurprisingly—women aren’t all that different from men when it comes to shopping for cars. But there are a few places where we differ. “In terms of motivators and thought process, [men and women] are fairly similar,” Craig said in a phone interview. But women are more likely to start their shopping process online, and have a greater desire to feel informed before we ever set foot in a dealership. Here are five things that are important to women buyers. Automakers, are you listening?

1. We Want Clarity on the Web

There's a lot of information available on automakers' websites now. Unfortunately, many automakers have websites that aren’t fully responsive to the needs of a variety of shoppers. Websites often fail to clearly demonstrate a car’s full range of features, tending to focus in on its performance attributes instead. “Some women may be interested in performance, some want to know about safety features. It’s important to understand the range,” Craig explained. She said many shoppers would benefit from a full, jargon-free rundown of a car’s features and how it compares to the competition.
We want to know how long cars will last, how reliable they’ll be, and what kind of warranty the manufacturer offers. It should be easier to make head-to-head comparisons.

2. We Want to See Warranty and Resale Information

Women also buy new cars less frequently than their male counterparts, meaning they hold on to cars for longer. This means we want to know how long our cars will last, how reliable they’ll be, and what kind of warranty the manufacturer offers. “The warranty piece, I think, is a mystery to everybody,” said Craig. While some automakers tout their warranties and resale values, others aren’t as clear. It should be easier to make head-to-head comparisons and find the details on the model you are looking at.

3. We Expect a Little Respect at the Dealership

While we’re waiting for car companies to wise up to the things they could do to cater to women in the shopping process, is there anything women can do to streamline the process ourselves? Craig acknowledged that for many women, a trip to the dealership can be a stressful experience. “Going to the dealer feels like being in a pressure cooker. The focus is on [the dealer], not what the customer wants.” This could be why so many women start their search online in hopes of avoiding an unpleasant experience at the dealership. Craig said she has walked away from a dealership that gave her “that slimy, icky feeling,” opting instead for one that treated her with respect and gave her plenty of time to test drive the car she was interested in.

4. We Listen to Our Friends

Craig said that in her own car buying process, she has relied on advice from trusted friends instead. That’s not uncommon: 63 percent of the women she surveyed also looked to friends for car advice. Dealers should be leveraging the socially interactive female customer by asking them to refer friends and inviting them to bring friends along on the buying process.

5. We Want Car Buying to Be Fun

If you’re dreading a trip to the dealer, don't. You have the purchasing power to make it a good experience. Starting your search online could be a good way to get some basic information about the cars you’re interested in. The test drive is still a crucial step, so don’t put up with a dealer who won’t give you the time you need. Find one who will help you feel good about the process of buying a car, and be sure you're comfortable with your purchase before you sign on the dotted line. Craig lamented that car buying has become such a chore for some women. “There’s a lot of frustration with this process, but there doesn’t need to be. It should be exciting.”

title: Why Pascale Loves Her Countryman
subTitle: This French expatriate in New York City replaced a Lincoln with a très chic Mini Cooper Countryman.

metaTitle: Why Pascale Loves Her Countryman
metaDescription: Why Pascale Loves Her Countryman: Dr. Pascale Gousseland's love for her new Mini Cooper Countryman, as narrated to Elizabeth Sobieski. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pages.metaDescription: Dr. Pascale Gousseland's love for her new Mini Cooper Countryman, as narrated to Elizabeth Sobieski.
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: “My car 'ees' so stylish and so much fun!” says Dr. Pascale Gousseland, a New York-based French psychoanalyst specializing in family practice, addiction, and personality disorders. We are in a covered parking garage on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, and Pascale points to a copper-hued (she calls the color “cognac”) crossover with white hood stripes. It's her new Mini Countryman.

As a young student at the Sorbonne in Paris, Pascale scooted around the Place de l’Etoile, the insane traffic circle that revolves around the Arc de Triomphe where twelve boulevards converge, in a dark blue Mini that she absolutely adored. There were neither airbags nor air conditioning in the iconic two-door vehicle, and the only "très cool" option was a radio. She eventually had to replace that spirited car with other Minis, which tended to break down after meeting too many potholes.

From the Continent to the Continental

Pascale's family then did the unthinkable (for Parisians)! They moved to the United States, and her father, Pierre, became passionate about large American automobiles, what Pascale calls “boat cars”: Cadillacs and Lincoln Continentals offering an automatic ride that seemed to float compared with the old manual-transmission Minis, which served passengers a “tape-cul”: a sore butt on a long drive. Her father’s final Lincoln was “spacious and gracious,” according to Pascale, who is also a published poet. And when her father died nine years ago, she inherited his beloved 1994 vehicle.

The Lincoln was a good car for making jaunts to her weekend home in Greenwich, Connecticut. Her three not petite dogs were able to travel in luxury. But after 137,000 miles, it was time to retire that silver ship.

Mini Nostalgia Claims Another Customer

And Pascale immediately thought about the speedy small cars of her youth. She had begun to notice more Minis in New York and wondered about the newest models. The original inexpensive front-wheel-drive BMC Mini Coopers were top-drawer rally racing cars in the 1960s that eventually became the most popular British automobiles ever made. But now the Mini name was part of Germany's BMW.

At the dealership in White Plains, New York, she test-drove several models: the Clubman, the Paceman, and the Countryman, and was impressed. The new Minis felt solid, the ride as smooth as that of a “boat car,” and she admired the retro styling. She returned to the dealer with her three dogs and a blanket, and the dealer allowed her to try the various models for canine-carrying size. She saw that the dogs, Matheo, Scottee, and Foo, immediately relaxed in the Mini Cooper S Countryman ALL4, a four-door hatchback with a back seat that flattens. There's no space relinquished to a spare tire, as the car features run-flat tires that can sustain themselves for fifty miles when punctured. And the rear windows supplied unobstructed viewing for the dogs.
It is a happy, funny, original car. You feel very comfortable inside. It is full of little gadgets. And I feel safe, which was never true in the old Mini.

Delighted with what she encountered, she ordered the cognac-colored car with extensive options, including all-wheel drive, a two-tone leather interior, Bluetooth and USB connectivity, a sunroof, xenon headlights, an adjustable traction control system, keyless entry, rear parking sensors, auto-dimming mirrors, heated mirrors, and an automatic transmission. And it boasts a terrific Harman Kardon ten-speaker audio system, mocking the tinny radio of old.

Although her Mini only has a 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, the S model is turbocharged, producing 181 horsepower and 177 pound-feet of torque. Pascale tells me: “It is a happy, funny, original car. You feel very comfortable inside. It is full of little gadgets. And I feel safe, which was never true in the old Mini. My new car has seven airbags!"

The Car for a City Dweller

The garage attendant brings the handsome Mini out to the street, and we drive downtown. The car is so agile and easy to park! Pascale notes she can always find parking places in the city, even though the Mini dwells in the garage at night. Its fuel economy averages 26 miles per gallon, and the warranty covers four years or 50,000 miles, with free maintenance for the first three years or 36,000 miles.

The dashboard looks typically English, even though Mini has been owned by BMW for twenty years. Like its driver, this car is very international. The Countryman engine is still manufactured in the U.K., the transmission is from Japan, and the car was assembled in Graz, Austria. And a Countryman ALL4 won the Dakar Rally in 2013.
While her father’s beloved old Lincoln still exists in her mother’s garage, Pascale now gets to zip around New York City looking "très chic" in her Mini that now has all the comfort of a Maxi.

The white racing stripe is part of the "happy, funny, original" feeling Pascale likes.
She manages to find room for three dogs in the car.
Tres chic, says French expatriate Dr. Pascale Gousseland.
Even though Jean Knows Cars believes in harnesses for dogs in the car, check out how well three large dogs fit in this Countryman!

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Once you arrive at an auto show—especially one like the Los Angeles Auto Show, which has two large halls that take some time to cover in detail—it's hard to get outside. And once you do get outside, you are in downtown L.A., surrounded by triple-decker freeways jammed with cars that are frequently stopped cold, and a sky the color of seven-layer bean dip.

But my L.A. show host, Volkswagen of America, planned a fun couple of hours driving a trio of oddball Volkswagens at Hollywood Park, a vast parking lot in Inglewood, California, within a thirty-minute drive of the show. Make that a one-hour drive at 1 p.m. Well, let's just say that once committed to leaving the show, I abandoned the idea of ever getting back to it the same day. The traffic was even more horrendous than normal, so the idea of driving any cars at all without the great mass of southern California humanity pressing upon me from all sides seemed sweet indeed. When I arrived at the Hollywood Park, I noticed the sky was getting blacker by the minute and looked like it was going to pour rain, which, by the way, it very rarely does in L.A. The wind was whipping like hell, and it was not warm in the least.

While a couple of other journalists were out on the course, I headed for the al fresco lounge that VW had set up in the parking lot (as one does when entertaining the automotive press), complete with a gourmet food truck, to have a warm cup of coffee and a bowl of chili. Much to my surprise, there was Hans Stuck, Hurley Haywood’s old Audi teammate back when Audi dominated Trans-Am racing. All I could think about when I saw him was the famous story about when Stuck and a racing buddy were waiting for a flight from a race in Australia back to Germany and decided to kill time taking the rental car for a little drive out of town into the Outback.

During the course of the drive, they nailed a random kangaroo with the rental. They jumped from the car and stared at this dead kangaroo lying in the middle of the road, when crazy Stucky got a crazy idea. They sat the dead kangaroo up on his feet, dressed it in Stuck’s sport coat and hat, and just when they were about to take a picture of Stuck with the deceased (but quite dapper) kangaroo, it came to life and hopped off into the Outback. It was still wearing Stuck’s sport coat.

Problem was, the sport coat held Stuck’s return ticket and passport. We can only imagine Stuck and friend explaining themselves to the local Australian authorities. If that story is apocryphal, it doesn't really matter, does it?

I write of kangaroos and food trucks because I had forgotten that driving concept cars was not really my idea of a good time. It’s like writing. It’s fun to have written, but not so much fun to write.

Volkswagen XL1 Concept

My first drive was in the XL1, revealed at the 2011 Qatar Auto Show and promised by Dr. Martin Winterkorn, VW’s chairman, to be in production by 2013. The last I looked, 2013 was winding quickly down, and the car I drove was definitely not ready for prime time. At least not in America. Never mind that VW has in fact sold fifty XL1s in Germany for about $150,000 apiece. The harshness and noise would make this car totally unacceptable here. The whole purpose of the car was to be a hyper-fuel-efficient exercise, a “one-liter car” in that it could go 100 kilometers on one little liter of fuel. After several years of trying and several iterations, this current XL1 actually beat the goal, achieving 100 km on 0.9 liter of diesel fuel.

VW engineers employed every aero, every fuel economy, and every weight-saving trick it had learned in the nine years it worked on the one-liter car. The ingredients: a slippery body (rearview cameras replaced side mirrors) with a Cd of .189, a lightweight monocoque made of carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer, polycarbonate side windows, and a Volkswagen TwinDrive plug-in hybrid powerplant allowing separate or tandem operation of a lithium-ion battery, an electric motor, and a one-liter, two-cylinder TDI engine.

One reason cars weigh a lot is that they’re heavily padded to create a magic carpet ride and a quiet womb for the driver. With every scrap of non-essential padding gone and the rear-mounted diesel essentially sitting behind my head, the XL1 was all lumbering rattletrap with no magic carpet ride to write home about.

Still. Do the kilometers-to-miles conversion. If VW actually brings this incredible accomplishment to the American public, 261 miles per gallon may be worth putting up with a few body noises, suspension thumps, and diesel rattles. But for $150,000, I think I want my cake and I want to eat it, too.

Volkswagen Design Vision GTI

The Design Vision GTI was revealed during VW’s press conference earlier in the day as an exercise showing how far Volkswagen could go in making the most futuristic, the most extreme GTI they could conceive of. It looks pretty damn cool.

This GTI has a twin-turbo V-6 making 503 horsepower, a 0-to-62-mph time of 3.9 seconds, and a top speed of 186 mph. So it makes sense that it was first seen at the Worthersee tuner show in Germany, and it also makes sense that VW is bragging it “eats any type of racetrack.” We would not be eating Hollywood Park this afternoon.

The Vision was much more finished than the XL1, but also a concept-car queen. When I jumped in, I was asked not to make any tight turns and to just drive conservatively around the big wide oval cone course that was set up for our “amusement.”

Only it's never really amusing to drive concept cars. Maybe it’s slightly cool to be seen moving inside one, but not so amusing. There was one moment of fun, though. In both of these concept cars, we drove around a very simple track. It was basically a large swath of asphalt with a slight curve and a breaking point at the end of it through one tight-ish turn that brought us back to the start. On the other side of the parking lot, facing us, I spotted the LAPD doing police car testing. I admit that the devil in me wished I had a super hot GTI and a full-blown slalom course that I could scream through, squealing the tires all the way, and scare the crap out of the cop cars facing us on the other side of the parking lot. Yes, I know. Very juvenile.

APR Super Beetle

The hottest car at Hollywood Park was conceived by the rabid VW fanboys of VWvortex.com and built by APR Motorsport, one of VW’s racing supplier partners. It was unveiled at the 2012 Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) Show, where it won the Gran Turismo Best European Import at SEMA 2012 award for its utter fabulosity.

“A Super Beetle should be super, and to us that means adding all-wheel drive and 500 horsepower to a bone stock Turbo Beetle,” wrote VWvortex.com editor Jamie Vondruska, a month before SEMA in 2012. “And thus our latest project car is born. Yes, we’re excited.”

Of course the first thing APR did was see just how much power that basic turbo engine could produce without actually doing anything to it. They got all the way up to 420 horsepower on standard pistons and rods before they blew the engine. These guys are a laugh riot. Once they got that out of their system, they went to town making an incredibly robust 500-horsepower racing engine for the car from one of the best engines on the planet. Once you do that, you'd better have a suspension and brakes that can handle the power. So the APR Super Beetle gets an H&R adjustable coil-over suspension with VW Racing StreetSport+ camber plates and H&R Sport sway bars, plus more suspension modifications from APR's work on the Audi TT RS. Brakes are from Volkswagen Racing to handle what VW described as "more rigorous stopping duties." I don't know what VW plans to do with this car now that I've had a shot at it, but the result was my idea of a proper show car. One you could drive the wheels off.

Carry on, boys!
To those few Neanderthals on the VWvortex.com site, yes, indeed, the APR Super Beetle is "still a car for girls." Hahaha, goofballs! It's for girls who will use it to kick your sissy butts.

God bless you, Jamie. I peeled off three laps of the quick and dirty cone course set up just for the APR Super Beetle (man, this was some terrible pavement, and what was with the ditch right through the middle of the course ?!?) before the rain came.  When the sky finally dumped, the VW handlers came out and shut us down, putting an end to a most amusing afternoon. Those three laps were worth the trip out from the convention center, and definitely a lot more fun than a second day of clomping around the L.A. Auto Show.
If I'd worn a hat, I'd have tipped it to VW for bringing the auto show spirit to life out on the track.
